description: CLEVELAND  Sonny Gray may have had to fiddle a bit with his new blue cap, which was a size too big, but he otherwise looked at home in his traveling gray jersey as he made his much-anticipated debut on Thursday. Once he got on the mound, Gray made it clear why General Manager Brian Cashman had doggedly pursued him at the trade deadline.

title: Corrections: August 4, 2017
description: NATIONAL

title: Escaping From a Dire Diagnosis on Match.com
description: When my best friend since childhood wound up back on the oncology unit for her third relapse, I decided it was time to start online dating. I knew from Nances prior hospitalizations that talking about lymphoma and PET scans was not her idea of fun. A far better entertainment would be for me to get on Match.com so we could hang out together on her hospital bed scrolling through potential dates.

title: What Qualifies a Woman to Compete as a Woman? An Ugly Fight Resumes
description: For the past two years, Dutee Chand could be herself.

title: Small Transylvania Brewer Stood Up to a Beer Giant, and Survived
description: SANSIMION, Romania  Beer is cheap and abundant in this farm village, hidden near the slopes of the Transylvanian mountains. A dim local bar displays it behind glass doors, in refrigerators filled with cans, glass bottles and two-liter plastic containers. Most are lagers from well-known global brewers, easy to find across Europe.

title: Donald Trump, Robert Mueller, Russia: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Whats on TV Friday: Wet Hot American Summer and Comrade Detective
description: Wet Hot American Summer returns with a follow-up to the 2015 prequel series. And Comrade Detective takes viewers to 1980s Romania.

title: Lawsuit Accuses Former Phoenix Bishop of Sexually Abusing Boy
description: A Roman Catholic bishop who once led the Diocese of Phoenix has been accused of repeatedly sexually abusing a boy decades ago, according to a lawsuit filed in Arizona Superior Court.

title: Mexicos Deadliest Town. Mexicos Deadliest Year.
description: TECOMN, Mexico  He slumped in a shabby white chair, his neck unnaturally twisted to the right. A cellphone rested inches away, as if he had just put it down. His unlaced shoes lay beneath outstretched legs, a morbid still life of what this town has become.

title: The Owner Brought the Money. The Agent Delivered the Players. Now What?
description: WOLVERHAMPTON, England  The formula for success was simple. Last year, when Peter Kenyon  a former chief executive of both Chelsea and Manchester United and now a kind of itinerant soccer rainmaker  approached the English club Wolverhampton Wanderers with a takeover offer from Fosun, the Chinese conglomerate, he outlined a clear vision of how the deal would benefit both parties.

title: Law and Order Catches Up With Sheriff Joe Arpaio
description: Former Sheriff Joe Arpaio, for years a fearsome figure for Arizonas Latinos, was convicted of criminal contempt this week for violating a court order to stop his dragnet harassment of immigrants for documentation.

title: Can People Change After Middle Age?
description: I sometimes read that people dont change much after middle age. But everyday experience contradicts this on a weekly basis.

title: Motherhood Isnt Sacrifice, Its Selfishness
description: I was taking a few weeks break from work over the summer. My family and I  my husband and my sons, then 9 and 7  planned to spend the time at our house on the New Jersey shore. When my mother asked what we would be doing on our vacation, I told her we would be together  going to the beach and the nearby amusement park, cooking, playing in the yard.

title: Lets Stop the Bickering and Fix the Health Care System
description: If either of us were building the American health care system from scratch, wed probably end up in different places.

title: Obamacare Rage in Retrospect
description: I guess it aint over until the portly golfer sings, but it does look as if Obamacare will survive. In the end, Mitch McConnell couldnt find the votes he needed; many thanks are due to Senators Susan Collins, Lisa Murkowski and John McCain (who turns out to be a better man than I thought), not to mention the solid wall of Democrats standing up for whats right. Meanwhile, all indications are that the insurance markets are stabilizing, with insurer profitability up and only around 0.1 percent of enrollees unserved.

title: Stephen Colbert Is Amazed Trump Wont Endorse the Statue of Liberty
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: Chinese Court Sentences Activist Who Documented Protests to 4 Years in Prison
description: HONG KONG  A court in southern China sentenced a blogger to four years in prison for his work documenting mass unrest around the country.

title: Making the City More Accessible
description: As frustrating as the subway can be for most New Yorkers, it is a joy ride compared with the  ordeal that physically challenged commuters face. They are stymied by hard-to-negotiate staircases and hard-to-find elevators. On a typical weekday, 20,000 or more disabled riders turn instead to Access-a-Ride, run by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority with some city help.

title: China Tells India That It Wont Back Down in Border Dispute
description: BEIJING  Chinas military has warned India not to underestimate its resolve to hold a mountainous piece of land at the heart of a standoff between the two Asian powers.

title: Paul Kagame Appears Set for Victory in Rwanda Vote
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Rwandans went to the polls on Friday, appearing to overwhelmingly extend the long tenure of President Paul Kagame, who has guided the country with a steady and at times repressive hand after a genocide two decades ago.

title: Jump In! Double Dutch is Back
description: After a three-decade hiatus, the Double Dutch Summer Classic tournament returned to Lincoln Center to celebrate the history, diversity and evolution of the game.

title: Poets to Discover
description: Assuming that weve all read  or at least know to read  Robert Lowell, Elizabeth Bishop, Philip Larkin and other giants, I asked a few of my colleagues to suggest poets whose work they believe should be better known.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Can You Develop Food Allergies at Any Age?
description: Q. Can adults develop food allergies, such as allergies to peanuts?

title: Judge John Hodgman on the Schrodinger-Like Nature of Chicken Tenders
description: Andy writes: My college friend Bill says chicken tenders are an appetizer. I think that they are an entree. (Theyre often served with fries.) I cant imagine starting a meal with chicken tenders and moving on to an even heavier entree.

title: Prediagnosis
description: Sometimes form is the only way to hold a poems intensities. This poem, a loose pantoum, gives feeling shape. It braids hymnal and elegy. It emits a near-ecstatic passion. I often pause over the line anything can be a drug if you love it. True that. This poem deals with those intensities between feeling nothing and feeling everything. This poet, Sam Sax, is addicted to feeling. Selected by Terrance Hayes

title: How to Lament
description: You must have visible tears, says James M. Wilce, an anthropology professor at Northern Arizona University who studies lamentation, or what he calls melodic wailing with words. Wet cheeks are the minimum: In some places, funeral keeners throw themselves to the ground, sway their bodies or beat at their chests. These age-old, songlike wailing traditions are found worldwide  one ethnomusicologist studying in Egypt has noted that modern mourners raise their clenched fists skyward in the exact posture depicted in ancient tomb paintings  but theyre disappearing from most places. Not so in Finland, where an organization that Wilce studies runs instructional workshops on lamenting as the Karelian people of the region have done for centuries. These three-day classes add a modern twist: Rather than being performed solely at a wake (by what Finns call a cry woman), impromptu requiems are devoted to all manner of emotional hardship, from divorce to illness.

title: The 7.23.17 Issue
description: RE: MOSUL

title: New Sentences: From An Arrangement of Skin, by Anna Journey
description: I have been an animal lover since early childhood, and one of my favorite animal facts, central to my whole understanding of the natural world, has to do with raccoons: that they love to wash their food, and their tiny humanoid paws, in creeks. They spend most of their lives, I have always imagined, hunched over swift-running streams, scrubbing in like doctors, getting ready for the highly technical business of being raccoons.

title: Behind the Cover: 8.6.17
description: Jake Silverstein, editor in chief: We set out to convey, through the exploding scale and the playfully contradictory cover line, the infuriating dissonance of a culture that has begun to reject dieting but has yet to embrace bodies that arent skinny.

title: On the Front Lines of Ohios Heroin Crisis: Playwrights
description: KENT, Ohio  An epidemic that fills coffin after coffin with people in their 20s. Activist-minded theatermakers who work furiously between funerals to bring the tragedy to life onstage. Audience members who express fear that if nothing changes, they or someone they love will be gone soon, too.

title: The Secret Life of the City Banana
description: On a hot day in June, the Hermann Hesse slipped into New York Harbor and headed for the Red Hook Container Terminal in Brooklyn. The 550-foot container ship, flying the Liberian flag, had come some 3,000 miles from Ecuador. It had gone through the Panama Canal, picked up cargo in the Caribbean and weathered a few squalls.

title: A Native American Poet Excavates the Language of Occupation
description: WHEREAS By Layli Long Soldier 101 pp. Graywolf Press. Paper, $16.

title: A San Francisco Restaurant Serving Hawaiian Cuisine (Hold the Pineapple)
description: Just after dawn in Dogpatch, on San Franciscos east side, a golden light falls on parked Tesla Model Ss and on blooming mountain laurels and, at an hour when the air is still touched by a chill, on a crowd that forms most mornings on the corner of 22nd and Minnesota Streets. That is where Aina, a modern Hawaiian restaurant whose brunch has spawned a citywide mania, opened last year in April in a small light-flooded corner space.

title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: First novels rate highly among our offerings this week, from Matthew Klams Who Is Rich? to a debut by the Nigerian author Ayobami Adebayo that drew raves from Michiko Kakutani. Globe-trotting types might want to pick up Andrew Sean Greers Less or Lynn Freeds The Last Laugh, both tales of transformation that happen overseas. And Patricia Highsmith, the author of Strangers on a Train and The Talented Mr. Ripley, stars as the subject of The Crime Writer, a novel by Jill Dawson that plays with the conventions of noir and suspense to blur the lines between reality and imagination. Is it all in your head? Read and find out.

title: Five Poets Offer Eloquent Views of the American Experience
description: LESSONS ON EXPULSION Poems By Erika Snchez 73 pp. Graywolf, paper, $16.

title: With Few Wins in Congress, Republicans Agree on Need to Agree
description: WASHINGTON  Most people do not become United States senators to pass a resolution declaring National Lobster Day. But Congress has had to settle largely for small-bore victories since President Trump was sworn into office, ostentatiously failing to pass a bill to repeal the Affordable Care Act and achieving little substantive policy legislation.

title: Jobs, Factories and Stocks Provide Economic Lift for Trump
description: A stock market hitting record highs. Foreign corporations announcing big new plants in the United States. And robust hiring that has brought the unemployment rate to a 16-year low.

title: Derek Walcott and the Peculiar Disturbance of His Poetry
description: Blown canes. Those were his first words to mark me. Like any true discovery, they came tangled in myth. I was about 16, a sixth former at Titchfield, my high school on a peninsula in Port Antonio, a town on the northeastern coast of Jamaica. Almost daily, for my last thing after school, I went to the towns library. Once inside, I was at sea, isolated, but not alone.

title: When Brokers Want to Move Your Money Out of a Very Good Thing
description: So far this year, heres what our friends in the federal government have done for  and to  citizens who hope to find simple ways to save enough money for retirement without anyone robbing them blind.

title: Exploring the Sources and Consolations of Poetry, in Prose
description: POETRY WILL SAVE YOUR LIFE A Memoir By Jill Bialosky 222 pp. Atria Books. $24.

title: Deep Dives Into How Poetry Works (and Why You Should Care)
description: A LITTLE BOOK ON FORM An Exploration into the Formal Imagination of Poetry By Robert Hass 446 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $29.99.

title: Going Nomad to Avoid Summer Rent Spikes
description: Twenty-five years old, employed and engaged, Elana Rosman had not envisioned moving back to her childhood home in Great Neck, N.Y., on Long Island.

title: Opioid Users Are Filling Jails. Why Dont Jails Treat Them?
description: NEW HAVEN  When Dave Mason left jail in October 2015 after his 14th criminal conviction, the odds were good that he would soon end up dead.

title: Australia Details Sophisticated Plot by ISIS to Take Down Plane
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The Australian police described on Friday an elaborate terrorist plot in which two men from Sydney tried to place an explosive supplied by the Islamic State on a flight last month, an operation that officials said was among the most sophisticated plots that has ever been attempted on Australian soil.

title: How Air-Conditioning Conquered America (Even the Pacific Northwest)
description: Air-conditioning has been remarkably good at creating demand for itself.

title: Donald Trump, Robert Mueller, The Dark Tower: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Daily: The Asian-Americans Suing Harvard, and the Man Behind the Case
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: With a Glimpse of Mortality, Losing Sight of the Wild
description: Before I became a mother, I led wilderness trips. I was strong, firm, sharp. For more than a decade, I took other peoples children up mountains, into woods, across lakes, down rivers, deep into canyons. I held the ropes while they rappelled down cliffs. I paddled the raft while they screamed through rapids. I tied the tarps and gave them shelter; I knelt with them on sodden backpacks halfway down remote trails, singing to distract them from the thunder and lightning crashing around us, while the hairs on our arms stood at attention.

title: Behind Berkeleys Semester of Hate
description: Last semesters protests at the University of California, Berkeley, challenged liberal presumptions about who exactly the good guys were. Anti-fascists, or antifa, clad like ninjas and hellbent on silencing a speaker (the provocateur Milo Yiannopoulos), smashed windows and set fires. Clashes with right-wingers erupted again at rallies in March and April in support of free speech (a messy pepper spray mosh pit, as one anti-fascist described it).

title: New York Today: The Poetry in Politics
description: Good morning on this wet Friday.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Drinking, Tears and Sexual Transmission
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Professors as Targets of Internet Outrage
description: Many professors who have expressed their views about race and politics this year have found themselves targets of both the left and right. Nothing is too abstrusely academic, it seems, to seed an attack campaign fueled by websites that surveil social media to find gotcha-worthy gems. The Professor Watch List, for one, created last year by the conservative group Turning Point USA, is helping drive a new level of scrutiny of professors who, it says, discriminate against conservative students and advance leftist propaganda in the classroom. Some sites even send out alerts to subscribers. The latest casualties:

title: Klansmen Survive Campus Upheavals
description: Racist historical figures have had a legacy-lashing on campus over the last year. Statues have been toppled and buildings rebranded across the land. After student protests and internal review, at least five universities, from the University of Texas at Austin to the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, have renamed buildings that originally honored Ku Klux Klan members. Other universities have not.

title: Learning to Learn: You, Too, Can Rewire Your Brain
description: The studio for what is arguably the worlds most successful online course is tucked into a corner of Barb and Phil Oakleys basement, a converted TV room that smells faintly of cat urine. (At the end of every video session, the Oakleys pin up the green fabric that serves as the backdrop so Fluffy doesnt ruin it.)

title: Listening In on Portland State Activists
description: The Portland State University Student Union explains itself on Twitter as your friendly, neighborhood, radical student action team.

title: Liberal Lessons in Taking Back America
description: Marshall Ganz, shirt sleeves rolled up, spread his arms wide with a join me. Hands came together, slowly at first, then in a flurry of rapid, synchronized thwacks. A member of the old left  he dropped out of Harvard in 1964 to fight for civil rights in Mississippi and for California farmworkers with Cesar Chavez  Dr. Ganz was teaching the unity clap, the audible calling card of the United Farmworkers of America 50 years earlier.

title: More Diversity Means More Demands
description: Last semester was a stormy one for the Claremont Colleges, a consortium of seven elite institutions in suburban Los Angeles.

title: Caregiving Is Hard Enough. Isolation Can Make It Unbearable.
description: For years, Marcy Sherman-Lewis went to a beauty salon in St. Joseph, Mo., every few weeks for a haircut and highlights.

title: Freshman Trends
Renegades and Radical Bodies in 3 New York Exhibitions
description: What makes a radical body? Take three renegades: the choreographer Anna Halprin, the visual artist Robert Rauschenberg and the Japanese designer Rei Kawakubo. Theyre not as disparate as you might think.

title: A 20-Year Age Gap Makes No Difference
description: It was early 2012 when Liz Axelrod met James Olson at a Manhattan bar near the New School, where both were getting Master of Fine Arts degrees; she in poetry, he in fiction. She thought he was cute. He thought she was pretty. They saw each other a few more times, after their Wednesday night class. Finally they talked. And talked. And talked.

title: Toyota to Take 5 Percent Stake in Mazda and Build Joint U.S. Plant
description: TOKYO  Toyota said on Friday that it was taking a 5 percent stake in Mazda, another Japanese automaker, and that the companies would jointly build an assembly plant in the United States and would pool resources on new technologies.

title: Morning Agenda: Tough Times for Female C.E.O.s
description: Even when women break through the glass ceiling, it can be difficult to stay up there.

title: Affirmative Action Is an Example of How Polls Can Mislead
description: Trump administration officials are preparing to challenge admissions policies they deem to be discriminatory against white students. Unsurprisingly, analysts and commentators have dredged up old poll numbers to try to figure out how it will play politically.

title: Michel Feaster of Usermind on How to Unlock Employee Potential
description: This interview with Michel Feaster, the chief executive of Usermind, a customer-engagement software firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Asbury Park: Where Art, Grit and Local Spirits Mix
description: Asbury Park embraces the ocean, its salty scent mixed with eau de sunscreen on summer days. The citys mile-long beach is carpeted by bright towels and canopied by a pageant of umbrellas. Along the wooden boardwalk is a cavalcade of bare limbs, baby strollers, a blue booth promising fortunes told by Madam Marie and stalls hawking flip-flops, fruity drinks, cold-brew coffee, Korean-style tacos and just about everything else under the sun.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 8 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: Update: Winners for this week have been announced.

title: On a Date While Venezuela Burns
description: CIUDAD GUAYANA, Venezuela  It was 7 p.m., and the restaurant was empty. I was taking her to my favorite place in the city, informal but charming, with plastic tables and chairs outside, and sometimes live music. It has the best pizza.

title: A Bad (for the Team) Romance
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: YouTube Falls Hard for In a Heartbeat, a Boy-Meets-Boy Story
description: Its hard to forget your first childhood crush  and the anxiety that accompanied it. (Do you like me? Circle yes or no.) That heart-pounding, sweaty-palmed infatuation is nothing new in childrens animation, but two students decided to tell the tale in a different way, creating an animated short film that is drawing the interest of big production studios.

title: Pence to Speak at Conservatives Meeting Organized by Koch Brothers
description: WASHINGTON  In a sign of an expanding alliance between the Trump administration and one of the most well-financed forces in conservative politics, Vice President Mike Pence has agreed to speak to a gathering of the billionaire Koch brothers advocacy network this month.

title: Jeff Sessions, Unbound
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

title: Vietnam, Yielding to Beijing, Backs Off South China Sea Drilling
description: HONG KONG  Vietnam appears to have retreated in a high-stakes maritime gambit against China, suspending a gas-drilling project that it had approved in the South China Sea but that was said to have irritated Beijing.

title: Video of Drive-By Cat Killings Prompts Arrest in Saudi Arabia
description: It was the kind of cat video no one would want to see.

title: The Markets Are Up, Unemployment Is Down. How Much Credit Should Trump Get?
description: President Trump has taken to Twitter to celebrate his handling of the economy. But how much credit can he really claim?

title: California Today: A Seismic Change at Cal State
description: Good morning.

title: Can Gene Editing Actually Do That?
description: A new technique known as Crispr has revolutionized humans ability to edit DNA. See if you can identify whether a given development has already happened, could eventually happen or is pure fiction.

title: A Month Rent-Free: A Great Deal or a Gimmick?
description: Scroll through any New York City rental website and you will be bombarded with listings offering what landlords call concessions: months of free rent, gift cards and broker fees paid by the landlord. Some tenants have another word for such offers. They call them gimmicks.

title: How ASAP Ferg, Rapper, Spends His Sundays
description: ASAP Ferg is hardly ever home. The rapper and fashion designer, born Darold Ferguson Jr., just wrapped up a tour, visited Russia last month and will soon go to South Africa and Australia. His second mixtape, Still Striving, will be released this month, which will mean more trips. Rarely is he able to sneak a few days in Harlem, where he grew up and still lives. Even then, hell often stay busy, with studio sessions and appearances in between shows that cause the days to blur together. But Sundays are for him. He recharges and catches up with his friends and family and, among other things, sits very still on his couch. If you squint, his Sundays kind of look like ours.

title: Why Is Fashion So Obsessed With Hedi Slimane?
description: Why is fashion so obsessed with Hedi Slimane?

title: Randy Newman: And You Thought Short People Was Controversial?
description: Randy Newman is releasing Dark Matter (Aug. 4), his first album of new material in nine years. The news that one of Americas most acclaimed and ambitious songwriters has broken a nearly decade-long recording drought, though, has largely been overshadowed by coverage of a song that he started, and scrapped, for the project. It was written in the voice of President Trump, when he was still a candidate, bragging about the size of his penis.

title: ADP Says Activist Investor William Ackman Seeks a Shake-Up
description: ADP, the payroll processing giant, said on Friday that the hedge fund mogul William A. Ackman had sought five seats on its 10-member board, in the latest clash between corporate America and activist investors.

title: Taking Your AutoCorrect Entries With You
description: Q. I have years of personal AutoCorrect data entries I have made for Microsoft Word. Is it possible to transfer these settings to another computer running Word?

title: Heres the New Frozen Musical Poster (and Seven That Didnt Make the Cut)
description: Its been almost four years since the animated film Frozen made it impossible to unhear  Let It Go. Thats music to the ears of the Disney Theatrical Group as it readies to open a new high-profile musical adaptation of the movie on Broadway next spring.

title: Woody Harrelsons Real Life Is Weirder than Fiction
description: The sky was gray and drizzly outside the 54th-floor duplex in the Time Warner Center where Woody Harrelson was staying. But Mr. Harrelson was bright as a rainbow: yellow T-shirt, cobalt cap, purple cauliflower in his green salad and flecks of red rimming his baby blues, perhaps a side effect of jet lag after having just arrived from London.

title: America Is Running Out of Bomb-Sniffing Dogs
description: SAN ANTONIO  If within the past few years you received a package, roamed a shopping mall, boarded a plane, train, ferry or cruise ship, went to a major sporting event, ran a marathon, attended a concert, gambled at a casino or visited a tourist attraction, chances are a dog made sure it was safe for you to do so.

title: Paperback Row
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

title: In Singapore, Family Feud Deepens Over Facebook Posts
description: BANGKOK  Singapores government has been trying for two weeks to get the Harvard economist Li Shengwu, a grandson of Singapores founder, Lee Kuan Yew, to apologize for comments he made in a private Facebook post that were seen as critical of the countrys leadership.

title: Your Stories About Indias Partition
description: Aug. 15 marks the 70th anniversary of the end of British colonial rule in India and the creation of the two independent countries of India and Pakistan. Wed like to hear from you.

title: Cold Summer Suppers
description: Five dishes that put glorious summer ingredients to good use.

title: A Cool Solution for Hot Summer Nights
description: For some, a cold suppers main virtue is expedience  a less-than-exciting but convenient way to get food on the table with no cooking required.

title: Its a Superfund Site, but Its Also Their Livelihood
description: For two decades, Alberto Rodriguez has worked in the same cavernous garage along the border between Queens and Brooklyn, surrounded by the clang of metal and the rumbling of engines awaiting repair.

title: The Secret to Atlanta's Growth? Just Look Up
description: Atlanta is home to the worlds busiest airport. Learn how an unlikely partnership with the airline industry made the city a global hub for culture and commerce. This is where Atlanta came from, where its going and how it took to the skies.

title: Neymar Says Transfer to P.S.G. Was Not Motivated by Money
description: Neymar, the dynamic Brazilian forward, was officially unveiled as a player for Paris Saint-Germain on Friday after his $263 million transfer, which more than doubled the world record.

title: Hamilton Hip-Hop, by Students
description: An American history curriculum lets young people write the narrative. Fill in the rap.

title: Julys Most Popular Listings
description: The most-viewed listings on The New York Timess Find a Home site last month included a midcentury modern home in Princeton, N.J., that topped our list for the second month running, a country house in Steamboat Springs, Colo., and an elegant Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, home that was originally a church.

title: Mostly Mozart Remixes a Schubert Soiree
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival is presenting Schubertiade Remix, a radical re-creation of the legendary musical soirees in Vienna featuring Schubert and his fellow artists, often hosted by prosperous admirers of the struggling composer. (Monday, Aug. 7, 7:30 p.m., free, David Rubenstein Atrium, Lincoln Center; mostlymozart.org.)

title: Border-Crossing Music from Mexico, Cuba and Texas Hits Manhattan
description: Americas music has always benefited from a permeable Southern border, and free concerts in the coming week celebrate interchanges and connections across the Americas. A concert at Lincoln Center Out of Doors features Natalia LaFourcade, a Mexican songwriter with half a dozen Latin Grammys. Her latest album, Musas, is split between folky, unplugged songs from around Latin America and her own new ones that belong among them; shell be backed by the guitar duo Los Macorinos. Sharing the bill is the indie-rocker Vagabon, born in Cameroon and based in Brooklyn. (Friday, Aug. 11, at 7:30; Damrosch Park, free.)

title: A Japanese Woodblock Smackdown!
description: Ladies and gentlemen, boys and girls, lovers of Japanese woodblock art: Lets get ready to rumble! In this corner, the prince of portraits, the regent of realism, the king of Kabuki-actor pictures: Utagawa Kunisada (1786-1864). And in this corner, the wizard of warriors, the sultan of the supernatural, the ancestor of anime: Utagawa Kuniyoshi (1797-1861).

title: Rising Artists (and a Werewolf) at a New Summer Theater Festival
description: With the New York International Fringe Festival, normally the biggest fish in the pond, on hiatus for 2017, a number of opportunists have leapt forward with new summertime options for New York City theatergoers. Among these go-getters are the folks behind the inaugural Corkscrew Theater Festival, running Monday, Aug. 7, through Sunday, Sept. 3.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Good morning. Im not much for these so-called national days of food recognition, all the rah-rah boosterism that leaves my email and social media traps thick with press releases celebrating things like National Raspberry Cream Pie Day, National Ice-Cream Sandwich Day or National Grab-Some-Nuts Day (yesterday, as it happens, according to the National Day Calendar, which is someones actual job to maintain).

title: Shopping for Bathroom Vanities
description: A good bathroom vanity is a multifunctional workhorse, providing a surface for washing, shaving and applying makeup, while concealing plumbing and also storing legions of toiletries  all in a minimal amount of space.

title: Katherine Dunham, Pioneering Dancer and Activist, Inspires a Book
description: The choreographer, dancer and social activist Katherine Dunham made headlines in 1944, when, after reluctantly performing for a racially segregated audience in Louisville, Ky., she declared that if the theater wanted her to return, it would have to integrate. This scene introduces an in-depth, necessary new book on Dunham and her trailblazing career, Katherine Dunham: Dance and the African Diaspora (Oxford University Press), by the dance historian Joanna Dee Das.

title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: 38 Rapids Road, Stamford

title: August: The Film Series and the Dog Days of Summer
description: Summer is a ripe time for great repertory cinema in New York.

title: Hudson Yards Grows Slowly, Apartment by Luxury Apartment
description: The Hudson Yards mega-project, rising atop rail yards on the Far West Side, can seem a perpetual work in progress. Years after the first groundbreaking at the mixed-use minicity being developed by the Related Companies and Oxford Properties Group, few buildings have opened.

title: Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Slept Here
description: A childhood home of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis in New York City has sold for $25.25 million.

title: Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis Slept Here
description: The Park Avenue duplex where Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis lived as a child has sold for $25,250,000, one of the citys most expensive closed sales in July. But the price for the apartment was far below what it was first listed for three summers ago.

title: Look Whos Still Talking the Most in Movies: White Men
description: With Wonder Woman and Girls Trip riding a wave of critical and commercial success at the box office this summer, it can be tempting to think that diversity in Hollywood is on an upswing.

title: Star of Waitress Finds a Home of Her Own
description: After a lifetime infatuation with real estate, Betsy Wolfe bought an apartment of her own. Now all she has to do is finish decorating it.

title: The New Star of Waitress on Finally Having a Real Home
description: Growing up in central California, Betsy Wolfe was so infatuated with real estate that she routinely collected the circulars that listed homes for sale, fanning them out on the living room floor and mooning over the possibilities.

title: Leak Investigations Triple Under Trump, Sessions Says
description: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Jeff Sessions announced on Friday that the Justice Department is pursuing about three times as many leak investigations as were open at the end of the Obama era, a significant devotion of resources to hunt down disclosures that have plagued the Trump administration.

title: Volkswagen Executive Pleads Guilty in Diesel Emissions Case
description: DETROIT  A Volkswagen executive pleaded guilty on Friday to federal charges arising from a continuing investigation into the automakers diesel emissions scandal.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

title: Amy Schumer on Girl With the Lower Back Tattoo
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: Partial Lunar Eclipse Will Shadow the Moon on Monday
description: Call it a cosmic consolation prize.

title: Superfans Unite: A New Breed Reimagines Criticism for a Digital Age
description: LOS ANGELES  A few Sundays ago, as millions of people were sitting down to watch the season premiere of HBOs Game of Thrones, those gathered at a small house party in the Van Nuys neighborhood here were still figuring out dinner.

title: A Final Mystery for Amelia Peabody, Egyptologist and Sleuth
description: LAST HURRAH: When the mystery writer Barbara Mertz died, in 2013, she left behind an unfinished manuscript in her long-running series about the early-20th-century Egyptologist and amateur sleuth Amelia Peabody. Mertz (who wrote the series under the name Elizabeth Peters) was herself an accomplished Egyptologist, with a Ph.D. from the University of Chicago, and she often based her novels on actual episodes from the disciplines colorful history  as in the new book, The Painted Queen, about the discovery and theft of a priceless bust of Nefertiti. But she hadnt made much progress when she fell ill, and was still working out details of the plot with occasional help from her friend and fellow novelist Joan Hess. So her estate, naturally enough, asked Hess if she would finish the book that Mertz had started. My first response was an adamant refusal, Hess writes in a preface to The Painted Queen, new at No. 7 on the hardcover fiction list. The idea of attempting to capture her voice, her erudite style, her wit and her vast knowledge of archaeology in the early 20th century seemed ludicrous. I lost that one, obviously.

title: The Transformation of the American Dream
description: The American Dream is back. President Trump made that claim in a speech in January.

title: Missing the Eclipse? Read All About It
description: There has not been a coast-to-coast solar eclipse in the United States since 1918, so the upcoming celestial phenomenon on August 21st is exceedingly rare. It will be visible in cities across the country  Columbia, S.C., Nashville, Tenn., and Carbondale, Ill., to name a few. These books offer historical context and insight on the upcoming event. But beware: you may be tempted to impulse buy a flight to the city closest to you, if you havent already.

title: Engineering Happiness at Zappos
description: Tyler Williams, 33, is the head of experiential marketing for Zappos, an online retailer based in Las Vegas.

title: Ignorant Immigration Reform
description: This week the Republican senators Tom Cotton of Arkansas and David Perdue of Georgia introduced  a bill that they said would cut legal immigration to the United States by 50 percent. They are right about that, but nearly everything else that they have said about their bill is false or misleading.

title: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
description: The title of this retrospective comes from one of Mr. Demmes Neil Young concert films (Neil Young: Heart of Gold, showing on Aug. 20), but there are few directors who have such a generous, open view of humanity, an outlook that helped the director, who died in April, even on The Silence of the Lambs (Aug. 12). The series begins with Something Wild (Friday), in which a free spirit played by Melanie Griffith takes Jeff Danielss closet rebel banker for a whirl. The filmmaker Paul Thomas Anderson will participate in a Q. and A. after the 7 p.m. screening; on Saturday he will speak before the 4:20 p.m. showing of Melvin and Howard  Howard being Howard Hughes (Jason Robards), and Melvin being the luckless Everyman (Paul Le Mat) who befriends him. This near-comprehensive program, continuing through Aug. 24, has untold riches, but the most underrated may be The Truth About Charlie (Wednesday), a remake of Stanley Donens Charade and a loving homage to the French New Wave. BEN KENIGSBERG

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: This weeks properties include a seven-bedroom contemporary in Roslyn Heights, N.Y., and a peaceful house in the woods in Westport, Conn.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties include places in Brooklyn and Manhattan.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York and New Jersey:

title: Homes for Sale in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: 10 Sickened at Kansas City I.R.S. After Contact With a Package
description: Ten Internal Revenue Service employees became ill on Friday after coming in contact with an envelope smelling of ammonia at the agencys office in Kansas City, Mo., local and federal officials said.

title: Right and Left React to Leaks and Presidential Communications
description: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. Thats why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

title: How Sam Shepard Hit Downtown New York and Reinvented Himself
description: Sam Shepard, who died last week at 73, used to say that he was lucky to have landed in New York at just the right time. Rents were cheap, rock n roll was blooming, sex and drugs were easy, and adventurous no-budget theaters were opening in makeshift spaces downtown. For a 19-year-old arriving from California in 1963, handsome and unpolished, the city was a charmed playground.

title: Italys Lord of the Spies Takes On a Migration Crisis
description: ROME  During a visit to Moscow in 1980, Marco Minniti, a bald and bold young functionary in the Italian Communist Party, mortified his comrades by asking a Red Army general why the Soviets had occupied Afghanistan. The general pointed south on a map and explained that the faraway land mattered for his countrys national security.

title: Cleaning a Dirty Sponge Only Helps Its Worst Bacteria, Study Says
description: Stop. Drop the sponge and step away from the microwave.

title: When Bad Drinks Go Good
description: Just as the cocktail renaissance has brought renewed fame to classics like the martini, the manhattan and the Negroni, it has heaped fresh infamy on a rogues gallery of less classy concoctions, most of which emerged during the final decades of the last century.

title: Writing the Script for Your Next Act
description: In winter 2007, John V. Siebel, an oncologist with a busy office in San Mateo, Calif., was feeling restless.

title: The Accounting Tack That Makes PayPals Numbers Look So Good
description: Investors liked what they saw in PayPals second-quarter financial results, reported by the digital and mobile payments giant on July 26. Revenues grew to $3.14 billion in the quarter that ended in June, an increase of 18 percent over the same period last year. Total payment volume of $106 billion was up 23 percent, year over year.

title: What Trump Says About Immigration
description: Fixing Americas immigration policy was a major tenet of President Trumps campaign and has been at the top of his agenda since taking office. Here's what the president has said.

title: You Can Always Get a Tee Time, but Turning a Profit Can Be Tricky
description: Chip Smith didnt set out to get into the golf course business. He ran an advertising company in South Carolina in the 1990s, then got into the more lucrative business of running an institutional pharmacy in 2000, selling medications to nursing homes.

title: Stephen King Swerves Too Close to Reality for Comfort
description: Stephen Kings 2014 novel Mr. Mercedes opens with a psychopath plowing a stolen luxury car into a crowd at a job fair. Later, theres an attempted bombing at a boy band concert teeming with girls  all of which might sound too gruesomely familiar to relive as entertainment.

title: Usain Bolt, an Icon in Track and Field, Is About to Run His Final Race
description: LONDON  Track and field, once the most universal of sports in reach and resonance, is now a niche diversion, outpaced long ago by the likes of soccer, basketball and tennis. But there has been nothing niche about Usain Bolt, whose winning ways and winning manner have translated to the masses like few athletes in any sport.

title: Charges Against Charles Oakley Set to Be Dropped
description: Six months after a mind-boggling altercation at Madison Square Garden led to charges against the former Knicks star Charles Oakley, the case was essentially dismissed Friday.

title: The Robots Are Here. And Theyre Not Friendly.
description: To the Editor:

title: The Playlist: Kelela Wants Answers, and Jackie Shane Gets Another Shot
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this Playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter here.

title: 19th-Century Diary Suggests Slaves Are Buried in Brooklyn Lot
description: From 1828 to 1830, a Gowanus landowner, Adriance Van Brunt, paused several times a week to record in a diary the events of that day he deemed worthy of mention. The diary, in neatly inked handwriting stretching from edge to edge, offers a detailed portrait of farm life near what was then the Village of Brooklyn.

title: Structural Unemployment: Yes, It Was Humbug
description: It seems like ancient history now, but five years ago there was a remarkable Beltway consensus that high unemployment was structural, the result of a mismatch between the skills workers had and the skills the economy needed. What made this consensus remarkable was that all the evidence pointed the other way: none of the telltale signs of a skill mismatch, like rising wages for some groups despite high unemployment, were in sight. Meanwhile, lots of other evidence  like the fact that unemployment was falling fastest in the same places and occupations where it rose most  pointed to a cyclical story, that is, that the economy was simply suffering from inadequate demand.

title: Need Models for Your Party? Theres an App for That
description: When the vibrating yoga pants were switched on, the party perked up considerably. Oh, I like this, said Briana Siaca, facing the floor in a downward dog pose, as electronic sensors pulsed along her legs.

title: These Tacos Get Their Fire From the Grill
description: Its not the warm tortilla or the tender filling that makes a taco for me  its the condiments. The main protein almost doesnt matter, be it fish, beef tongue or crisp pork carnitas. As long as there are several kinds of salsas and hot sauces, alongside the lime wedges, sliced radishes and chopped onions available at the taco truck, youll find me happily dabbing, squeezing and layering before taking a bite.

title: In Blackwater Case, Court Rejects a Murder Conviction and Voids 3 Sentences
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court on Friday threw out lengthy prison sentences for three former Blackwater Worldwide security contractors and ordered a new trial for a fourth involved in a deadly 2007 shooting in Baghdad that became a symbol of unchecked, freewheeling American power in Iraq.

title: Turning Cotton Scraps Into Beautiful Canvas
description: Beloved by Los Angelenos with an eye for elevated folk, the four-year-old sister-run company Block Shop is known for its modern California textiles, made with traditional Indian hand block printing techniques. As someone who comes very close to stealing the Block Shop-designed napkins at Kismet (they are the happiest color of grapefruit pink, with the restaurants logo charmingly hidden in the natural-white batik pattern), imagine my excitement upon learning that the company is releasing its first collection of woodblock prints.

title: Now at Saks: Salt Rooms, a Bootcamp and a Peek at Retails Future
description: I entered a neon-lit chamber the size of a phone booth and sat on the bench as instructed. Pink Himalayan salt bricks formed the walls, and pink salt crystals crunched beneath my shoes.

title: When Pro Golfers Confront Threats Off the Fairways
description: AKRON, Ohio  His day of practice done at Firestone Country Club, Brooks Koepka headed to his courtesy car in the players parking lot, which was cut off from the public by temporary fencing covered with banners.

title: The Secret to Atlanta's Growth? Just Look Up
description: Atlanta is home to the worlds busiest airport. Learn how an unlikely partnership with the airline industry made the city a global hub for culture and commerce. This is where Atlanta came from, where its going and how it took to the skies.

title: Monicas 3 Movies to Stream or Rent This Weekend
description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

description: To the Editor:

title: Martin Shkreli Is Found Guilty of Fraud
description: Martin Shkreli, 34, has confidently courted controversy in recent years, bulldozing his way into Wall Street and the drug industry, raising the price of a lifesaving drug by 5,000 percent overnight, boasting that he would outwit prosecutors in his federal fraud case, and live-streaming and tweeting throughout his five-week trial.

title: At Statue of Liberty, Words That Resonate Even if Theyre Unfamiliar
description: The words did not ring a bell among many visitors to the Statue of Liberty on Thursday.

title: U.S. to Join Climate Talks Despite Planned Withdrawal From Paris Accord
description: WASHINGTON  The White House formally notified the United Nations on Friday that it intends to abandon the Paris agreement on climate change but remains open to re-engaging on the accord.

title: Will Cosby Lawyers Departure Lead to Delay in Retrial?
description: PHILADELPHIA  With the withdrawal of his lead counsel, Bill Cosby may want to seek a delay in his retrial, now scheduled to start on Nov. 6, according to legal experts who have been tracking the case.

title: What Were Reading
description: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What Were reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

title: African Womens Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: The Value of Economic Sanctions
description: To the Editor:
