description: Exit greed, enter fear.

title: Corrections: August 11, 2017
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Trumps Twitter Fury at McConnell Risks Alienating a Key Ally
description: WASHINGTON  By preventing President Barack Obama from filling a Supreme Court vacancy, Senator Mitch McConnell secured Donald J. Trump the signature accomplishment of his young presidency: the confirmation of Justice Neil M. Gorsuch.

title: New York Times Editorial Writer Must Testify in Sarah Palin Lawsuit
description: The author of a New York Times editorial will have to testify under oath in a defamation lawsuit filed by the former vice-presidential candidate Sarah Palin, a federal judge ruled on Thursday.

title: For Mexicos Mrquez, Treasury Sanctions Carry Broad Consequences
description: Rafael Mrquezs life just became a lot more difficult.

title: Thought Bullies or Right Move: A Divide Over James Damore Firing
description: Google on Monday fired an employee, James Damore, over an internal memo he wrote that questioned the companys diversity efforts and claimed that women were less likely to succeed in technical positions because of biological differences rather than gender discrimination.

title: Walmart Apologizes for Sign Advertising Guns as Back-to-School Item
description: Walmart officials are apologizing after a photograph surfaced online of a company sign that appeared to promote guns as essential back-to-school purchases.

title: Another Course Correction for City Policing
description: In recent years, pressured by the courts, the federal government and the public, New York City has taken several important steps to make its policing policies fairer, more rational and, ultimately, more effective. It has greatly scaled back its practice of stopping and frisking people in high-crime neighborhoods. It has reduced the number of people prosecuted on minor marijuana charges. The Manhattan and Brooklyn district attorneys offices announced they would no longer prosecute most people arrested on fare-beating charges.

title: Soccer Capital: Lure of London, and Its Money, Reshape Premier League
description: LONDON  At the tail end of last year, two Wall Street investors were searching for a soccer club to buy. Not one at the top end of the market, where blue-chip Premier League teams are valued at more than $1 billion, but something a little smaller, a little less flashy, in one of English soccers lower tiers.

title: Even the Most Precise Strike on North Korea Could Prompt Retaliation
description: WASHINGTON  North Koreas threat on Thursday to test-fire ballistic missiles soon near the American territory of Guam deepened the challenge confronting the Trump administration: how to defang Pyongyangs missile programs without risking all-out war.

title: Mets Announce Dominic Smith Will Make His Debut on Friday
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Mets efforts to move past a discouraging 2017 season and determine the shape of next years team continued Thursday.

title: Two Track Luminaries Watch as Their Records Remain Untouched
description: LONDON  The rain was gone at the world track and field championships. The stands at London Stadium were full again, and the victories and the surprises kept piling up.

title: Jeffrey Lord, Trump Defender on CNN, Is Fired for Using Nazi Slogan
description: Jeffrey Lord, the indefatigable defender of President Trump whose advocacy turned him into an unlikely political celebrity, was fired by CNN on Thursday after a convoluted Twitter exchange in which he evoked  mockingly, he said  a Nazi salute.

title: Daniel Loeb, a Cuomo Donor, Makes Racial Remark About Black Leader
description: The hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb, a prominent supporter of charter schools and a major financial backer of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and congressional Republicans, accused the African-American woman who leads the Democrats in the New York State Senate of having done more damage to people of color than anyone who has ever donned a hood.

title: What Can North Korea Reach With Its Missiles?
description: North Koreas ballistic missile program has recently accelerated faster than expected.

title: What Many Stargazers Wonder
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  When we last saw Hal Moore, he was making his debut by putting birds into very small boxes, but today he is branching out into the realm of themeless puzzles. And hes doing very well, in my opinion.

title: Review: Michael Moore, Bragging on Broadway, in The Terms of My Surrender
description: In 1972, having campaigned on a platform of firing his high schools top administrators, Michael Moore won a seat on the Davison, Mich., school board. (The assistant principal, he says, whacked his bottom with a two-by-four as punishment for not tucking in his shirt.) At 18, Mr. Moore became the youngest elected official in the country.

title: Trump Had a Lot to Say on Thursday. Here Are the Highlights.
description: WASHINGTON  Sometimes, 140 characters just arent enough.

title: Saudis Propose That U.N. Run Airport in Yemens Capital
description: Saudi Arabia proposed on Thursday that the United Nations reopen and run the international airport in Yemens capital, which has been closed for a year because of a Saudi blockade to pressure the Houthi rebel movement.

title: 12-Year-Old Bronx Girl Arrested in Scalding of Friend at Sleepover
description: A 12-year-old girl was arrested and charged with assault on Thursday after a bizarre attack at a sleepover party in the Bronx that left an 11-year-old girl with second-degree burns to her face and upper body.

title: Google Cancels Employee Meeting Because of Harassment Fears
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google on Thursday canceled a scheduled companywide meeting at which executives had planned to discuss a memo that questioned the Silicon Valley giants diversity efforts after employees expressed concern that they would be exposed to harassment online.

title: Yankees Beefed Up Their Pitching. Now They Need Hitting.
description: TORONTO  When Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman was burning up his cellphone leading up to the nonwaiver trade deadline, it appeared he was after three things: pitching, pitching and pitching.

title: Four Castaways Make a Family
description: I think youre just right for her, my adoption caseworker said, showing me her picture in the foster-child bulletin.

title: Bed-Stuy Is Burning Takes On Gentrification in Brooklyn
description: BED-STUY IS BURNING By Brian Platzer 326 pp. Atria Books. $26.

title: England Bans Betting in Soccer, but Not for The Lizard
description: LONDON  They call Tony Bloom The Lizard in poker circles. But the Lizard is more than just a gambler.

title: Donald Trump, Fipronil, Premier League: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Whats on TV Friday: Son of Sam: The Killer Speaks and Atypical
description: David Berkowitz, a.k.a. the Son of Sam, speaks out on the 40th anniversary of his arrest. And on Netflix, a teenager with autism goes in search of a girlfriend.

title: Who Owns Anbang of China? A U.S. Labor Union Wants to Know.
description: BEIJING  To the growing list of entities questioning the ownership of Anbang Insurance Group, the Chinese financial conglomerate, add one more: an American hotel union.

title: The Mailman of Kabul
description: He was a master detective in a city with few addresses. But he couldnt find the intended recipient, Atta Mohammed, next to Sajadee Mosque.

title: Right and Left on the North Korean Nuclear Threat
description: Days after President Trump threatened North Korea with fire and fury, tensions have remained high. On Thursday, the president doubled down on his warning, suggesting that perhaps his first comment wasnt tough enough.

title: Australians Turn In 12,500 Guns in National Amnestys First Weeks
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The first numbers for the National Gun Amnesty are in, and more than 12,500 unregistered firearms have been surrendered since it started last month, Michael Keenan, the minister for justice, announced on Thursday.

title: Why Are Police Officers More Dangerous Than Airplanes?
description: Its 2:30 in the morning and my phone rings. My daughter says, Daddy, you need to come to the hospital,  Michael Bell told me, of the moment in 2004 when he learned that his son had been shot by a police officer in their hometown, Kenosha, Wis.

title: Sundar Pichai Should Resign as Googles C.E.O.
description: There are many actors in the whole Google/diversity drama, but Id say the one whos behaved the worst is the C.E.O., Sundar Pichai.

title: Partners in Voter Suppression
description: The Trump administration moved deeper into the politics of voter suppression this week by reversing the federal governments opposition to Ohios effort to purge tens of thousands of voters from the rolls simply because they vote infrequently.

title: On Health Care, Who Needs Congress?
description: Regardless of whether Congress enacts health care reform, the private sector isnt waiting. Health care for our employees is too expensive, and the employer-based system must be reformed.

title: Wheels of Misfortune
description: New York City is in the midst of a cycling boom. New Yorkers are riding bikes more than ever, both as a commuting option and a recreational activity. But with that growth has come a steady increase in the number of riders who flout traffic laws, ignoring the fact that their actions can have tragic consequences.

title: The Axis of Climate Evil
description: Its Not Your Imagination: Summers Are Getting Hotter. So read a recent headline in The Times, highlighting a decade-by-decade statistical analysis by climate expert James Hansen. Most summers, the analysis concluded, are now either hot or extremely hot compared with the mid-20th century.

title: Skinny Women Who Eat Cheeseburgers in Magazines
description: If you are a woman in America who spends any amount of time thinking about her body  which is to say, if you are a woman in America  then you know that its August, not April, thats the cruelest month. In April, you can wear a cardigan. In August, youve got to either bare your flesh to sun and scrutiny, feigning body confidence in your swimsuit, or cower in your cover-up and risk being shamed for your shame.

title: If Missiles Are Headed to Guam, Here Is What Could Stop Them
description: HONG KONG  North Koreas threat to launch four intermediate-range ballistic missiles into the ocean near Guam could mark the first combat test of the sophisticated missile defense systems of the United States and its Asian allies.

title: Beijing Warns U.S. Over Navy Patrol in South China Sea
description: BEIJING  As the Trump administration pressed China to curb North Korea, Beijing issued its own warning over another festering dispute on Friday, saying that American naval operations in the South China Sea would only force it to deepen its military buildup there.

title: Hong Kong Activist Says Chinese Agents Stapled His Legs Over Messi Photo
description: HONG KONG  A pro-democracy activist in Hong Kong said on Friday that Chinese agents drove staples into his legs after he asked the soccer star Lionel Messi to send a message of support for a jailed Chinese dissident.

title: How to Handle a Sleepwalker
description: Dont startle the person, says Charlene Gamaldo, the medical director at the Johns Hopkins Center for Sleep. Sleepwalkers exist in a semiwakeful state and can become testy and disoriented when forced to come to full consciousness. Instead, speak to them in a quiet voice and lead them gently back to their bed. In most cases, theyll settle easily and in the morning remember nothing of their nighttime ambulations.

title: Swimming While Black: Then and Now
description: From 2017: Black children drown five times as often as white children, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The Harlem Honeys and Bears, a senior synchronized swim team, is trying to help by offering free lessons for young people.

title: The Way It Is
description: Selected by Terrance Hayes.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Animal-Costume Cruelty
description: Martin writes: My wife and kids dressed Scooby, our Chi-wiener dog (half dachshund, half Chihuahua), in a poncho and a sombrero as part of a Mexican-themed dinner party. I contend that this is both cruel to the animal and possibly racist. She contends that it is all in good fun.

title: New Sentences: From Elin Hilderbrands The Identicals
description: Every summer, on vacation in Cape Cod, my friend Rachelle sits on the beach reading novels set on nearby Nantucket. They have sky-blue covers featuring women in bathing suits and blurbs about what perfect beach reads they are. (People magazine: Just the thing for a day by the sea.) Every summer there is a new one, or even two, by the same author. This year I snatched one for myself and hunkered down in the sand. I was captivated. I finished it in a day, as waves slipped over the shore and crabs scuttled across the seafloor and the white edge of my thigh burned.

title: The 7.30.17 Issue
description: RE: CHINESE LAWYERS

title: A New Kind of Classroom: No Grades, No Failing, No Hurry
description: Few middle schoolers are as clued in to their mathematical strengths and weakness as Moheeb Kaied. Now a seventh grader at Brooklyns Middle School 442, he can easily rattle off his computational profile.

title: How to Ignore Your Kids Bad Behavior and Yet Be Fully Present for Them
description: The biggest holiday of the year for parents is not Thanksgiving or Christmas or Mothers Day or Fathers Day. Its the day in September your kid goes back to school  or, as I call it, Tag, Youre It! day. Very soon, for six sweet hours, five delicious days a week, we hand our children over to the loving ministrations of someone who isnt us. As that glorious day nears, this might be a good opportunity to look at a recent crop of books about parenting. How did you do this summer? Yeah, I know. Me too.

title: Behind the Cover: 8.13.17
description: Gail Bichler, design director: Roberto and Renato Miazs gauzy image of Michael Deng, made with aerosol paint, invites the viewer to fill in the details of his face. We liked the subtle emotional overtones to the image and thought it spoke to the loneliness and search for identity that many college-age Asian-Americans like Deng experience.

title: A Classic London Restaurant Gets a Makeover and a New Mission
description: The rubbery corporate mascot we know as the Michelin Man actually has a name: Bibendum, drawn from a Latin phrase once used in the tire companys advertising: nunc est bibendum, best translated as time for a drink  odd advice, perhaps, for drivers, but good news for diners.

title: If You Want to Know What Its Like to Die, Ask Writers
description: THE ART OF DEATH Writing the Final Story By Edwidge Danticat 181 pp. Graywolf Press. Paper, $14.

title: A Mystery Wrapped in Race, Class and Silence
description: TORNADO WEATHER By Deborah E. Kennedy 308 pp. Flatiron Books. $24.99.

title: A Novel of Desperate New Yorkers and Those Who Evict Them
description: MOVING KINGS By Joshua Cohen 240 pp. Random House. $26.

title: Marianne Moores Poetry, the Way She Intended It
description: NEW COLLECTED POEMS By Marianne Moore Edited by Heather Cass White 480 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $35.

title: Fiction From Japan, for the Old World and the New
description: THE GREAT PASSAGE By Shion Miura Translated by Juliet Winters Carpenter 212 pp. Amazon Crossing, paper, $10.99.

title: 27 National Monuments Are Under Review. Here Are Five to Watch.
description: No president has ever abolished a national monument designated by a predecessor. President Trump may try to change that.

title: Hamilton Is Known for Its Music, but What Did Alexander Hamilton Listen To?
description: Toward the end of the first act of the Broadway smash hit Hamilton, opening the Los Angeles leg of its national tour on Friday, Aug. 11, the British Army surrenders at Yorktown. Narrating this transformative moment in the American Revolution, the musicals title character observes that as our fallen foes retreat, I hear the drinking song theyre singing.

title: Investing Short-Term When Stocks Are High? Imagine a Painful Drop
description: Every week brings a new worry, something or another that could finally, truly, end our eight-year-plus bull market in American stocks.

title: Neighborhoods That Play Hard to Get
description: Richmond Hill, in southwestern Queens, can be an eye-opener for the uninitiated home buyer. Neck rolls may even be in order. Theyll help with the double take: Victorian houses with verandas and grassy lawns a few blocks from the subway; locals gallivanting on horseback in Forest Park; street parking on a Saturday.

title: Elevating the Humble Cookie
description: Twenty-five years ago, I met Pierre Herm for the first time. We were in a labyrinthine basement kitchen that thrummed with the low rumble of mixers and oven fans, and he mentioned the architecture of taste. I wrote the words in my notebook, sensing they were important even if I didnt understand them  all I could imagine was blueprints of intricate confections in infinite flavors. At that time, Pierre was the head pastry chef at the Parisian food hall Fauchon. He was a pastry chefs pastry chef, admired by professionals in France, somewhat known among pros in America and on the cusp of fame worldwide. I didnt have a clue who he was. I had secured a 15-minute interview for an article I was writing, and I turned up on time and left two hours later, my head spinning with ideas he planted there and my pockets bulging with small cakes, chocolate bonbons and cookies. I didnt know that I had also taken away the seeds of a lasting friendship.

title: Donald Trumps First Nine Holes
description: Golf is a big deal to President Trump. Over the years he has defended his stubborn character by saying a change of swing is a mistake, and dismissed Mitt Romney as a guy who cant sink a three-foot putt. His main concern about possible Scottish independence, as expressed to the Wall Street Journal, was whether the British Open could still be held. As of Aug. 10 he had spent 50 out of 202 days in office at golf courses, according to NBC News.

title: Seth Meyers Thinks Fire and Fury Has Something to Do With the Opioid Crisis
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

description: TOKYO  Few foreign leaders have courted President Trump as assiduously as the prime minister of Japan, Shinzo Abe.

description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: Morning Agenda: Uber Investor Sues Ex-C.E.O. Travis Kalanick
description: Travis Kalanick may no longer be Ubers chief executive, but hes still a major figure at the ride-hailing company.

title: Does Colon Cleansing Wipe Out Our Gut Microbiome?
description: Q. Wouldnt having an enema prior to a colonoscopy virtually wipe out ones internal microbiome?

title: Protecting My Son Meant Wishing for His Death
description: Im standing in the acute neurosurgery ward of Innsbruck University Hospital. The senior consultant has asked me to tell him about my son Miles, who is lying motionless on the bed beside us.

title: Trump Wants to Get Tough on Crime. Victims Dont Agree.
description: Sending more people to prison, deporting illegal immigrants, cracking down on marijuana use  those are some of the things the Trump administration has said will make America safer.

title: New York Today: Polluting the Perseids
description: Good morning on this so-so Friday.

title: Shes 98. Hes 94. They Met at the Gym.
description: Gertrude Mokotoff and Alvin Mann were introduced eight years ago at a gym in Middletown, N.Y., where they still work out twice a week.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Appetite, Shampoo and Serial Killers
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Tensions Between U.S. and North Korea Spur Global Stock Sell-Off
description: LONDON  A sell-off in global markets accelerated on Friday as tensions between the United States and North Korea escalated, driving investors toward havens.

title: How Helen Uffner, Vintage Clothing Expert, Spends Her Sundays
description: Helen Uffner has been a go-to period clothing source for television, movies and the stage since she began her career 39 years ago. From her 5,000-square-foot warehouse and showroom in Long Island City, Queens, she rents out vintage clothing, with her oldest pieces dating back to 1860. Her first film job was outfitting Meryl Streep for Out of Africa, and more recently, she supplied Amy Schumers dress for a Mary Todd Lincoln skit on Saturday Night Live (a regular client) and Kate Winslets shoes  1930s wedges, new in the box  for Ms. Winslets portrayal of Mildred Pierce in the recent HBO remake. Sundays find Ms. Uffner, 68, who lives on East 70th Street, visiting flea markets and tag or estate sales with friends. Shes always on the lookout for new inventory and for additions to her personal collection of toys from the 50s and 60s.

title: Matthew Prince of Cloudflare on the Dangers of Fast Growth
description: This interview with Matthew Prince, chief executive of Cloudflare, a cybersecurity firm, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: North Korea Aside, Guam Faces Another Threat: Climate Change
description: HONG KONG  The island of Guam made rare headlines this week when North Korea, responding to blustery language from President Trump, threatened to fire four ballistic missiles into waters near the American territorys shores. Some Guam residents told reporters that they worried what might happen if North Koreas leader, Kim Jong-un, were actually to follow through.

title: South Korea Says U.S. Promises Coordination in Standoff With North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  With the United States and North Korea locked in an escalating exchange of threats, South Korea told its people on Friday that the White House had agreed not to do anything on the Korean Peninsula that would catch the South off guard.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 9 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: Update: Winners for this week have been announced.

title: Trump Says Military Is Locked and Loaded and North Korea Will Regret Threats
description: BRIDGEWATER, N.J.  President Trump continued to beat war drums on Friday against North Korea and, unexpectedly, said he would consider a military option to deal with an unrelated crisis in Venezuela. But though he declared that the armed forces were locked and loaded, there were no indications of imminent action in either part of the world.

title: U.S. Airstrikes in Afghanistan Are Said to Kill 16 Civilians
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan  Afghan officials said on Friday that American warplanes killed 16 civilians as they tried to flee an area in eastern Afghanistan controlled by Islamic State militants, but the United States military insisted the dead had been extremist fighters.

title: The Great British Bake Off as We Know It Is Over. What Comes Next?
description: Americans, The Great British Baking Show as you have known it is coming to an end.

title: California Today: Renewed Scrutiny of Sanctuary Bill
description: Good morning.

title: The Art of the Temporary Obstacle Course
description: On a cool Thursday in July, nine teenagers and young adults from Concrete Safaris arrived in their signature lime green T-shirts, lugging the colorful tools of their trade: red metal hurdles, bright hula hoops, multicolored cones, small green balance beams and a rainbow of plastic circles. They tossed them all onto the black asphalt on East 104th Street and then started building.

title: Cronenbergs Videodrome, at MoMA, More Prescient Than Ever
description: David Cronenbergs 1983 horror hallucination Videodrome  screening Tuesday, Aug. 15, as part of the Museum of Modern Arts Future Imperfect: The Uncanny in Science Fiction series  bears the directors leading preoccupations: flesh-and-technology hybrids (as in Existenz); cult psychology ( la Crash); and splashes of splatter (thanks to Rick Bakers effects wizardry). But most startling is its prescience.

title: Editta Sherman Gets Her Due at the New-York Historical Society
description: The name Editta Sherman may not ring a bell, but she was the blithe spirit who flitted through Bill Cunningham New York, about the New York Timess street-fashion photographer, who died in 2016. Sherman (1913-2013) was Cunninghams muse, erstwhile collaborator and longtime neighbor in the fabled studios above Carnegie Hall.

title: Two Different Flavors of Soul: Lionel Richie and Mariah Carey
description: Consider it a stroke of brilliance to put Lionel Richie and Mariah Carey on tour together. Mr. Richie is a cool sensualist who never pushes too hard, and Ms. Carey is an ostentatious emoter who never stops short of glitz. Mr. Richie is a gorgeous ocean at low tide; Ms. Carey is a set of waves that unnerve even the most game surfers. Its illogical, and yet not  an alliance of soul- music opposites who are both committed to tradition, in different ways.

title: Forget Washington. Help This Mayor Find His Goats.
description: Roughly 1,000 miles separate Washington from DLo, Miss., unless youre talking about the political climate. Then youd need to be measuring the difference in light-years. Small Town, Big Mayor, an impossibly cheery and lighthearted reality series that began this month on UP TV, follows John Henry Berry, the mayor of DLo, which has a few hundred residents, as he tackles his 95-point plan to improve the community. In the latest episode, he was promoting environmentally friendly practices, including using goats to keep the ball field grass clipped, but there was a problem. Apparently I didnt fence them in as well as I thought I had, he said. An episode-long hunt for the missing goats followed.

title: For Peter Pan on her 70th birthday Takes One Last Trip to Neverland

The young woman is Ms. Ruhls mother, Kathleen Kehoe Ruhl, for whom she wrote For Peter Pan.

title: Erasing Borders Through Indian Dance
description: Each August, the Indo-American Arts Councils Erasing Borders Festival of Indian Dance makes Lower Manhattan a brighter place. Presented in part with the Battery Dance Festival  theres an indoor program at Schimmel Center on Monday, Aug. 14, and an outdoor presentation at Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park on Tuesday in conjunction with Battery Dance  this spotlight on classical Indian music and dance offers an eclectic mix.

title: DellArte Opera Offers a Cavalli to Fill a Summer Lull
description: For over a decade now, the DellArte Opera company has filled the summer lull with fresh productions of well-known classics and rarities, performed by emerging talents. Few works fit the companys mission better than Francesco Cavallis 1651 La Calisto, a tender and alluring opera based on a tale from Ovids Metamorphoses in which a nymph allied with Diana is abducted by Jupiter, cursed by Juno and transformed into a constellation of stars  a metamorphosis the organization probably hopes to effect on its young singers, too.

title: Seven Ways to Save on Your Kitchen Renovation

title: Even for Philanthropists, Museums Can Make Art a Tough Give

But as an art historian, Mr. Jordan was sure it was actually a work by the 17th-century master Diego Velzquez.

title: Marlon Wayans Takes on a Different Kind of TV Dad

title: Under the Stars and Quilts, With Randalls Island as Her Stage
description: Its a sleepover to beat all sleepovers. Food, stories, discussions, dances and, after an opening ceremony and a two-mile walk, settling down for the night on a 4,000-square-foot bed of quilts.

title: Attacked on All Sides, an Anti-Trump Manifesto Prevails on the Best-Seller List
description: FLAKE NEWS: Quick, who wrote Inferno? (A) Dante. (B) Dan Brown. (C) All of the above. The right answer is of course (C), and thanks to Brown  I like to picture him introducing himself at cocktail parties as Dante Brown  there is recent precedent for borrowing a classics title in hopes that its posterity might rub off. (It worked for Brown. His Dante-influenced thriller spent more than a year on the hardcover and paperback fiction lists.) Even so, the Republican senator Jeff Flake of Arizona has raised eyebrows by calling his new anti-Trump manifesto Conscience of a Conservative. Thats because Barry Goldwaters 1960 book of that title, which stayed on the Times nonfiction list for 31 weeks, is still revered as a founding document of the modern conservative movement. Right-wing commentators who arent as ready to abandon the president see Flakes appropriation of the name more as apostasy than as the homage Flake intended, and object to the books attacks on the Republican establishment. (We pretended that the emperor wasnt naked, Flake writes. Even worse: We checked our critical faculties at the door and pretended that the emperor was making sense.) Brent Bozell III, president of the conservative Media Research Center and son of Goldwaters collaborator (some say ghostwriter), recently insisted that Jeff Flake is not a conservative, nor does he have a conscience, and he called on his conservative brethren to denounce this impostor. You know youre in trouble when your critics are using the word brethren. Not that liberals are much happier. In The New Republic this month, Alex Shephard applauded the books message but said that Flake  who has voted with Donald Trump 95 percent of the time  was the wrong person to deliver it.

title: American Says Hes Not London Jogger Who Shoved Woman in Front of Bus
description: LONDON  What appeared to be an open-and-shut case involving a jogger in London who pushed a woman in front of a bus is suddenly  and surprisingly  open again.

title: Morocco Will Challenge U.S.-Led Bid for 2026 World Cup
description: Morocco will bid to host the 2026 World Cup, emerging as a last-minute challenger  and a potential complication  to a United States-led campaign that appeared to be coasting to victory unopposed.

title: How to Prevent a Cyberwar
description: While the specifics of Russias interference in the 2016 American election remain unclear, no one doubts that Moscow has built a robust technological arsenal for waging cyberattacks. And as tensions between the two countries rise, theres a good chance President Vladimir Putin will consider using them against American interests  if he hasnt already.

title: Canada Letter: Ice Cream Revival and Cross-Border Trade Anxiety
description: Canada may be a country with a lot of open space, but it has become a country of urban dwellers, with most Canadians living in cities and suburbs. And as more people have left rural areas, schools in small towns and villages have closed, creating a vicious circle. Attracting young families to a town without an elementary school can be a very tall order.

title: Imam in Switzerland Urged Burning of Muslims Who Dont Pray, Prosecutors Say
description: BERLIN  The Swiss authorities have charged an imam from Ethiopia with inciting violence by calling in a sermon for local Muslims who refused to pray to be burned alive, prosecutors said on Friday.

title: Trump Isnt a Threat to Our Democracy. Hysteria Is.

title: In Montana, Days of Smoke and Ash
description: BIGFORK, Mont.  I guess we should consider ourselves lucky. Folks down on Rock Creek have been praying for rain (sans lightning, of course) and hoping that the fire lines hold. Missoula is surrounded by wildfires, to the point that it really doesnt matter which way the wind blows. North, east, south or west, the citys population is still sucking smoke.

title: In Barbara Cooks Final Days, Her Friends Came to Sing at Her Bedside
description: On a flight home to New York last week, the jazz musician John Pizzarelli received a text message saying that Barbara Cook, the 89-year-old star of Broadway and cabaret, was in failing health. He and his wife, the singer Jessica Molaskey, had met Ms. Cook a decade earlier at Caf Carlyle, one of her musical haunts, and they had become close. Would the couple like to come to her bedside and say their goodbyes?

title: Vietnamese Art Has Never Been More Popular. But the Market Is Full of Fakes.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Good morning. Theres a cool dish out of France called eclade de moules, in which you take a few pounds of mussels, put them on a board or rock, cover them with dried pine needles and then set the whole thing on fire. The intense heat of the burning pine opens the mussels and adds to their brininess the fragrance of the forest floor, and that would be a cool thing to do and eat this weekend if you have access to the pine, and a space in which to burn it. (Heres a video of the process.)

title: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
description: A fervid vocalist and full-bore entertainer, Mr. Mwenso has assembled a special three-part program for this concert. Taking place at 7 p.m. on Tuesday, its devoted to music of uplift and self-determination from across the African diaspora. The pianist Sullivan Fortner, a member of Roy Hargroves quintet, will play a sampling of African-American spirituals; the South African vocalist Vuyo Sotashe will introduce audiences to songs he learned in the townships of his homeland; and Mr. Mwenso, who hails from Sierra Leone, will debut a selection of newly composed anthems aimed at inspiration. GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO

title: Some Things T Editors Like Right Now

And yet each season, it seems that a good bathing suit is almost impossible to find. Solid and striped suits are attractive and yet ill-fitting on my body; one-piece Speedos are ideal in terms of comfort and yet out of place on a beach. Two brands  Marieyat and the wonderfully titled Babes in Bathers  offer new solutions.

title: Desperate Times Call for Old Measures

Flakes Conscience of a Conservative pays tribute to Barry Goldwaters 1960 treatise  one of the most influential political books of all time, in Flakes estimation (even if the premise of Flakes jeremiad on the current crisis for conservatives suggests it wasnt nearly influential enough)  and includes a lengthy list of plaintive questions about President Trumps deeds under the heading What Would Goldwater Do?

Inside, it was standing room only as Jeremiah Moss, bearded and in a black T-shirt, read from his book, Vanishing New York: How a Great City Lost Its Soul (Dey Street, 2017). The book chronicles how (and why) a city of diners and delis morphed into a string of interchangeable blocks filled with forgettable stores of the sort that could be found in a Long Island strip mall.

title: How U.S. Military Actions Could Play Out in North Korea
description: WASHINGTON  The intelligence could come to President Trump secretly and urgently: The North Koreans have placed another intercontinental missile on its launching pad. In less than two hours, it could be fueled and ready for launch on a test flight into the Pacific Ocean or perhaps on a mission to strike American territory.

title: To Stay Sane, Read More Celebrity Gossip
description: The world feels very fragile right now. Every morning I wake up to see if our president is threatening any more dangerous despots with nuclear war. I dont like this new abnormal. It scares me and depresses me. So I check Twitter and hooray, I see Aaron Carter is trending because he has announced hes bisexual. This is so great, because I dont care! Im only vaguely aware of who Aaron Carter is, and his sexuality couldnt matter less to me, so I read more.

title: Quotation of the Day: As a Cabaret Star Lay Dying, Friends Came to Serenade Her
description: We started singing and she lifted her finger up to her mouth. She tapped her lips twice and I thought she was singing with us.

title: Police and Protesters Mobilize for Trumps Return to His Own Home
description: President Trump is set to return to his own home Sunday for the first time since taking office, to sleep in his own bed at his triplex apartment atop Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue.

title: A Small Towns Sacrifice to Vietnam
description: In March 1966, a Marine sergeant named Earl Peterson arrived in Morenci, a town in southeastern Arizona. Home to the largest copper mine in the United States, Morenci is a company town, at the time owned almost completely by the Phelps Dodge Corporation. Practically every man in Morenci worked for the mine, and every boy knew that his future lay in its depths.

title: New Orleans Scrambles to Repair Drainage System After Severe Flooding
description: NEW ORLEANS  With rain threatening, work crews scrambled on Friday to repair New Orleanss pumping and drainage network in the hopes of preventing a repeat of last weekend, when flooding inundated many neighborhoods and forced city officials to admit that vital pieces of the system were inoperable.

title: Make Commuters Pay Their Share Again
description: Even as New Yorks political leaders talk about a new, higher tax rate for the rich to fix mass transit, they might consider reviving an old revenue source that state lawmakers eliminated 18 years ago, to New York Citys enduring harm. This is the commuter tax, a modest imposition on the paychecks of 811,000 suburbanites who make their living in the city and may reasonably be expected to contribute a little to help keep it running.

title: For Doomsday Preppers, the End of the World Is Good for Business
description: Shoppers are buying six-month food supplies wrapped in military-grade Mylar pouches, and kits filled with duct tape, food bars and an air-filtration mask.

title: Health Attacks on U.S. Diplomats in Cuba Baffle Both Countries
description: The University of Miami received a nervous call from the Trump administration: American diplomats in Havana were getting sick with headaches, dizziness and hearing loss. Washington needed answers.

title: Judge Drops Complaint Aimed at Taylor Swift in Groping Case Brought by D.J.
description: DENVER  After four days of testimony, a federal judge on Friday dropped Taylor Swift from a suit filed by a radio host who took the star to court claiming she had falsely accused him of groping her.

title: Trump Tweets Tough
description: Look, I have  nobody has better respect for intelligence than Donald Trump, said the president of the United States this week.

title: Teenagers Arrests Are Unconstitutional, A.C.L.U. Lawsuit Says
description: With law enforcement officials aggressively pursuing gang members on Long Island after a recent spate of homicides by the transnational gang MS-13, the American Civil Liberties Union said in a class-action lawsuit on Friday that federal authorities had gone too far.

title: Jon Rahm, a Rising Star, Stalls at Golfs Majors
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  People craned their necks as if they were watching a racecar carve a fast curve in traffic. Here in Nascar country, it probably shouldnt be surprising that several fans followed Jon Rahm during the second round of the P.G.A. Championship in anticipation of seeing him fishtail around the difficult finishing holes or smash a club.

title: A Crisis Forces Google to Uphold Its Values While Fostering Debate
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As a crisis unfurled at Google over an employee memo that argued biological factors helped explain the shortage of female engineers and leaders in Silicon Valley, some of the most pointed critiques of the companys handing of the issue were posted to its own message boards.

title: Weve Had Enough: Conservatives Relish the Fury in Trumps Talk
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Fire and fury? Eugene Yu could not have said it better himself.

title: Dominic Smith Realizes a Dream During a Mets Victory
description: PHILADELPHIA  Early Thursday afternoon, Dominic Smith received a call from Pedro Lopez, the manager of the Mets Class AAA affiliate in Las Vegas. Lopez told Smith, a first-base prospect, to come to the field because he had an idea on how to fix Smiths malfunctioning sleep apnea breathing machine.

title: Eduardo Nunez, Groomed as a Yankee, Blossoms With the Red Sox
description: Eduardo Nunez could not confirm a report on Friday that a group including Derek Jeter had reached a $1.2 billion agreement to buy the Miami Marlins. But Nunez, the former Yankee infielder turned Boston Red Sox dynamo, did reveal another recent purchase by Jeter.

title: Comment on Race Reopens New York Democrats Split Over Schools
description: The 55-word Facebook post had a remarkably short life span, especially for one from Daniel S. Loeb, a charter school proponent and activist investor known for his acid-penned missives.

title: An Assault on Efforts to Prevent Teenage Pregnancy
description: With flimsy justification, and in small type buried in routine documents, the Trump administration has informed 81 local governments and health groups that it will end grants they have received to run teen pregnancy prevention programs, two years before the grants are scheduled to end. The decision is unsettling even by the disquieting standards of this anti-science administration.

title: The Foolish Transgender Debate in Texas
description: While much of the nation appears to be adjusting to the transgender rights movement, social conservatives in the Texas Legislature  prodded by Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick, a Republican  continue their obsessive campaign to restrict the bathroom rights of transgender citizens.

title: Fund-Raising Push by Challenger Forces de Blasio Into Primary Debates
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio will have to appear in two debates before the September primary now that his chief Democratic rival, Sal F. Albanese, has crossed the threshold of fund-raising and campaign spending needed to qualify.

title: Donald Trump Is Giving North Korea Exactly What It Wants
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A few years ago, when I was a reporter working in Pyongyang, North Koreas capital, I went to visit a kindergarten. While I was there, I picked up a childrens book called A Hedgehog Defeats the Tiger. It was a tale, a North Korean told me, about a feisty little hedgehog that bests a much larger and fiendishly ravenous tiger using the only weapons at its disposal: the small but sharp quills on its back. The tiny but clever hedgehog pounces on the big nose of the blundering tiger, blinding him into submission.

title: Ability to Learn and Adapt
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  This might or might not be a popular opinion but its mine, so Ill just say it: I love pop culture. I revel in it. But that is not all there is to me as a person or as a solver, so Im always baffled by those who look down on pop culture in crosswords.

title: Another Silicon Valley Start-Up Faces Sexual Harassment Claims
description: Social Finance, a hot financial start-up, is the latest prominent Silicon Valley company to face accusations that it turned a blind eye to sexual harassment.

title: Trump Alarms Venezuela With Talk of a Military Option
description: President Trumps remarks on Friday that he would not rule out a military option to quell the chaos in Venezuela set off a late-night diplomatic duel, with the defense minister accusing Mr. Trump of an act of madness and the White House saying it had turned away a call from Venezuelas president.

title: With Five-Run Eighth, Yankees Edge Red Sox and Pull Closer
description: As Aaron Hicks sat out for much of the last six weeks, sidelined by an oblique strain, the Yankees may have wondered just what they were missing without Hicks, their fourth outfielder in name only.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them and Rescue Dog to Super Dog
description: J. K. Rowlings latest Harry Potter offshoot brings its inky enchantment to HBO. And some good dogs take on daunting tasks for love.

title: Chiles Energy Transformation Is Powered by Wind, Sun and Volcanoes
description: CERRO PABELLN, Chile  It looks and functions much like an oil drilling rig. As it happens, several of the men in thick blue overalls and white helmets who operate the hulking machine once made a living pumping crude.

title: Generating Green Energy in a Chilean Desert
description: Chile is advancing in its goals for reliance on renewable energy, with South Americas first geothermal plant and a constellation of solar and wind farms.

title: A Tranquil Oasis in Greece
description: From 101 euros (about $120).

title: For Once, No One Was Upset. Truth Works.
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

title: Portugal Forest Fires Worsen, Fed by Poor Choices and Inaction
description: OLEIROS, Portugal  When Portugals deadliest wildfire killed more than 60 people in June not far from the hamlet where Daniel Muralha lives, it was just the pensioners latest brush with death.

title: Dear Sugars: Should I Intervene?
description: Should a parent stay out of the personal lives of their independent adult children  even when they see potential land mines? Thats a question the Sugars answer in this weeks episode from a writer who calls herself Damned Either Way.

title: Silicon Valley Now Has Its Own Populist Pundit
description: MENLO PARK, Calif.  Its not easy being the first and only Fox News host in Silicon Valley.

title: Trump Tower, a Home for Celebrities and Charlatans
description: Hillary Clinton slept here.

title: Hong Kongs Cinematic Style
description: Mr. Xu, who grew up in Queens, N.Y.,  cited Wong Kar-wai films, Christopher Doyle cinematography, Fan Ho photography and 90s gangster movies like Young and Dangerous as inspirations for his work. He has frequently traveled to Hong Kong, spending weeks there at a time.

title: Senate Inquiry Into Russian Meddling Could Wrap Up This Year, Burr Says
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Richard Burr, the initially reluctant but now determined leader of the Senate Intelligence Committee inquiry into Russian interference in the 2016 election, said the investigation had expanded beyond its original scope based on new evidence, but he hoped to complete it this year to allow Congress to take steps to prevent future efforts at tampering by Moscow.

title: Why the Dow Isnt Really the Stock Market
description: Despite a few rocky days recently, the stock market is having a great year. But exactly how great depends on what you mean by the stock market.

title: Techs Damaging Myth of the Loner Genius Nerd
description: The Google engineer who was fired last week over his memo wrote that most women were biologically unsuited to working in tech because they were more focused on feelings and aesthetics than ideas and had a stronger interest in people rather than things.

title: Its Very Easy to Die There: How Prisoners Fare in Vietnam
description: HANOI, Vietnam  Do Thi Mai said she was shocked to learn that her 17-year-old son, Do Dang Du, had fallen into a coma in prison a few weeks after he was arrested, accused by the police of stealing about $90.

title: Mikes and Katies Week in Tech: Uber Infighting and the Google Memo
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Farhad is off this week, so Katie Benner, a Times technology reporter, filled in.

title: Only 22 Years, 364 Days Old? Come Back Tomorrow
description: Caitlin Iris Moseman Wadler and Christopher Brice Porter were married Aug. 12 at the Portside Manor in Searsport, Me. Andrew Martin, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Two Worldviews Meet in the Middle
description: Adrian Andrew Ohmer and Darren McKibbon DeWitt were married Aug. 8. Judge Judith E. Levy of Federal District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan officiated at the Gandy Dancer, a restaurant in Ann Arbor, Mich. On Aug. 12, a friend of the couple, Brian P. Glenn Jr., led a ceremony at Camp Smitty in Eganville, Ontario.

title: A Wall That Tracks Trends for Architectural Design
description: Water and space to spare

title: Is Motherhood a Sacrifice or a Privilege?
description: In my recent Sunday Review piece, I addressed the question of whether motherhood is a sacrifice or a privilege, whether it is selfless or selfish. I made the argument that we would go a long way to empowering women and mothers by reframing the way we think and talk about mothers by refusing the badge of martyrdom and by heeding the language we use when we talk about motherhood. By insisting on calling motherhood a selfless sacrifice, we take agency away from her.

title: What if Friends Stay Past the Landlords Limit?
description: Q. I have been living in the same rent-stabilized apartment in Midtown East for decades. I am planning a trip of as long as six weeks to Europe, swapping apartments with a friend who lives in Italy. There would be no exchange of money. My landlord says I am allowed to have a visitor for no more than 30 days. What would happen if I had two guests stay, one for 20 days and the other for 25 days?

title: Trump to Guam Governor: North Korea Threats Will Boost Tourism Tenfold
description: HAGATNA, Guam  If theres one thing that Guam does not have to worry about while the tiny island is in the nuclear cross hairs of North Korea, its tourism, President Trump told the islands governor in a phone call made public on Saturday.

title: Braves Freddie Freeman Sets a Moving Example
description: The Anaheim Angels, as they were known then, hosted nine postseason games in October 2002. In the first of those, they fell far behind the Yankees but stormed back to win. Freddie Freeman, then a 13-year-old fan in the stands, will never forget it.

title: Once in the Vanguard of Diversity, Knicks Build a Future That Echoes the Past
description: A reliable and deserving piata for critics since the turn of the century, the Knicks are suddenly drawing applause for going all-in on front-office diversity, for being progressively bold, for doing the right thing.

title: Trumps Talk of Military Option in Venezuela May Bolster Maduros Hand
description: The thought of military intervention in Venezuela probably took many Americans by surprise when it was floated on Friday by President Trump. But in Venezuela, it was a threat that would have sounded familiar, as if the words had been scripted by the government itself.

title: In the Land of Internet Subcultures, Try Not to Look Like a Tourist
description: A loose agglomeration of right-wing pundits and personalities on YouTube have, in the last few years, accumulated substantial and devoted audiences. Their politics are severe; they are culture warriors with a new set of weapons. They make their arguments for people who might not be reached by other media  and do so in a novel, medium-specific way. Those audiences get to know their hosts, and each other, developing those who develop into fandoms while simultaneously experiencing ideological formation. This is the simple case for the relevance of the YouTube Right, which I wrote about for The New York Times Magazine earlier this month. After it was published, controversy erupted over a Google employees memo criticizing his companys attitudes toward diversity; when the employee was fired, he granted his first interview to Stefan Molyneux, a central figure in the movement (and the piece).

title: When Torture Becomes Science
description: Was the Central Intelligence Agencys post-9/11 enhanced interrogation program an instance of human experimentation?

title: Submarine Owner Is Charged in Journalists Disappearance
description: COPENHAGEN  Did a Danish submarine owner kill his only passenger, a Swedish journalist who had accompanied him onboard for a story?

title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Sometimes your imagination can run away with you and you run into the danger of overthinking things. I really enjoyed Richard Silvestris cryptic crossword, especially since I am solving a lot of them right now. But I honestly thought he had laid an egg in his grid.

title: Man Charged After White Nationalist Rally in Charlottesville Ends in Deadly Violence
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  The city of Charlottesville was engulfed by violence on Saturday as white nationalists and counterprotesters clashed in one of the bloodiest fights to date over the removal of Confederate monuments across the South.

title: Mueller Is Said to Seek Interviews With West Wing in Russia Case
description: WASHINGTON  In a sign that the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election will remain a continuing distraction for the White House, the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, is in talks with the West Wing about interviewing current and former senior administration officials, including the recently ousted White House chief of staff, Reince Priebus, according to three people briefed on the discussions.

title: Trump Eyes China Sanctions While Seeking Its Help on North Korea
description: BEIJING  In a diplomatic gamble, President Trump is seeking to enlist China as a peacemaker in the bristling nuclear-edged dispute with North Korea at the very moment he plans to ratchet up conflict with Beijing over trade issues that have animated his political rise.

title: American Is Cleared After Woman Is Shoved Into Path of London Bus
description: LONDON  A man who was arrested after a woman was shoved into the path of a London bus has been released and eliminated as a suspect in the incident, the police said on Saturday.

title: Trump Threats Are Wild Card in Showdown With North Korea
description: BRIDGEWATER, N.J.  After a four-day fusillade of apocalyptic threats against North Korea, President Trump left many in Washington and capitals throughout the Pacific wondering whether it was more method or madness. Among those wondering were members of Mr. Trumps own administration.

title: Protests Rage On in Kenya After President Is Re-Elected
description: KISUMU, Kenya  The sun had barely risen, but protesters were already bracing for another wave of confrontations with the police in the city of Kisumu on Saturday after an election disputed by supporters of Kenyas opposition party.

title: Youll Never Be as Radical as This 18th-Century Quaker Dwarf
description: It was September 1738, and Benjamin Lay had walked 20 miles, subsisting on acorns and peaches, to reach the Quakers Philadelphia Yearly Meeting. Beneath his overcoat he wore a military uniform and a sword  both anathema to Quaker teachings. He also carried a hollowed-out book with a secret compartment, into which he had tucked a tied-off animal bladder filled with bright red pokeberry juice.

title: A Mets Outfielder Waits, and Waits, to Show What He Can Do
description: The odds against Brandon Nimmos becoming a major league baseball player were perhaps more daunting than those of many other talented players who are taken in the draft.

title: State of Emergency in Virginia as White Nationalists March
description: The governor of Virginia declared a state of emergency in Charlottesville Saturday as white nationalists clashed with counterprotesters over a plan to remove the statue of a Confederate general from a city park.

title: A Cancer Conundrum: Too Many Drug Trials, Too Few Patients
description: With the arrival of two revolutionary treatment strategies, immunotherapy and personalized medicine, cancer researchers have found new hope  and a problem that is perhaps unprecedented in medical research.

title: Fleeing to the Mountains
description: ON THE PACIFIC CREST TRAIL, NORTHWEST OF TRUCKEE, Calif.  This will make me sound grouchy and misanthropic, but I sometimes wonder if what makes America great isnt so much its people as its trees and mountains.

title: Im a White Man. Hear Me Out.
description: Im a white man, so you should listen to absolutely nothing I say, at least on matters of social justice. I have no standing. No way to relate. My color and gender nullify me, and it gets worse: I grew up in the suburbs. Dad made six figures. We had a backyard pool. From the 10th through 12th grades, I attended private school. So the only proper way for me to check my privilege is to realize that it blinds me to others struggles and should gag me during discussions about the right responses to them.

title: Send the Breast Pump With the Defense Attach
description: I held the syringe up to the light above the bathroom mirror and flicked it a few times with my finger to make sure I had the exact dose of Lupron. I checked my watch to calculate the time in Washington. I pulled the waistline of my pants below my belly button, steadied my feet, wiped my abdomen with an alcohol swab and took a deep breath.

title: When Doctors Help End Lives
description: To the Editor:

title: Unions Loss Is the Souths Loss, Too
description: Workers at a Nissan plant in Canton, Miss., picked a bird in the hand when they recently voted against forming a union, and thats understandable. Veteran workers, who generally opposed the union, make $26 an hour. That is less than the nearly $30 an hour for similar autoworkers in unions at the major American carmakers  but almost twice the median hourly wage in Mississippi.

title: Definition of Summer Madness
description: Think Im ready to come home, Daddy.

title: The Vacation-Taker Denier in Chief
description: Donald Trump is on vacation, but the White House has made it clear that its not a real vacation. Its 17 days away from Washington, but its a working vacation. Actually, its more of a working remotely situation. Actually, hes working so hard he may as well be at the White House, do you understand? If you dont, just check Twitter, where he will be giving hourly updates about how not relaxing this getaway is!

title: Google Doesnt Want Whats Best for Us
description: Google processes more than three billion search queries a day. It has altered our notions of privacy, tracking what we buy, what we search for online  and even our physical location at every moment of the day. Every business trying to reach mass-market consumer demand online knows that Google is the gatekeeper.

title: Making Affirmative Action White Again
description: Jeff Sessions told the Senate Judiciary Committee 20 years ago that affirmative action irritated people (he meant white people) because it could cause them to lose opportunities simply because of their race. This sense of grievance lies behind the Justice Departments recent memo seeking lawyers to investigate race-based discrimination in college admissions.

title: This Is What Hunger Looks Like  Again
description: Mogadishu, Somalia  As I waited for my ride to collect me from the Mogadishu airport, an officer told me an apocryphal tale: A starving goat, blind from hunger, mistook a baby wrapped in a green cloth for grass and bit off a mouthful of emaciated flesh from the babys upper arm. The babys anguished cry brought the mother to her knees and she wept in prayer. The next day, a friend I met in Mogadishu repeated a variation of the same tale.

title: Will the Blowhard Blow Us Up?
description: WASHINGTON  A couple of chubby brats with big missiles and short fuses.

title: A Cosmic Distraction From Earths Troubles
description: By now, countless Americans are eagerly mapping their proximity to the path of totality. No, not the possible trajectories of North Koreas ballistic missiles, lately much in the news. This path of totality refers to a far less threatening and far more joyous event: the moons total eclipse of the sun on Aug. 21 in a 70-mile-wide swath in which darkness will snuff out daylight for two minutes or so as it glides across 14 states, silencing the birds and bestirring the humans.

title: The Missiles of August
description: Heres the good news, America: The Donald Trump versus Kim Jong-un showdown may be making you nervous, but it isnt the first time a reckless, lecherous U.S. president obsessed with his own vigor and out of his depth on foreign policy faced off against a thirtysomething dictator armed with nukes. If we survived the Cuban missile crisis without a thermonuclear war, theres probably a way to get through this one, too.

title: Why Women Had Better Sex Under Socialism
description: When Americans think of Communism in Eastern Europe, they imagine travel restrictions, bleak landscapes of gray concrete, miserable men and women languishing in long lines to shop in empty markets and security services snooping on the private lives of citizens. While much of this was true, our collective stereotype of Communist life does not tell the whole story.

title: When Lady Liberty Triggers Trump Supporters
description: Vogues September issue is to the fashion world what the Super Bowl is to football, and on Wednesday the glossy magazine unveiled four covers for next month, all featuring the actress Jennifer Lawrence. On one cover, she is dressed in a crimson gown, leaning on the rail of a ferry with the Statue of Liberty glowing behind her. American Beauty, reads the covers text. Jennifer Lawrence on love, liberty and the freedom to be herself.

title: Trump Cautious on China Inquiry Over Intellectual Property Theft
description: BRIDGEWATER, N.J.  President Trump is planning to jab, not punch, China for allegedly stealing intellectual property from American businesses, part of an effort to fulfill his hard-edge campaign promises on trade without alienating Beijing during the crisis over North Koreas nuclear weapons program.

title: Long Island Football Player Dies After Being Hit by 400-Pound Log
description: The death of a teenage football player on Long Island has raised questions as to why students were asked to carry what the police described as an approximately 400-pound, 10-foot log while participating in an off-season conditioning camp.

title: Yankees Place Masahiro Tanaka on the Disabled List
description: The right-hander Masahiro Tanaka on Saturday became the third of the Yankees five opening day starting pitchers to go on the disabled list.

title: Stay, Hide or Leave? Hard Choices for Immigrants in the Heartland
description: HAMPTON, Iowa  It was quitting time. Edith Rivera took one last lunch order, dropped off a basket of tortilla chips and set off from work, heading out to the farm roads where other immigrants feared to drive.

title: Trump Is Criticized for Not Calling Out White Supremacists
description: BRIDGEWATER, N.J.  President Trump is rarely reluctant to express his opinion, but he is often seized by caution when addressing the violence and vitriol of white nationalists, neo-Nazis and alt-right activists, some of whom are his supporters.

title: Usain Bolts Final Race Ends in a Cry of Pain, and a Whimper
description: LONDON  The loudest roar of these world track and field championships came on Saturday night as Usain Bolt lay facedown on the track and in great pain.

title: The Magic Show
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Anyone who has ever tried to construct a crossword learns almost immediately that it requires quite a bit of prestidigitation. But have you ever solved a puzzle that actually had magic tricks in it?

title: Quotation of the Day: Beach-Spread (Verb): To Cram the Sand With Tents, Grills and Tables
description: We had a guy last year bring in a coffin. Im not lying, a wooden coffin with his food and his drinks and so forth. And we said, No we cant have that.

title: Charlottesville and the Bigotocracy
description: The late, great Gore Vidal said that we live in The United States of Amnesia. Our fatal forgetfulness flares when white bigots come out of their closets, emboldened by the tacit cover theyre given by our president. We cannot pretend that the ugly bigotry unleashed in the streets of Charlottesville, Va., this weekend has nothing to do with the election of Donald Trump.

title: Yankees Jordan Montgomery Hit in Head by Ball During Batting Practice
description: Yankees pitcher Jordan Montgomery was struck in the head by a foul ball while he signed autographs down the right-field line during batting practice before Saturdays game against the Red Sox at Yankee Stadium.

title: Elizabeth Warren Takes Aim at Moderates and Generates Chants of Warren 2020
description: ATLANTA  Senator Elizabeth Warren used a speech to a grass-roots conference Saturday to take direct aim at Democrats diminished moderate wing, ridiculing Clinton-era policies and jubilantly proclaiming that liberals had taken control of the party.

title: Hideki Matsuyama Trips in Pursuit of a Breakthrough at the P.G.A. Championship
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  When Hideki Matsuyama climbed the 48 steps from the Quail Hollow practice green to the first tee on Saturday, he took them two at a time, as if to show that the lead he held halfway through the P.G.A. Championship was not weighing heavily on him.

title: Corrections: August 13, 2017
description: THE ARTS

title: Bostons Andrew Benintendi Picks Up Where Aaron Judge Left Off
description: Andrew Benintendi did not quite invade the Judges Chambers on Saturday.

title: Chelsea Is Stunned in Its Premier League Opener
description: Two Chelsea players were sent off Saturday during a 3-2 loss to visiting Burnley in the first game of Chelseas Premier League title defense. The defeat intensified the concerns surrounding Chelsea after its frustrating off-season in the transfer market.

title: After Yankees Montgomery Is Struck in the Ear, Severino Is Hit Hard in Loss
description: With time to kill on Saturday afternoon, Yankees pitcher Jordan Montgomery was being a mensch, signing autographs down the right-field line at Yankee Stadium while the Boston Red Sox took batting practice.

title: Stephanie Khan, Luis Gonzalez Jr.
description: Stephanie Marie Khan and Luis Fellipe Gonzalez Jr. were married Aug. 11 at the Town Hall of Hempstead, N.Y. Nasrin G. Ahmad, the Hempstead town clerk, officiated.

title: Sara Vandermark, Thomas de Swardt
description: Sara Laglia Vandermark and Thomas William de Swardt were married Aug. 12 in New York. The Rev. Dr. Kevin Moroney, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd at the General Theological Seminary.

title: Rachele Rosen, Jacob Fein
description: Rachele Helene Rosen and Jacob Solomon Fein are to be married Aug. 13 in Manhattan. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein is to officiate at Pier 60 at Chelsea Piers.

title: Emily Belfer, Raphael Rosen
description: Emily Anne Belfer and Dr. Raphael Judah Rosen are to be married Aug. 13 at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J. Rabbi Ezra Schwartz is to officiate.

title: Raquel Tavarez, Gregory Sanchez
description: Raquel Elisa Tavarez and Gregory Benjamin Sanchez were married Aug. 11 in Brooklyn. Bliss Broyard, a Universal Life minister, officiated at 26 Bridge, an event space.

title: Lucy Batterman, Eli Fishbein
description: Lucy Blake Batterman and Yasachar Eli Fishbein are to be married Aug. 13 at Nauticus Marina, an event space in Osterville, Mass. Rabbi Matthew D. Gewirtz is to lead the ceremony.

title: Grace MacLean, Michael Perillo
description: Grace Elizabeth MacLean and Michael David Perillo were married Aug. 12. The Rev. Dr. David J. Lose performed the ceremony at Mount Olivet Lutheran Church in Minneapolis, where he is the senior pastor, with the Rev. John L. Parr, a Roman Catholic priest, taking part.

title: Sterling McDavid, Carey Dorman
description: Sterling McDavid and Carey James Dorman were married Aug. 12. The Rev. Mark Matlock, a cousin of the bride and a nondenominational Christian minister, officiated at the Little Nells wedding deck at the top of Aspen Mountain in Aspen, Colo.

title: Betsy Morais, Thomas Rhiel
description: Betsy Ilene Morais and Thomas Wesley Rhiel were married Aug. 12 at Brooklyn Winery. Benjamin Cotton, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Ariel Cohen, Louis Orren
description: Ariel Nikiya Cohen and Louis Howard Maurice Orren are to be married Aug. 13. Rabbi Randy E. Sheinberg is to officiate at the Carlyle on the Green in Farmingdale, N.Y.

title: Judith Heicklen, Neil Schuman
description: Judith Rachel Heicklen and Rabbi Neil Ross Schuman are to be married Aug. 13 at Temple Beth Rishon in Wyckoff, N.J. Bat Sheva Marcus, who was ordained by the American Marriage Ministries, is to officiate in a ceremony that will incorporate Jewish traditions.

title: Ariana Torchin, Vivek Mohan
description: Ariana Judith Torchin and Vivek Kartik Mohan were married Aug. 12 at the Gramercy Park Hotel in New York. Susan Turchin, an interfaith minister, officiated the ceremony, which incorporated Jewish wedding traditions after a traditional Vedic ceremony.

title: Katrina Valdes, Joseph Bishop IV
description: Katrina Lauren Valdes and Joseph Andrew Bishop IV were married Aug. 12 at the Basilica of St. Lawrence in Asheville, N.C. The Rev. Adrian Porras, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with Eduardo Blanco, a Roman Catholic deacon, taking part.

title: Laura Dunn, Louis Cona

Now, in her second novel, Eat Only When Youre Hungry, she takes a different tack. The books protagonist, Greg, is a suburban 58-year-old man who goes off in search of his drug-addicted adult son, whos been missing for three weeks.

Jung Ki-youl, chairman of the local government here, asked an estimated 25,000 mostly young South Koreans at Nuri Peace Park, only five miles from the demilitarized zone that separates the two Koreas. The crowd was eagerly awaiting a two-hour concert on Saturday night featuring some of the biggest stars of K-pop, a popular genre of music in South Korea.

title: Weekly Occurrence

My older child is a vegetarian who is allergic to mushrooms and dislikes green salads, my younger child eats maybe three foods (most of which involve meat), and Im quite happy to try anything, as long as it doesnt involve liver, cottage cheese, or has the head still on it. So our bases are covered.

Senator Luther Strange of Alabama wields an endorsement from the president of the United States, is the beneficiary of a multimillion-dollar campaign from allies of Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, and has the backing of influential conservative interest groups like the National Rifle Association.

title: Twin Peaks Season 3, Episode 14: Who Is the Dreamer?
description: Several times during this season of Twin Peaks, right before an episode has ended with a musical performance, the show has featured brief scenes of young people talking at the Roadhouse. Sometimes these characters have returned later. But for the most part, these sketches have been disconnected to anything else happening on the show. Theyve functioned more as a reminder that the current generation of fresh-faced Twin Peaks residents is as mired in melodrama as Donna Hayward, Audrey Horne, Laura Palmer, James Hurley and Bobby Briggs once were.

title: Quotation of the Day: Tracing Success of North Korea to Ukraine Plant
description: Its likely that these engines came from Ukraine  probably illicitly. The big question is how many they have and whether the Ukrainians are helping them now. Im very worried.

description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, August 14, 2017.

title: Salma Hayek Isnt Trying to Fool Anyone
description: Salma Hayek, 50, may have broken into Hollywood via hot girl roles, but she long ago left them in the Desperado dust. These days, she has become quite the powerhouse: producing TV shows, running a skin care and makeup label called Nuance, investing in the company Juice Generation  and acting. This month, shell appear in the action film The Hitmans Bodyguard, in theaters Friday. Here, she reveals how she keeps her skin sane and why a particular Japanese masseuse is the woman to know.

title: Premier League Heeds the Siren Song of Spend, Spend, Spend
description: NEWCASTLE, England  Last Wednesday, the English striker Andre Gray moved to Watford from Burnley. At 18.5 million pounds, or about $24 million, it was not the most expensive transfer this summer. It was hardly the most glamorous, and it is unlikely to be the most meaningful or memorable.

description: WASHINGTON  The day before President Trumps inauguration, the top executive of the Sinclair Broadcast Group, the nations largest owner of television stations, invited an important guest to the headquarters of the companys Washington-area ABC affiliate.

title: Joseph Bologna, Onscreen Tough Guy With a Sense of Humor, Dies at 82

He was 82.

description: Princess Diana talks about life under the microscope in a series of rarely heard interviews from 1991. CBS News visits American military bases on alert during threats from North Korea. And Hunting the KGB Killers investigates the 2006 poisoning death of Alexander V. Litvinenko.

title: On Set | 5 Cats, 200 Japanese Pastries
description: On set with the feline stars of a very sweet story in Ts fall womens issue.

title: Sweets as Poignant as Poetry
description: River of heaven. Young grass waiting under snow. Wind in the distance.

title: Meet the Cats
description: To pose alongside the almost 200 Japanese sweets we photographed for Ts Fall Womens Issue, our photo director, Nadia Vellam, cast five fabulous  felines. With the exception of one fledgling foster kitten, the models were all perfectly trained professionals, having starred in luxury fashion campaigns and high-profile commercials. But on set, even they could not resist the bright bounty before them: Piles of artfully crafted jellies, cakes and bonbons in fairy-tale hues and dazzling shapes, each, coincidentally, about the size and color of a cat toy.

title: The Brain Cancer That Keeps Killing Baseball Players
description: PHILADELPHIA  Since Darren Daulton succumbed to brain cancer on Aug. 6, heartfelt tributes have honored the way he led a raucous Phillies team to the World Series in 1993.

title: At the Stroke of Midnight My Entire Family Was Displaced
description: August marks the 70th anniversary of the end of British colonial rule in India and the creation of the two independent countries of India and Pakistan, carved along religious and political lines. More than 10 million people were uprooted. We asked readers how they or their families were affected. These are some of their stories.

title: North Koreas Missile Success Is Linked to Ukrainian Plant, Investigators Say
description: North Koreas success in testing an intercontinental ballistic missile that appears able to reach the United States was made possible by black-market purchases of powerful rocket engines probably from a Ukrainian factory with historical ties to Russias missile program, according to an expert analysis being published Monday and classified assessments by American intelligence agencies.

title: A Lighthearted Look at L.A.
description: Beth Dubber has been photographing L.A. for a decade, offering a decidedly lighthearted take on street photography in a city not known for it.

title: The Free Speech Hypocrisy of Right-Wing Media
description: The right-wing media is obsessed with the supposed stifling of free speech on college campuses, but it seems to care only about protecting speech it likes. When progressives make provocative statements, conservative pundits react with wounded outrage. This double standard is especially striking in the internet era, as the negative coverage of progressives leads to unbelievable harassment of both professors and students.

title: Single Payer or Bust?
description: News arrived last week that Our Revolution, the political group that arose from Bernie Sanderss presidential campaign, is going to back primary challenges against Democrats who arent deemed ardent enough in their support for single-payer health care. Were not going to accept no more hemming and hawing, said the groups president, Nina Turner. Make your stand.

title: Before You Rip Up That Iran Deal ...
description: Opponents of the 2015 Iran nuclear deal often complain that the deal doesnt address the nefarious ways in which Iran is expanding its influence and further destabilizing the Middle East. Such concerns, while valid, are no reason to blow up the agreement, as President Trump is recklessly trying to do by pressing his administration to declare, with absolutely no evidence, that Iran is in violation of the terms.

title: When the President Is Un-American
description: Remember back in 2008, when Sarah Palin used to talk about the real America? She meant rural and small-town residents  white residents, it went without saying  who supposedly embodied the nations true essence.

title: Christianity Does Not Justify Trumps Fire and Fury
description: Following President Trumps initial threats of fire and fury toward North Korea on Aug. 8, Robert Jeffress, the evangelical pastor of the First Baptist Church of Dallas, and a presidential adviser, released a statement claiming that God had given the president authority to take out North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. Jeffress was the presidents selected preacher at the traditional pre-inauguration liturgy at St. Johns Episcopal Church and claims to speak with Mr. Trump on a variety of issues.

title: Gunmen Kill 18 at Restaurant in Burkina Faso
description: DAKAR, Senegal  At least 18 people were killed in Burkina Faso when gunmen stormed a popular cafe and sprayed diners with bullets, including a family celebrating a 9-year-olds birthday, the authorities said Monday.

title: A Lighthearted Look at L.A.
description: Instagram and iPhones didnt exist when Beth Dubber began taking street photographs in Los Angeles in 2006. She had moved there in 2003, hoping for a career as a set photographer for film and television. While waiting for her big break, she joined a local networking group where she got the idea to photograph Los Angeles one day a week, and share one picture with a weekly email list. Remember, this was 2006: Social media hadnt taken off, and the list forced her into a habit of shooting weekly, no matter what.

title: U.S. Rallies Behind Charlottesville
description: Vigils were held across the country on Sunday to honor the life of Heather D. Heyer, who was killed a day earlier while protesting a rally of white nationalists.

title: On the Beach, the Once and Future Me
description: All the worlds a beach, and the men and women merely sunbathers, as Shakespeare put it, in that famous speech about remembering to use sunscreen with a high enough SPF, and to reapply regularly after swimming.

title: New on This Falls Law School Syllabus: Trump
description: President Trump is transforming the study of constitutional law.

title: New Ways to Find and Book the Perfect Vacation Rental
description: Many travelers have grown accustomed to finding vacation rentals by going directly to sites like Airbnb, HomeAway and VRBO. But these days you can find and book a rental halfway around the world in ways you may not have considered, or even know about: on traditional hotel and airfare booking websites like Expedia and Hotels.com, through the hotel review (and now booking) site TripAdvisor or even in Google search.

title: The Life of a Game of Thrones Recapper

title: How A.I. Is Creating Building Blocks to Reshape Music and Art
