title: Word + Quiz: anticlimax
A Total Solar Eclipse From Space
description: Will you be able to see the total solar eclipse that will trace a path on Aug. 21 from Oregon to South Carolina? Will you be watching?

title: Film by Beijing Students Explores Being Young and Transgender in China
description: BEIJING  The 18-year-old student out for a stroll at night was wearing makeup and a skirt and high heels when a passer-by suddenly collided with him. Sorry, miss, the man said before continuing on his way. The student turned and stared at the man until he was out of sight, clearly delighted to have been taken for a woman.

title: Thousands of Players, Hundreds of Events and Little Reward
description: PRAGUE  A German of Chilean descent, an American with Russian parentage, a Pole and a Dutchman were arguing in English on a red clay tennis court on the outskirts of Prague.

title: Right and Left on Removal of Confederate Statues
description: The political news cycle is fast, and keeping up can be overwhelming. Trying to find differing perspectives worth your time is even harder. Thats why we have scoured the internet for political writing from the right and left that you might not have seen.

title: Reset the Clock for Malpractice Suits
description: In 2010, a Brooklyn woman named Lavern Wilkinson went to Kings County Hospital with chest pain. An X-ray was taken. It looked fine, a first-year resident in the emergency room said, and Ms. Wilkinson was sent home.

title: A Simple Move to Save Thousands of Lives From Overdose
description: The United States is in the midst of a public health crisis. More than 59,000 people are believed to have died from drug overdose in 2016, an increase of nearly 20 percent from the previous year. Most of these deaths are caused by opioids like prescription painkillers, heroin and the potent synthetic drug fentanyl.

title: Jeff Flake: We Need Immigrants With Skills. But Working Hard Is a Skill.
description: Someone recently said, When Mexico sends its people, theyre not sending their best.

title: Trump Makes Caligula Look Pretty Good
description: Even before the media obsession with Hillary Clintons email server put The Worst President Ever in the White House, historians were comparing Donald Trump to Caligula, the cruel, depraved Roman emperor who delighted in humiliating others, especially members of the empires elite. But seven months into the Trump administration, we can see that this comparison was unfair.

title: The Real American Heritage
description: Before they die, before they disappear into the opaque mist of history, the last Americans to fight Nazi Germany have to face one more blast of something they thought theyd eliminated in the bloodiest war of all time.

title: The Justice Department Goes Fishing in DreamHost Case
description: Do you use the internet? Are you interested in politics? Do you value your privacy? If you answered yes, you should be alarmed by the shockingly broad search warrant sought by the Justice Department, and approved by a judge in Washington, D.C., last month, targeting DreamHost, an internet hosting company based in Los Angeles.

title: Police See Wider Plot in Spain and Say Carnage Could Have Been Worse
description: BARCELONA, Spain  When an earthshaking explosion on Wednesday blew apart a house outside Alcanar, a town surrounded by olive groves and holiday homes overlooking the Mediterranean, the police first blamed it on a gas leak.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge John Hodgman on Pie Semantics
description: Caren writes: A friend of mine hosted a pie party, and I arrived with a raspberry Danish coffee cake. Another friend claimed that this was a pastry, not a pie. I argued that by the various definitions of pie found online and in dictionaries, the coffee cake did, in fact, technically qualify as a pie.

title: How to Survive a Bear Encounter
description: Help the bear identify you as human, says John Hechtel, a retired wildlife biologist for Alaskas Department of Fish and Game. Talk to it in a calm but firm voice. Put your hands above your heads and wave them slowly. Avoid reacting to a confrontation in a way that makes you look like prey: no screaming, flailing or running.

title: New Sentences: From The Great Nadar, by Adam Begley
description: A parenthetical sentence is a paradoxical thing. It straddles worlds: It is both inside and outside the text simultaneously, included and excluded. It is not quite important enough to merit the full center-stage spotlight but also not unimportant enough to be shoved entirely behind a curtain. A pair of parentheses is the sound of a text leaning over and whispering to us.

title: The Challenge of a Wright House
description: Frank Lloyd Wright houses may be architectural masterpieces but finding a buyer isn't always easy. Take a tour of Tirranna, on the market in New Canaan, Conn., for $7.2 million.

title: The 8.6.17 Issue
description: RE: LOSING IT

title: How to Stay Sane During a Solar Eclipse
description: In March 2006, I stood on a crowded beach in Turkey and waited until, at the allotted time, with a chorus of screams and cheers and whistles and applause, the sun slid away, and impossibly, impossibly, we saw above us a stretch of black sky and in the middle of it a hole, blacker than anything Id ever seen, fringed with a ring of soft white fire. My heart jumped up to my throat, and my eyes grew hot with tears. I fell to my knees, feeling tiny and huge, and as lonely as Ive ever been, but also astonishingly close to the crowds around me.

title: Behind the Cover: 8.20.17
description: Jake Silverstein, editor in chief: Mark Petersons kinetic shot of Charlie Spiering, Breitbarts senior White House correspondent, manages to feel simultaneously dramatic and absurd  a juxtaposition of qualities that captures the strangeness of this news organizations rapid ascent into the inner circle of power in Washington.

title: Poem: The Widow
description: Selected by Terrance Hayes

title: Trump Says More Jobs Will Help Race Relations. If Only It Were So Simple.
description: President Trump has a simple answer for racial tension in the United States: jobs.

title: Giving the Lie to the Notion That Warfare Is Unwomanly
description: THE UNWOMANLY FACE OF WAR An Oral History of Women in World War II By Svetlana Alexievich 331 pp. Random House. $30.

title: Food, Folklore and Fulfillment Against a French Backdrop
description: THE LITTLE FRENCH BISTRO By Nina George 311 pp. Crown. $26.

title: Paperback Row
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

title: Americas Quintessential Maverick Composer, at 100
description: Many of the musical and philosophical characteristics that defined Lou Harrison, who would have turned 100 this year, as a quintessential American maverick composer come through in La Koro Sutro (The Heart Sutra).

title: What Happens to Solar Power in an Eclipse? Well Find Out Monday
description: Unlike most eclipse-watchers in the United States, Eric Schmitt wouldnt mind seeing a few clouds in the sky when the moon starts blotting out the sun on Monday.

title: The Russian Revolution Recast as an Epic Family Tragedy
description: THE HOUSE OF GOVERNMENTA Saga of the Russian RevolutionBy Yuri SlezkineIllustrated. 1,104 pp. Princeton University Press. $39.95.

title: Surfing With Sartre: Does Riding a Wave Help Solve Existential Mysteries?
description: SURFING WITH SARTRE An Aquatic Inquiry Into a Life of Meaning By Aaron James 336 pp. Doubleday. $27.95.

title: Birders and Naturalists Ponder the Fate of the Greater Sage Grouse
description: Evan Obercian says it is the highlight of his Colorado birding tours every spring, even though he has to wake his clients up before 5 a.m. to be in the sagebrush flats before the sun comes up. And there they wait in Mr. Obercians van, listening to strange whoops and popping sounds that float magically from the predawn darkness.

title: Alaska Warily Eyes Change Bringing Suburbs and Amazon Boxes
description: PALMER, Alaska  For years, pet owners in this Anchorage suburb of big homes and lawns have fretted over snares set in the local parks by fur-trappers going after fox, lynx and rabbits. But in a quiet revolution this spring, dog lovers got the upper hand, and after a series of public meetings where few trappers showed up to fight back, trapping was banned by the borough council. The suburbs had won.

title: Wells Fargo Borrower Got Unneeded Insurance, and Ruined Credit
description: Wells Fargo has promised to make amends to the customers it forced to buy car insurance that they didnt need. Allan Dunlap, a former Wells Fargo borrower who spent months trying to get the bank to correct an insurance error that marred his credit report, says hell believe it when he sees it.

title: Disappearing Acts: Thrillers Stalk Women With Deadly Secrets
description: LOCAL GIRL MISSING By Claire Douglas 340 pp. Harper, paper, $15.99.

title: In the Yakima Valley, Serious Wines and Sweeping Vistas
description: Travelers to the Pacific Northwest are sometimes lured by postcard promises of orca whales or the Space Needle against a backdrop of lofty peaks. But what too few tourists learn is this: The massive dome of Mount Rainier  arguably the showiest of Washington States majestic Cascades  is best beheld not from Puget Sound but from the high desert east of the mountains. There, from points up and down the Yakima Valley, Rainier and its sister summit, Mount Adams, loom like giant snow cones above swaths of irrigated farmland and sagebrush-covered range.

title: Appreciating Air Travel (For One Day, At Least)
description: Between getting dragged off a plane, punched in the face and paying five times what you normally would for a small can of Pringles, passengers have good reasons to be grumpy. But with National Aviation Day taking place on Aug. 19, why not take a day off from ranting on Twitter to appreciate some of the positive aspects of air travel? There is plenty to marvel at, from its technology and safety to its fascinating history and entertaining in-flight videos.

title: Sorrow and Scrutiny After a Teenagers Death at Football Practice
description: FARMINGVILLE, N.Y.  It was the first official day of football season at Sachem High School East here, but the field remained empty and silent. The overcast sky bore down on the green grounds; dreary weather on a dreadful day. If not for the accident, Joshua Miletos team would have been holding tryouts for the new season.

title: How to Sell a Frank Lloyd Wright House
description: In mid-September, Frank Lloyd Wright aficionados are expected by the busload in New Canaan, Conn., passing through a gate with the name Tirranna carved into the metalwork, to tour a 6,917-square-foot hemicycle house largely designed by Americas master architect.

title: Jimmy Kimmel Says Trump Tower Is Now Its Own Monument to Racism
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: What We Know About the Attacks in Spain
description: Seven suspects in the attacks on a busy pedestrian thoroughfare in Barcelona and the seaside resort town of Cambrils are dead, four are in custody, and one is unaccounted for.

title: Barcelona, Donald Trump, The Defenders: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Thanks to a Shopping Spree, Japan Is Looking Up. It May Not Last.
description: TOKYO  Japans long-sluggish economy has found its spark. To keep it flickering, Japan needs to find more big spenders like Sayaka Sakata.

title: Morning Agenda: A Quiet Investor in Public Fight at Uber
description: The fraying relationship between Uber and one of its largest shareholders has opened a rift in the boardroom of the ride-hailing service.

title: The Daily: The Alt-Right and the Internet
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: Walnuts for Weight Loss?
description: A handful of walnuts may be an effective weight loss tool.

title: Back-to-School Clothes, Back in the U.S.S.R.
description: When summer winds down and my teenage daughter gets ready to start the new school year, she and I go through a ritual. I open her closet and take things out. She wrinkles her nose, rolls her eyes and ignores me, her eyes firmly glued to a screen. I pile clothes on her bed, taking them off hangers or rescuing them from drawers filled to such capacity that opening them is a challenge. She takes her eyes off Instagram for a moment, and says:

title: New York Today: Whales in Our Waters
description: Good morning on this frown-inducing Friday.

title: Meril, From Emeril Lagasse, Looks Beyond New Orleans for Inspiration
description: Even with three successful restaurants in New Orleans, Emeril Lagasse knew that there was room for a new addition to the citys ebullient dining scene. Emerils New Orleans has long cultivated contemporary food in the city, while Emerils Delmonico offers a fresh take on Creole cuisine and NOLA Restaurant presents a taste of Acadiana, with a global tinge. Meril, which Mr. Lagasse named after his youngest daughter and opened in the Warehouse District in September 2016, is the newest star in his constellation.

title: Can You Sweat Out Toxins?
description: Q. Is there any validity to the popular claim that one can sweat out toxins? If so, what toxins can the body sweat out?

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Guns, Sperm and Brainpower
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Guam Is Suddenly in the News. But What Is It Like to Travel There?
description: On a nub-like point on the west coast of Guam stands a monument built as the Statue of Libertys Pacific counterpart. The Latte of Freedom, which opened in 2010, is an 80-foot-tall concrete structure, shaped like a mushroom with an upturned top. Its a homage to the islands famous lattes (pronounced LAH-tees), two-piece stone pillars that, for centuries, the indigenous Chamorros erected as the foundation of traditional buildings. In the observation deck inside the Latte of Freedoms capstone, a plaque explains its cultural roots and announces its modern-day purpose: to stand boldly as Americas Western gatepost from Asia and the Pacific Rim.

title: Coping With Depression as Love Wins the Day
description: From the moment he spotted her in a church pew in 2012, Noah Sutter had a crush on Anna Risch, a college student with part of Psalm 18 (I stood there saved, surprised to be loved) tattooed on her forearm. But it was the Anna Risch he got to know two years later  the one whose suicidal thoughts had put her into a hospital  whom he fell in love with.

title: In China, Your Companys Name Cant Be a Mouthful
description: SHANGHAI  The Chinese government thinks this companys name goes too far: A Group of Youths in Baoji Holding a Cherished Dream That Under the Leadership of Uncle Niu They Will Create the Miracle of Life Network Technology Company Ltd.

title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 10 | What Interested You Most in The Times This Week?
description: Update, Sept. 5: Winners have been announced.

title: Corey E. Thomas of Rapid7 on Why Companies Succeed or Fail
description: This interview with Corey E. Thomas, chief executive of Rapid7, a corporate network security company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Women of Sex Tech, Unite
description: For Janet Lieberman, making sex toys started as a bit of a joke. In 2013, she was living in Brooklyn and getting ready to leave MakerBot, where she worked as an engineer. When people asked her what she planned to do next, shed say she wanted to start a sex toy company.

title: Japan Still Seeks U.S. Protection but Quietly Stakes Its Own Path
description: TOKYO  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan has never seemed to waver in his support for President Trump, seeking out meetings and regularly speaking by telephone. He is one of a few world leaders who rarely criticize or even comment on Mr. Trumps political turmoil at home.

title: Teaching Activities for: What We Know About the Attacks in Spain
description: Before reading the article:

title: Deciding When a Mentor Is a Mentor
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

title: The Locrian Chamber Players Put New Music on the Manhattan Map
description: From their perch high up in the tower of Riverside Church, the Locrian Chamber Players continue to present one of the most consistently interesting new-music series  and when they say new, they mean it: Only works written in the past 10 years make the cut. On Friday, Aug. 25, regular members of the ensemble will be joined by the harpist Jacqueline Kerrod for an evening of musical reveries and meditations.

title: Tracy Morgans Post-Crash Comedy Comes to Carolines
description: At the start of his recent Netflix special, Staying Alive, Tracy Morgan doesnt waste any time addressing his near-death experience, when a car he was in collided with a Wal-Mart truck; he broke his nose, a leg and ribs in the crash and sustained a traumatic brain injury. Could have been worse, he said. I couldve got hit by a Bobs Discount Furniture truck. Recovering from the 2014 accident, with a healthy settlement, he has not only emerged every bit as strong as a comic, but hes also incorporated the experience into his act.

title: Azealia Banks Eyes a Comeback and a Homecoming
description: It wasnt supposed to go like this for the ostracized Harlem rapper Azealia Banks. After 212, her 2011 viral hit that still sounds like it came from the future, Ms. Banks was strapped to the industry rocket ship  a major-label record deal, magazine covers, a Pharrell collaboration  only to self-destruct. With her strong will and studiously uncouth opinions (including a trollish Trump endorsement), she became better known as a social-media loose cannon than a musician.

title: Maira Kalman and The Principles of Uncertainty Head to Jacobs Pillow
description: Take a walk. Who knows what youll find? One observant and serendipitous walker through the world is the artist Maira Kalman, whose fanciful drawings have graced childrens books, covers for The New Yorker and the pages of many other publications, including The New York Times. She and her friend John Heginbotham  a former member of the Mark Morris Dance Group who now directs his own troupe, Dance Heginbotham  have collaborated on The Principles of Uncertainty.

title: A New Hologram of Serena Williams at Martos Gallery
description: The artist JPW3 (J. Patrick Walsh) has described his materials  wax, tuning forks, car engines, doorways, popcorn  as an excess of fuel, which he directs toward his various experiments in painting, installation, performance and holography. Now, in a show called Figure Ascending a Return, which opened Aug. 17 at Martos Gallerys new Elizabeth Street location, he has created another version of his Serena Williams hologram, Serena Hologram xl, 2017.

title: Ready for the Solar Eclipse? Nova on PBS Has You Covered
description: For those stuck under a rock on Aug. 21 when the Eclipse Across America plunges moongazers along the narrow path of totality into darkness (and the rest of us into various shades of dim), Nova is coming to the rescue. That evening, the PBS science show will present a companion to this celestial experience  the first time since June 8, 1918, that a coast-to-coast total solar eclipse has occurred in North America  featuring footage shot earlier in the day by NASA and local public television stations in the path.

title: Late-Night Summer Offerings Include Firestarter and Crash
description: Concerts in the park? Check. Days at the beach? Absolutely. But any must-do list of summer-in-the-city activities should also include a midnight movie or two, with the late-screening crowd spilling out onto the steamy streets afterward.

title: California Today: The Eclipse Is Coming. Are You Ready?
description: Good morning.

title: The Demons of Darkness Will Eat Men, and Other Solar Eclipse Myths
description: We understand the cosmic calculus that leads to solar eclipses like the one that will enchant many Americans on Monday.

title: Cambridge University Press Removes Academic Articles on Chinese Site
description: BEIJING  One of the worlds oldest and most respected publishing houses, Cambridge University Press, has bowed to pressure from Beijing and removed sensitive content on its site in China.

title: China Steps Up Warnings Over Debt-Fueled Overseas Acquisitions
description: BEIJING  China moved on Friday to curb investment overseas by its companies and conglomerates, issuing its strongest signal yet that it wants to rein in runaway debt that could pose a threat to the countrys slowing economy.

title: Hippie Amenities With a High-End Twist
description: As dusk fell over Staten Island on a recent evening, about 10 people sat around a large wooden table in a communal kitchen, listening to Van Morrison and painting terra-cotta flowerpots. Houseplants were suspended from the rooms high wood-beamed ceilings, and the smell of freshly baked bread hung in the air.

title: How Michael Strahan, Television Host, Spends His Sundays
description: Michael Strahan, the Hall of Fame defensive end who played 15 seasons with the New York Giants before retiring in 2008 after helping the team win the Super Bowl, probably changed a lot of Sundays for a lot of people. These days, however, Sundays tend to change him. Now a sought-after television host, Mr. Strahan, 45, who is currently appearing on both ABCs Good Morning America and The $100,000 Pyramid, has a chance to catch his breath on the weekends. That will soon change, however, when he returns to his third gig, Fox N.F.L. Sunday, in September. Mr. Strahan lives in a townhouse on the Upper West Side.

title: When Terror Came to Barcelona
description: It was painful, conspicuous and easy: the sort of target terrorists are always looking for. Las Ramblas of Barcelona, Spain, where two men crashed a van Thursday into unsuspecting bystanders, killing at least 13 people and wounding more than 100, is a wide, unprotected, mile-long pedestrian artery. It stretches from the busy urban center to the old seaport.

title: Mother of Woman Killed in Charlottesville Says She Will Not Speak to Trump
description: The mother of the woman who was run down by a car during violent clashes in Charlottesville, Va., said Friday that after seeing President Trumps comments equating white supremacist protesters with those demonstrating against them, she does not wish to speak with him.

title: What Robert E. Lee Wrote to The Times About Slavery in 1858
description: One day in January, a few years before the Civil War, Robert E. Lee wrote to The New York Times, seeking a correction.

title: How to Take Care of Your Clothes
description: Buying clothes built to last is one thing  but theres a lot you can do to make them endure. Here are the experts tips for wearing, storing and even cleaning your clothes correctly to prolong the life of your favorite items.

title: Eagles Chris Long Joins Malcolm Jenkins as N.F.L. Anthem Protests Continue
description: If you thought the dispute over N.F.L. players protesting during the national anthem ended last season, think again.

title: George Guidall Reads Gunslinger
description: His rich baritone has narrated plenty of Stephen King.

title: 16 Members of White House Arts Committee Resign to Protest Trump
description: All 16 of the prominent artists, authors, performers and architects on the Presidents Committee on the Arts and the Humanities resigned on Friday, the latest group to protest Donald J. Trumps defense of white nationalists after the violent demonstrations in Charlottesville, Va.

title: As Trump Offers Neo-Nazis Muted Criticism, Netanyahu Is Largely Silent
description: JERUSALEM  The front-page headline in Yedioth Ahronoth, a popular Hebrew newspaper, above a large photograph of President Trump, summed up the feelings of many Israelis in one word: Shame.

title: Is It Fact or Fiction? Only Matt LeBlanc Knows
description: There was a surreal decade, starting in 1994, when fans confused Matt LeBlanc with his Friends alter ego, Joey Tribbiani: a flailing actor with voracious appetites who was also kind of dumb.

title: Its the Golden Age of TV. And Writers Are Reaping the Rewards and Paying the Toll.
description: LOS ANGELES  Kirk A. Moores sleeping pattern had landed him in the hospital.

title: A Pianist With Modern Flair Takes Over the Salzburg Festival
description: SALZBURG, Austria  The last time Markus Hinterhuser worked with the South African artist William Kentridge and the German baritone Matthias Goerne, he was the accompanist  bringing his intense, sensitive piano playing to their multimedia production of Schuberts Winterreise song cycle, which won wide praise and went on to tour the world.

title: The Real Opioid Emergency
description: Every Friday evening, with sadness and with pride, I make a 90-minute trek from Columbia University to Sing Sing Correctional Facility to teach a drugs and behavior course. My students, who are bright and predominantly black, enthusiastically engage with the curriculum, not least because some of them have a personal stake in the subject. Several are serving time for a drug-related offense, as are hundreds of thousands of other Americans.

title: Finding Your iPad Backup Files
description: Q. I prefer to keep my backups on the ground and out of the cloud, but where does my iPad backup file live on the computer when I back it up with iTunes?

title: George Guidall Reads Crime and Punishment
description: His rich baritone has narrated many audiobooks.

title: Taking Photos Wont Take You Out of the Moment, Study Suggests
description: On Monday, I will be one of millions watching the moon punch a hole in the sun during the Great American Eclipse of 2017. In preparation, Ive been thinking about how I want to spend my roughly two minutes of totality, when day surrenders, briefly, to coronal night. Should I try to capture my experience with photos? Or should I soak in the moment as deeply as I can?

title: Evidence of a Toxic Environment for Women in Economics
description: A pathbreaking new study of online conversations among economists describes and quantifies a workplace culture that appears to amount to outright hostility toward women in parts of the economics profession.

title: Money, Murder and a Missing Heir in a Thriller Set in Greece
description: THE DESTROYERSBy Christopher Bollen485 pp. Harper/HarperCollins Publishers. $27.99.

title: Knife-Wielding Man Kills 2 in Rampage in Finland
description: A man stabbed two people to death Friday and injured half a dozen others in Turku, in western Finland, before he was shot and apprehended, the police there said.

title: The Appointment Ends. Now the Patient Is Listening.
description: The next time you see your cardiologist or internist, what would happen if you took out your smartphone or a digital recorder and said youd like to record your appointment?

title: Confederate Statues Are the Easy Part
description: As a son of the South, Im glad to see folks finally getting their act together on the hundreds of Confederate monuments spread around the region  folks like the Republican governor of Tennessee, Bill Haslam, who recently endorsed removing a bust of Nathan Bedford Forrest from the state Capitol. Thats low-hanging fruit; Forrest was a Confederate monster who massacred black soldiers and later helped found the Klan. Still, its a start.

title: When Selling Out Brings Cash but Not Happiness
description: RIVER UNDER THE ROAD By Scott Spencer366 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $27.99.

title: A Science Writer Embraces Buddhism as a Path to Enlightenment
description: OMS LAW: To the extent that Buddhism encourages its practitioners to cast aside the self on their way to enlightenment, it can seem like a fools errand. The self isnt so easy to shed, as Buckaroo Bonzai noted: No matter where you go, there you are. But that doesnt mean theres no wisdom to be found in the effort. The journalist Robert Wright  a practicing Buddhist who often explores the intersection of science and religion, as in his 2009 best seller The Evolution of God  makes the case for a Zen lifestyle in his latest book, Why Buddhism Is True, new at No. 4 in hardcover nonfiction.

title: C.E.O.s Revolted Against Trump. Now Comes the Hard Part.
description: New Haven  This week the American business community did something virtually unprecedented in its history: It shunned the call to national service by the commander in chief. In the wake of President Trumps horrifying, un-American equivalence of neo-Nazi storm troopers with the peaceful counter-demonstrators at their weekend rally in Charlottesville, Va., first one, then another, then a flood of chief executives quit his business councils. Now they need to do more.

title: Notes From the Book Review Archives
description: On Page 17 of this weeks issue, Nicholas Dames reviews a novel that takes as its inspiration the accidental death of the French literary theorist Roland Barthes. Thirty-five years ago, Edmund White wrote in the Book Review about Barthess literary legacy.

title: The Week When President Trump Resigned
description: As the worst week in a cursed presidency wound down, I spotted more and more forecasts that Donald Trump would resign, including from Tony Schwartz, who wrote The Art of the Deal for Trump and presumably understands his tortured psyche.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

title: Romney Tells Trump to Apologize for Causing Racists to Rejoice
description: BRIDGEWATER, N.J.  Mitt Romney, the Republican presidential nominee in 2012, has excoriated President Trump for his equivocating response to the violence in Charlottesville, Va., and urged him to apologize or risk subjecting the country to an unraveling of our national fabric.

title: Dolly Parton on Her TV Movies Emmy Nomination and Playing the Town Tramp
description: For Dolly Parton, the Emmy nomination for NBCs Christmas of Many Colors: Circle of Love, was totally unanticipated. Nominated in the TV movie category alongside stories about Sherlock Holmes, Bernie Madoff, futuristic euthanasia and the ethics of cancer research  the sequel to her 2015 TV movie is definitely the brightest story in the bunch.

title: The War Between the North and South
description: Lesson 1: History repeats itself.

title: WilldaBeast, and Other Forces to Be Reckoned With
description: POMONA, Calif.  On a Tuesday morning last month, hundreds of dancers gathered outside the Fairplex Conference Center here, waiting for the doors to open. Though they would spend the next five days dancing, some were getting a head start, freestyling on the sidewalk as people crowded around to watch. As one tossed off pirouettes, another edged into the circle, etching zigzags into the pavement with the soles of her yellow sneakers. There was no time to waste in being seen.

title: Infosys Chief Quits After Battle With Founders
description: NEW DELHI  India Inc. suffered a new blow on Friday when the chief executive of one of the countrys leading technology outsourcing companies suddenly resigned, a surprise move he attributed to a continuous drumbeat of distractions and negativity.

title: A Chinese Poets Unusual Path From Isolated Farm Life to Celebrity
description: HENGDIAN, China  The woman who has become one of Chinas most-read poets  even hailed as its Emily Dickinson  spent most of her 41 years in a brick farmhouse tucked away behind trees and surrounded by wheat fields.

title: Updating DNAs Life Story
description: It is incredible enough that anyone ever discovered the structure of DNA. (James D. Watson, Francis Crick and Maurice Wilkins were awarded the Nobel Prize in 1962 for their research on the subject.) But the progress that has since been made in sequencing and editing our genetic building blocks is perhaps even more dizzying.

title: An Adorable Cat. A Grand Slam. A Kerfuffle in St. Louis.
description: A sweet story about a grand slam and a cute cat who seemed to inspire it has somehow turned sour in St. Louis. The ownership of the animal is in dispute, and the Cardinals and a local shelter have exchanged, well, catty comments on social media.

title: Want to Make Creamed Corn Into a Meal? Add Shrimp
description: Creamed corn doesnt need any help.

title: Review: Live Naked Boys, and a Modern Marriage, in Afterglow
description: When someone says I love you for the first time, it usually marks a hopeful beginning. For Darius and Josh, its a harbinger of doom. The men have been friends with benefits for a little while, until Josh blurts out those three little words and changes everything  because he is married to someone else.

title: Trump Aside, Artists and Preservationists Debate the Rush to Topple Statues
description: Mark Bradford, the renowned Los Angeles artist, says Confederate statues should not be removed unless they are replaced by educational plaques that explain why they were taken away.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York and New Jersey:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties include a three-bedroom in Easton, Conn., and a six-bedroom in Ardsley, N.Y.

description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are on the Upper East Side, in Chelsea, and in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: How To | Make a Gunpowder Painting
description: From sketch to explosion, a close look at the artist Cai Guo-Qiang's process.

title: An Architect and an Artist Walk Into a Barn
description: The hourlong train ride from New York City to Morris County, N.J., cuts through the dreary industrial swamp of the Meadowlands, goes past the concrete caverns of Newark and edges along leafy college towns, before finally ending in Morristown, the county seat, a Revolutionary War stronghold and the former site of the curiously named Fort Nonsense, now a nondescript village full of hulking suburban houses. (In an episode of the final season of The Sopranos, Morristown is where Tony Soprano dreams he goes to die, just before waking from a gunshot-induced coma.) A 30-minute drive from Morristown is Chester, a tiny, bucolic community of horse farms, where families of deer amble down narrow roads and rolling hills loom hazily in the distant skyline. There, at the end of a dirt path, is a sight so unexpected that it feels as if it had descended from another world, quietly and without explanation: the country home of the artist Cai Guo-Qiang, designed by his friend Frank Gehry.

title: Things That Cannot Stay
description: In Ts Fall Womens issue, we celebrate the beauty of impermanence.

title: The Beauty of Impermanence
description: In celebration of the melancholy of things that cannot stay: the sweet ache of summers end; an immaculate dessert soon to be devoured; fashion that hints at natures frailty, straddles seasons and unravels before our very eyes.

title: Solid-Gold Toilet to Be Removed From Guggenheim in September
description: America is over. Or at least it will be on Sept. 15, when the exhibition of that name closes at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum after a one-year run.

title: Ts Womens Fashion Issue: Editors Letter
description: In the natural world, spring is the season of renewal. But in fashion  an unnatural world, though one equally transformative, and one that also runs on its own cycle of birth and death, birth and death  fall is the most fecund time of year. And not just in the fashion world, but in virtually every other creative world as well: art, theater, film, books. For these few months, we are either the watchers or the watched, and by the time the seasons finished, we are drunk with looking, with being challenged to see anew. A successful season in the culture is one that leaves you feeling one part giddy and one part uncomfortable  Is this what a dress looks like now? Is this what a novel should say and do? Is this art, or is it not?

title: Does a Buildings Age Affect the Rent?
description: Just as a spate of new housing units  comes to market in New York City  the newborn sheen and amenities accompanied by premium rents  a study by the website RentHop offers a look at the relationship between a buildings age and the rents charged.

title: The Allure of Argentinas Bubbling Cheese
description: Bubbling melted cheese is hard to resist, whether its French fondue swirled around cubes of bread, Swiss raclette spread on hot boiled potatoes, or Tex-Mex queso fundido, served with thick tortilla chips. On my first trip to Argentina, I encountered a South American version.

title: Stephen Bannon Out at the White House After Turbulent Run
description: BRIDGEWATER, N.J.  Stephen K. Bannon, the embattled chief strategist who helped President Trump win the 2016 election by embracing their shared nationalist impulses, departed the White House on Friday after a turbulent tenure shaping the fiery populism of the presidents first seven months in office.

title: Flow of Migrants to Italy Slows, but Nobody Knows Why
description: LONDON  The main route to Europe is experiencing one of its longest lulls since the migration crisis began in 2014.

title: The Emoji Movie
description: To the Editor:

title: Trump Moves to Impede Consumer Lawsuits Against Nursing Homes
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration is pushing to scrap a rule that would have made it easier for nursing home residents to sue nursing homes for injuries caused by substandard care, abuse or neglect, bringing its campaign to relax federal regulations to the delicate business of care for older Americans.

title: The Terror in Spain
description: To the Editor:

title: Hard-Won Advice in Books on Aging and Elder Care
description: Longevity is generally better than its alternative. But when the body or especially the mind wears out, caring for yourself or finding someone else to do it for you can impoverish you in short order.

title: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
description: Sand and waves provide the backdrop for this free summer series, which returns at 6 p.m. on Saturday with a pair of new works. At Night is a duet created in darkness by Jodi Melnick and Jon Kinzel, two mesmerizing movers allowing their solo dance practices to intersect. Also on the program is Fun Young God, created by an anonymous choreographer, in which Pierre Guilbault and Cori Kresge replicate the movements of rock and pop stars including Mick Jagger and Beyonc, meshing those demeanors with their own to comment on celebrity, youth and faith. SIOBHAN BURKE

title: How Jinder Mahal, an Indian WWE Star, Is Turning Up the Heat
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  You people have nothing to celebrate, Jinder Mahal shouted into a microphone on Tuesday night at the Dunkin Donuts Center. The current World Wrestling Entertainment champion was dressed in a black turban and a gray suit with his giant belt slung over his shoulder. He twisted his face into a deep, angry grimace, and continued, But for my people, today marks Independence Day of the greatest nation on earth: the great nation of India!

title: A $2,500 Tax Credit for Students Has a Few Pitfalls
description: Families paying college tuition are often relieved that they can claim education credits on their income tax returns, which helps ease the financial burden of higher learning.

title: An Antebellum Hero, but to Whom?
description: The scenes of statues of Confederate generals being toppled from their perches or surrounded by torch-wielding white supremacists shouting racist and anti-Semitic slogans reminded Diane Collier of another monument that has roiled residents in East Harlem. On Fifth Avenue and East 103rd Street, across from the New York Academy of Medicine, is an imposing monument to Dr. J. Marion Sims, whose fame as the father of modern gynecology came at the expense of enslaved black women on whom he operated without anesthesia or informed consent.

title: Kesha and Taylor Swift Find New Voices
description: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

title: Columbus, Ind., Renews Its Big Design Legacy
description: COLUMBUS, Ind.  Getting around this city, located 45 minutes south of Indianapolis, can take a bit longer than expected. Its not large, with 46,000 people, but the Midwestern friendliness dictates a certain pace.

title: Crusader Who Saved Elephants From Poachers Is Shot Dead in Tanzania
description: Wayne Lotter, a wildlife conservationist from South Africa, was fatally shot this week in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, where he had worked to stop poaching and the illegal ivory trade, the organization he helped found said.

title: Whither Trumpism?
description: Everyone seems to be reporting that Steve Bannon is out. I have no insights about the palace intrigue; and anyone who thinks Trump will become presidential now is an idiot. In particular, I very much doubt that the influence of white supremacists and neo-Nazis will wane.

title: Is Trump a Real New Yorker?
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking Reset, Trump Dines With Some of His Biggest Donors
description: BRIDGEWATER, N.J.  President Trump dined on Thursday night at his Bedminster golf club with a handful of the rights most generous donors, as he tried to build support for his hobbled legislative agenda amid mounting criticism from within his own party, three people briefed on the dinner said.

title: Live Event: Big City Book Club at the Billie Holiday Theatre
description: Welcome to Times Insider Events  live programming for Times Insiders and their guests. Times Insider offers behind-the-scenes insights into news, features and opinion at The New York Times.

title: What I Love | Nelson DeMille
description: The best-selling novelist lives with his wife, Sandy, and their son, James, in a Tudor house in Garden City, N.Y.

title: A Tudor Castle for Nelson DeMille
description: What would a celebrity profile be without some rich biographical detail? So heres a little something to get the ball rolling: Nelson DeMilles father, Huron, was a contractor.

title: We Cant Just Pull Out Our Gun: Border Patrol Alters Training
description: ARTESIA, N.M.  In a classroom on the campus of the Border Patrol Academy here at the Federal Law Enforcement Training Center, Andrew Andrade, an instructor, is guiding a group of future Border Patrol agents through an intensive Spanish language-training course.

title: Born in Grief, New Group Helps Families of Slain Officers
description: It began at the wake for Rafael Ramos, one of two New York City police officers  murdered in their patrol car in Brooklyn in 2014: Officers from Chicago were talking to a few from New York about a charity they had begun for the survivors of colleagues killed.

title: Most of the People in This White House Swearing-In Photo Have Left
description: Some resigned, others were forced out or fired.

title: What Were Reading
description: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What Were Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

title: The Playlist: Justin Bieber Pleads on the Dance Floor and 9 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. This week, Julien Baker returns with a beautifully haunting song, Miley Cyrus drops the title track from her new album and Radiator Hospital release a dreamy indie-rock tune.

title: Save Your Sanity. Downgrade Your Life.
description: Recently, I gave up my electric toothbrush. There was nothing wrong with it. It was, in fact, an upscale model, and when I used it, I felt certain my teeth were not only getting cleaner and whiter but also perhaps even better aligned. And yet, my old manual toothbrush, poking out of a mug on the vanity, beckoned. One night, as I wearily approached the sink, I realized the last thing I wanted to experience was the frantic whir of yet another spinning gizmo. I plucked out the old-timey toothbrush instead, and never looked back.

title: William Ackman Needs Sharper Ideas in ADP Quest
description: William A. Ackman needs sharper ideas guys on his ADP payroll.

title: Sierra Leone Mudslides Unlikely to Leave Survivors, Rescuers Say
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Rescuers in Sierra Leones capital said on Friday that it was unlikely any of the hundreds of people buried in mudslides this week were still alive, after torrential rains that hit the countrys capital left more than 400 people dead.

title: Bleak, Gentle and Sweet: This Weeks 8 Best Classical Music Moments on YouTube
description: In addition to writing reviews, features and news during the week, our critics and reporters offer a glimpse into the research weve done on YouTube. Read the rest of our classical music coverage here.

title: Squabbles Over the Family Summer Home? Dont Hire a Lawyer Just Yet
description: For many people, summer means time for family vacations at the beach, on a lake or in the mountains.

title: Cider Moves Beyond the Apple
description: OVID, N.Y.  John Reynolds had just finished feeding his pigs, and was now pouring his funky, eccentric ciders into glasses inside the worn wooden barn that serves as the fermentation room, tasting room and shop for his Blackduck Cidery.

title: Mourning and Tourism Come Together at Ground Zero
description: Slur the words just right, and it becomes hard to tell the difference between terrorism and tourism. Just months after Sept. 11, 2001, when nearly 3,000 people died in attacks on the World Trade Center, one of the first reactions of New Yorkers and visitors to the city was to flock to the site. The event defied comprehension; proximity, perhaps, offered a path to understanding.

title: Roy Lunn, Pioneering Engineer of Celebrated Cars, Dies at 92
description: Roy Lunn, a British-born engineering virtuoso whose design teams spawned celebrated American cars like Fords muscular GT40 and the original Mustang and paved the way for the rise of the S.U.V., died on Aug. 5 in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 92.

title: Venezuelas New, Powerful Assembly Takes Over Legislatures Duties
description: Venezuelas new Constituent Assembly granted itself wide powers to write and pass legislation on Friday, a move that essentially nullifies the opposition-led legislature and puts President Nicols Maduros party firmly in control of the country.

title: Edward Allcard, Solo Sailor on the High Seas, Dies at 102
description: Edward Allcard, who was said to be the first person to sail both ways across the Atlantic Ocean single-handedly  save for a stretch with a young woman who stowed away on his return home to England  died on July 28 in Andorra, a principality in the Pyrenees Mountains, where he lived. He was 102.

title: Aging Parents With Lots of Stuff, and Children Who Dont Want It
description: Mothers and daughters talk about all kinds of things. But there is one conversation Susan Beauregard, 49, of Hampton, Conn., is reluctant to have with her 89-year-old mother, Anita Shear: What to do  eventually  with Mrs. Shears beloved set of Lenox china?

title: Restoring the Furniture at the St. Regis
description: Jose Gabriel Perez, 51, is an upholsterer at the St. Regis New York in Manhattan

title: Revived After Mosul, Iraqi Forces Prepare to Battle ISIS in Tal Afar
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs security forces, which suffered huge casualties in the nine-month-long slog to take back the city of Mosul, are replenished enough to begin the fight for the Islamic State stronghold of Tal Afar  one of the last urban areas held in Iraq by the militant extremist Sunni group, American defense officials said Friday.

title: In Terror Attacks in Spain, a Global Community of Victims
description: LONDON  A Belgian mother was killed while on holiday with her husband and two young sons. So was an Italian father, as he held the hand of his 5-year-old son.

title: Red Sox Renew Push to Rename Yawkey Way Amid Monument Debate
description: BOSTON  A dark blue banner with red letters reads Welcome to Yawkey Way, and on Friday morning it still hung over a street lined on one side by shops selling Boston Red Sox gear and souvenirs, and on the other by the brick facade of the teams century-old home, Fenway Park.

title: Hate That Doesnt Hide
description: Angry white men holding tiki torches and shouting their throats raw chanting blood and soil, spittle hanging from their lips. Angry white men, arms outstretched in the Nazi salute. Angry white men playing soldier, heavily armed in public. Nazi flags, Confederate flags, American flags, Make America Great Again hats. Bodies clashing. A slate-gray car barreling into people standing up to racism. Bodies flying.

title: The Damage Done by Stephen Bannon
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Letter: Stage Lights, Sunlight and Opening Shots
description: Jesse Green, who became The Timess co-chief theater critic in May, recently made his first trip to the Stratford Festival. He was impressed by one of the few remaining repertory theater companies in North America, describing his visit to Stratford, Ontario, as a bucket-list chance.

title: Analyzing Freud
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: Jo Walker-Meador, 93, Dies; Raised Country Musics Profile
description: Jo Walker-Meador, who joined the Country Music Association when it was a tiny start-up in the late 1950s and, as its longtime executive director, transformed it into a powerhouse in the music industry, died on Tuesday in Nashville. She was 93.

title: Bound for Burning Man, but First, the Costume
description: Recently, the mannequins in the window of the Manhattan vintage shop Reminiscence traded their summer outfits for Sgt.-Pepper-style military coats with tassels and epaulettes, harem pants, platform boots, headdresses, goggles, and, perhaps most mystifyingly, bulky faux fur coats.

title: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
description: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Exit Steve Bannon
description: It would be nice to think the departure of Steve Bannon, chief strategist in a strategy-free White House, signals that President Trump is oh-so-gradually closing the door on white nationalist sentiments. But that would require forgetting that Mr. Trump fostered birther lies and racist memes long before he worked with Mr. Bannon, who saw in him a vessel for a more developed nativist agenda.

title: User Generated Content Terms of Service
description: Before sharing your photo, please review our Terms of Service for User Generated Content.

title: Dutch Utility Bets Its Future on an Unusual Strategy: Selling Less Power
description: AMSTERDAM  When Eneco, a major Dutch utility, tested a promising energy monitor in several dozen homes, things could not have gone much worse. The company making the devices failed to deliver enough of them, and some of those provided did not work.

title: Steve Bannon, Back on the Outside, Prepares His Enemies List
description: Stephen K. Bannon has always been more comfortable when he was trying to tear down institutions  not work inside them.

title: Carl Icahn Quits as a Special Adviser to President Trump
description: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor, is no longer advising President Trump on regulatory matters.

title: Should You Trust Climate Science? Maybe the Eclipse Is a Clue
description: Eclipse mania will peak on Monday, when millions of Americans will upend their lives in response to a scientific prediction.

title: Told to Go Back to Guatemala, She Sought Sanctuary Instead
description: On Thursday, instead of showing up at her immigration check-in with a nonstop ticket to Guatemala, as she had been told to do, Amanda Morales Guerra, 33, walked into Holyrood Episcopal Church-Iglesia Santa Cruz in Washington Heights. She did not know when she could emerge again.

title: Stephen Bannon, Mitt Romney, Barcelona: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Judge Says Waymo Can Tell Jurors That Uber Withheld Evidence
description: In a strongly worded ruling on Thursday, a federal judge presiding over an intellectual property fight between Uber and Waymo, the self-driving car unit spun out of Google, said jurors in a coming trial may be told that Uber has been withholding key evidence.

title: City Will Move Sidelined Teachers From Limbo to Classrooms
description: For a dozen years, hundreds of New York City teachers have been paid despite not having permanent jobs, sidelined in most cases because of disciplinary problems or bad teaching records or because they had worked in poorly performing schools that were closed or where enrollment declined.

title: Steve Bannon Is Overrated
description: The White House chief strategist Stephen K. Bannons departure was widely applauded, and not only by the Washington establishment Mr. Bannon has spent a career excoriating. After the news broke, traders at the New York Stock Exchange literally cheered, according to a CNBC report.

title: Corrections: August 19, 2017
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Daily Special Edition: The Fall of Steve Bannon
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: Trump Officials Renew Effort to Expand Use of Prison at Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration is making a fresh attempt at drafting an executive order on handling terrorism detainees, reviving a struggle to navigate legal and geopolitical obstacles to expand use of the Guantnamo Bay wartime prison, according to officials familiar with internal deliberations.

title: A Baseball Manager Retires Again, Knowing It Rarely Sticks
description: ST. PAUL  Two questions stumped J. D. Droddy, baseballs leading Renaissance man.

title: E.P.A. Promised a New Day for the Agriculture Industry, Documents Reveal
description: WASHINGTON  In the weeks before the Environmental Protection Agency decided to reject its own scientists advice to ban a potentially harmful pesticide, Scott Pruitt, the agencys head, promised farming industry executives who wanted to keep using the pesticide that it is a new day, and a new future, and that he was listening to their pleas.

title: In Afghanistan, a Destructive Game of Thrones
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The senior security official in northeastern Takhar Province was deferential when he telephoned Commander Bashir Qanet. After all, he was talking to one of the most powerful government supporters in the province, who has hundreds of militiamen under his command.

title: In Monument Debate, Calls for an Overdue Reckoning on Race and Southern Identity
description: EUFAULA, Ala.  The facts of Southern history, according to Brad Griffin, are beyond dispute.

title: James Murdochs Rebuke of Trump May Signal a Shift
description: At 5:55 p.m. on Thursday, James Murdoch sent an email to a list of blind-copied recipients offering a striking repudiation of President Trump and a pledge to donate $1 million to the Anti-Defamation League. He addressed the note to friends, stating in the first line that he was writing it in a personal capacity, as a concerned citizen and a father.

title: In Charlottesville, Some Say Statue Debate Obscures a Deep Racial Split
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  One of the joys of growing up, for Deborah Bell-Burks, was sitting on the counter of the general store that her family owned on Main Street, helping her mother bag items and count change. A bicycle ride through the neighborhood would take her past a grocery, a barbershop and a cobblers shop. And most of the people she would see, well-off business owners and customers alike, were black like her, offering an early lesson in what she could become.

title: Friday Night Music: Warpaint, Elephants
description: Still shocked to discover how much I get out of this band, which I discovered so far into their career. (20-something relative: *You* like *Warpaint*?) Something deep about them  and this performance is one of the ones that get me most.

title: Thomas Yawkey, the Red Sox Owner Who Resisted Integration
description: BOSTON  White vertical lines frame the first column of out-of-town scores on the famous left-field wall at Fenway Park. For decades, a series of dots and dashes have been embedded within those lines, a cryptic memorial hiding in plain sight.

title: Discovering the Limitations of Statues
description: I believe I have an answer to our statue problem.

title: President Jabberwock and the Jewish Right
description: In the department of small violins, consider the moral embarrassment, after Charlottesville, Va., of right-of-center Jews who voted for Donald Trump in the election and remained  at least until last week  broadly supportive of his presidency.

title: It Covers Bridges
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Its Saturday, and you hopefully now know what that means: There will be few gimmes, and even the fill-in-the-blanks clues will not be obvious. Theres a lot of wide open white space here and that can be intimidating, but that doesnt mean you should back away from a good challenge.

title: Whose War Was It?
description: Perhaps no one came out of the Vietnam War with a reputation as tarnished as the Army of the Republic of Vietnam. Since well before the war ended, ARVN soldiers were made an easy and ready scapegoat for Americas losses, a stereotype that found its way into academia and popular culture. Were told they were incompetent cowards who often shirked their duties, leaving the hard work to the Americans.

title: Nigel Hayes, an Outspoken Star With Wisconsin, Signs With the Knicks
description: The Knicks signed three free agents Friday, including Nigel Hayes, a forward from Wisconsin who helped lead the Badgers to two Final Fours and who became recognized later in his college career for his outspokenness in addressing social issues.

title: Charlottesville Will Move On
description: Charlottesville, Va.  Last weekend several thousand alt-right activists and white supremacists came to my city, ostensibly to protest our plan to move a statue of Robert E. Lee from Emancipation Park. We knew they were coming, but like the rest of the world, we were shocked by the level of bigotry and violence on display, culminating in the terrorist attack that killed one counterprotester, Heather Heyer.

title: The Gunmen at Free Speech Rallies
description: Even before violence erupted in Charlottesville, Va., last weekend, city residents and the police anxiously watched the arrival of self-styled militias  swaggering gangs of armed civilians in combat fatigues  standing guard over the protest by white supremacists and other racist agitators against the removal of a Confederate statue.

title: Protesters Flood Streets, and Trump Offers a Measure of Praise
description: BOSTON  Tens of thousands of demonstrators, emboldened and unnerved by the eruption of fatal violence in Virginia last weekend, surged into the nations streets and parks on Saturday to denounce racism, white supremacy and Nazism.

title: After the Terror in Barcelona
description: There are always many questions after a terrorist attack, some never to be answered. Why a promenade in Barcelona and the seaside town of Cambrils? Why now? Were the terrorists compelled to act hastily after a more insidious plot collapsed when a house believed to be their bomb factory in a nearby town exploded prematurely on Wednesday?

title: Save New York Citys Fashion Factories
description: Manufacturing in New York Citys garment district is in jeopardy of unraveling at its seams. The citys Economic Development Corporation may soon begin the certification process to lift the zoning laws that have protected fashion and apparel businesses in these few blocks in Midtown Manhattan for decades.

title: Quotation of the Day: Bannon, Key Voice of Populist Right, Exits White House
description: Im going to nominate this White House for a Tony Award for the most drama, not the best drama but the most drama.

title: In a Post-Charlottesville Nation, Everything Feels Different and the Same
description: For years, I passed by the old Confederate battle flag sticker. It was affixed to a traffic sign on a lonesome four-lane rural road in Haralson County, Ga., the proud and hardscrabble patch of the rural South where my wife was raised.

title: M.T.A. to Modify Subway Station Design Resembling Confederate Flag
description: To busy New Yorkers walking briskly by, the mosaic inside a Times Square subway station might look like a Confederate flag.

title: As Bullpen Stumbles, Yankees Fall to Five Games Back of Red Sox
description: BOSTON  The Yankees gold-plated bullpen, the one with more closers than Manager Joe Girardi can shake a binder at, imploded at the most inopportune time.

title: Mets Skid Reaches Five Games in Loss to Marlins
description: Amed Rosario notched a multihit game at Citi Field for the first time, but the rest of the Mets struggled to piece together any semblance of offense as they fell to the Miami Marlins, 3-1, on Friday night for a fifth straight loss.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Beatriz at Dinner and Nocturnal Animals
description: Beatriz at Dinner, starring Salma Hayek as a holistic healer riled up by a boor, comes to iTunes. And Nocturnal Animals, with Amy Adams as a gallery owner uncertain of where real life ends and art begins, arrives on HBO.

title: The Fight for the White Race: What Some of the Charlottesville Rally Participants Stand For
description: Recent statements from participants at the protests.

title: Mets Trade Curtis Granderson to the Dodgers
description: When Curtis Granderson signed with the Mets before the 2014 season, the team was bereft of pillars. For the Mets official yearbook that year, Granderson and David Wright were alone on the cover, sitting on a staircase, the only two stars in a lineup in the middle of a rebuild.

title: Kissimmee Police Shooting Leaves Two Officers Dead
description: Two police officers have died after being shot Friday night in Kissimmee, Fla., in what the police chief said may have been an ambush while they were responding to a call complaining of suspicious activity on the citys north side.

title: Three Muslim Refugees at a Jewish Day Camp
description: Sandra, Lima and Reem find confidence in an unlikely place.

title: Let Those Communities Reflect on Why Those Statues Were Erected
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

title: 52 Places to Go: Drinking in Northwest Puerto Rico
description: Travel along the coast of Northwest Puerto Rico, where vendors and bartenders use machetes, ice picks and delicate herbs to create their drinks.

title: The Moral Voice of Corporate America
description: The nation has split into political tribes. The culture wars are back, waged over transgender rights and immigration. White nationalists are on the march.

title: How to Get Away With Murder in Small-Town India
description: PEEPLI KHERA, India  On my last week in India, I went to say goodbye to Jahiruddin Mewati, the chief of a small village where I had made a dozen or so reporting trips.

title: Dear Sugars: How to Talk About Our Partners Bodies
description: Ive been madly in love my boyfriend for over two years, but Im thinking of backing out of the relationship because hes gained weight and Im no longer physically attracted to him. Ive lost perspective. Please tell me what you think. Thats a question the Sugars answer in this weeks episode from a writer who calls herself Scared to Choose Wrong.

title: Sunday Best in Harlem and Brooklyn
description: Andre Wagners father was a minister in Omaha, so church on Sunday was an all-day affair.  The day would start when his grandfather picked up the family in what he called his Sunday van. Andre sang in the choir, went to Sunday school and usually ended up having a meal at the home of another preacher. You were spending time with people from church and being part of the community, he said.

title: 20 Years After Dianas Death, a Happier Ending Imagined
description: In a new novel called Imagining Diana, readers find Princess Diana having lunch in Midtown Manhattan at Michaels, nodding hello to Barbara Walters on her way in, dressed in an Oscar de la Renta suit, sitting at Table 1, ordering the gravlax.

title: Who Needs the Hamptons When You Have the Parker House?
description: SEA GIRT, N.J.  I have a time share with the dance floor  I own the front and center, Chris Fedroff, 27, said to his friend in the basement level of the Parker House, a green and white Victorian manse here that is by day a sedate lunch spot, by night a throbbing epicenter of summer parties.

title: Spain Looking for Moroccan Man in Barcelona Attack Investigation
description: BARCELONA, Spain  The Spanish authorities said on Saturday that they were hunting for a 22-year-old Moroccan-born man who they now suspect was the driver of the van that plowed through central Barcelona this past week, in the countrys worst terrorist attack in more than a decade.

title: The Stock Market Has Been Magical. It Cant Last.
description: Some things just cant last. The nearly magical stock market that has persisted so valiantly this year is one of them.

title: Fatal Knife Attack in Finland Is Investigated as Terrorism
description: STOCKHOLM  A knife attack that killed two people and wounded eight others in southwestern Finland is being investigated as a terrorist attack apparently aimed at women, Finlands National Bureau of Investigation said on Saturday.

title: Russian Knife Attacker Stabs and Wounds at Least 7 in Siberia
description: MOSCOW  A man wielding a knife attacked and wounded seven people on the central street in the Siberian town of Surgut on Saturday, local news reports and Russian investigators said.

title: Donald and Melania Trump to Skip Kennedy Center Honors
description: WASHINGTON  The White House announced early Saturday that President Trump and the first lady, Melania Trump, would not participate in this years Kennedy Center Honors, to allow the honorees to celebrate without any political distraction.

title: Farhads and Mikes Week in Tech: Apples Big Media Bet and More Uber Drama
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: Landslide in Congo Kills Dozens, Official Says
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  A landslide after heavy rains in an eastern area of the Democratic Republic of Congo has killed dozens of people, and possibly as many as 200, according to an estimate of the number of households buried by tons of mud, an official said Saturday.

title: Turning Over a New Leaf, and Finding Love
description: Diana Marie Hardeman and Naveen Selvadurai were married Aug. 19 at Casa Romantica Cultural Center and Gardens in San Clemente, Calif. Om Malik, a minister with American Marriage ministries and a friend of the couple, officiated.

title: Act 4: The Wedding Scene
description: Madhuri Shekar and Seamus Robert Sullivan were married Aug. 19. Megan E. Kelly, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister to preside at the event, officiated at the Manufacturers Golf and Country Club in Fort Washington, Pa. Last month, the couple had a traditional Tamil Hindu wedding ceremony in Chennai, India.

title: Neighbor Complains Bamboo Is Taking Over
description: Q. Soon after we moved into our home in Bayside, Queens, 13 years ago, we planted bamboo in our backyard. The plants have grown quite large. We like how they look and the shade and privacy they provide. Recently, a neighbor demanded that we remove the bamboo, claiming that, as an invasive species, it is illegal to grow. He said the roots are invading his yard. We told him he could cut or destroy any roots or plants on his property, but that we would not remove bamboo from our yard. He has threatened to sue us. Must we remove the bamboo to avoid a lawsuit?

title: Charlottesville and Trumps Response Reshape Virginia Gubernatorial Race
description: FALLS CHURCH, Va.  The bloody white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Va., has thrust race and history to the forefront of this years campaign for governor in Virginia, a tradition-bound state whose identity has always been rooted in a past that is as proud for some residents as it is painful for others.

title: Watching Charlottesville From Jerusalem
description: In the almost 20 years since we moved our three young children from a bucolic street in West Los Angeles to a Jerusalem apartment in the rough-and-tumble Middle East, my wife and I consciously taught them that in going from the United States to Israel, we had not been fleeing anything. We had moved not from something but to something. The country in which they were born, we reminded them time and again, not only was the greatest democracy on the planet (after which Israel largely models itself) but also has been unique in Jewish history. Everywhere else, Jews had lived tenuously, doing their best to be accepted until their host community eventually tired of them. When that happened  as in England in 1290, Spain in 1492 and Germany in 1933  horror ensued.

title: What Happens to Creativity as We Age?
description: One day not long ago, Augie, a 4-year-old Gopnik grandchild, heard his grandfather wistfully say, I wish I could be a kid again. After a thoughtful pause, Augie came up with a suggestion: Grandpa should try not eating any vegetables. The logic was ingenious: Eating vegetables turns children into big strong adults, so not eating vegetables should reverse the process.

title: 1917: Maximalists Are Fomenting Fresh Trouble in Russia
description: Government Is on Alert  National Conference Is Expected to Strengthen Unity.

title: Sharing Secrets to a Successful Marriage
description: The recent State of the Unions column, Happily-Ever-After Doesnt Exist, was a vivid account from a couple about the ups and downs of their 20-year marriage. The column sparked an outpouring of comments on Facebook and Twitter. Readers shared their own experiences and opinions, along with their secrets to a successful marriage. Below are some of the highlights, edited for space.

title: Will Bannons White House Agenda Survive Without Him?
description: WASHINGTON  In his West Wing office, Stephen K. Bannon kept a chart listing trade actions  on China, steel and autos  that the Trump White House planned to roll out, week by week, through the fall. Now that Mr. Bannon, the presidents chief strategist, has been pushed out, the question is whether his agenda will be erased along with him.

title: When Self-Criticism Was an Order, These Portraits Were Revolutionary
description: BEIJING  Chinas Cultural Revolution, the decade-long campaign remembered for its fanaticism and upheaval, began in 1966 and was enforced by radicalized students who pledged to put the Communist Party ahead of self.

title: Variety: Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Another tough one today, but markedly more upbeat than the last acrostic puzzle and beautifully science-geeky, as our constructors, Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, say below. Its timely, too: Todays acrostic is all about a solar eclipse, which we North Americans will experience on Monday, Aug. 21.

title: In Serbian Refugee Center, a Little Picasso Dreams of Art and Asylum
description: BELGRADE, Serbia  In a shabby refugee center on the outskirts of Belgrade, an Afghan artist nicknamed Little Picasso spends his days sketching and dreaming while living in limbo, seemingly immune to the deepening sense of hopelessness and despair all around him.

title: With Color and Fury, Anti-American Posters Appear in North Korea
description: The language on the North Korean posters is as bombastic as the images are eye-popping and the colors blindingly bright.

title: The Benefits of Standing by the President
description: He heaped praise on Jared Kushner at a private gathering of bankers and corporate executives in December, congratulating President Trumps son-in-law on the surprise election triumph.

title: Aryana Saeed, Afghan Pop Star, Wont Let Mullahs Stop the Show
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan singer and pop star Aryana Saeed, as famous here for her curve-hugging costumes as she is for her feminist lyrics, can sell out any stadium in Afghanistan, and in many other countries as well. When it comes to her home country, though, that does not necessarily mean she can perform in them.

title: Missing Widow of Chinas Nobel Laureate, Liu Xiaobo, Surfaces in Video
description: BEIJING  The widow of Liu Xiaobo, the Chinese winner of the Nobel Peace Prize who died of cancer while under police guard last month, has resurfaced for the first time since his death in a brief online video pleading for privacy and time to recover from her grief.

title: In Indonesias Dysfunctional Prisons, Escapes Arent the Half of It
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The recent escape of four foreign inmates who tunneled their way out of Kerobokan Prison, a high-security facility on the Indonesian resort island of Bali, could have been a scene from a Hollywood movie.

title: Transgender Pakistanis Win Legal Victories, but Violence Goes On
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  Pakistans Parliament is poised to pass the nations first law recognizing transgender people as equal citizens and laying out penalties for discrimination and violence against them, a surprising victory for activists in a country with deeply conservative social views.

title: The Islamic State's Claim to Spain
description: Spain hasnt been in ISIS crosshairs as much as France and Britain, but it has been as a through-point for ISIS recruits and target of its propaganda for years.

title: 9 Eclipses, 4 Continents, Never Tired of the Spectacle
description: I booked my flight to Wyoming nearly a year ago  as soon as the airline would accept reservations. Ditto my hotel and rental car. Why wait, when untold numbers of other eclipse chasers were sure to be flocking to all points along the path of totality? Why risk missing a chance to stand once again under the shadow of the moon?

title: The 10 Best Places to Swim in the World, According to Me
description: This summer I went swimming, this summer I might have drowned

description: WASHINGTON  One lazy, sultry afternoon in 1947, two years after America helped trounce the Nazis, my father arrived at our familys modest summer house on the Severn River near the Naval Academy.

title: Is Your Sunscreen Poisoning the Ocean?
description: One of the perks of being a Californian is that Hawaii is a quick, often affordable getaway: Without the need to escape frosty weather, were free to visit during summer, when the surf lays down flat and the price of hotel rooms plummets.

title: What White Nationalism Gets Right About American History
description: My dad often gave me the advice that white nationalists are not looking to recruit people on the fringes of American culture, but rather the people who start a sentence by saying, Im not racist, but

title: The Failing Trump Presidency
description: With each day, President Trump offers fresh proof that he is failing the office that Americans entrusted to him. The rolling disaster of his presidency accelerated downhill last week with a news conference on Tuesday at which he seemed determined to sow racial strife in a nation desperate for a unifying vision.

title: Rene Rivera Goes to Cubs, Joining a Mets Exodus
description: Less than 12 hours after the Los Angeles Dodgers acquired Curtis Granderson in a trade with the Mets, the Chicago Cubs claimed one of Grandersons former teammates, Rene Rivera, off waivers before Saturdays game at Citi Field.

title: Stuart J. Thompson, Award-Winning Broadway Producer, Dies at 62
description: Stuart J. Thompson, a Tony Award-winning producer and manager of Broadway shows who brought a contemplative, low-key style to an industry known for its razzmatazz, and helped mount hits like The Book of Mormon, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 62.

title: Spain, a Leader in Foiling Attacks, Falls Victim to One Anyway
description: For more than a decade, Spain seemed immune to the steady eruptions of Islamist violence that rocked other European countries where radicalized young men, often from poor immigrant backgrounds, carried out devastating bomb, gun or vehicular attacks.

title: Fight Fanaticism With Modesty?
description: To the Editor:

title: 500 Neo-Nazis Rally in Berlin, and Meet Strong Opposition
description: More than 500 neo-Nazis took to the streets of Berlin on Saturday to observe the 30th anniversary of the death of Rudolf Hess, the onetime deputy to Hitler. Hess, once one of Hitlers designated successors, was the last survivor of the 19 German officials convicted by the International Military Tribunal at Nuremberg in 1946.

title: A Deal Breaker for Trumps Supporters? Nope. Not This Time, Either.
description: For Parson Hicks, a health care finance executive who supports President Trump, this past week has felt a little like dj vu. Mr. Trump says something. His opponents howl and then predict, with certainty, a point of no return.
