title: Found in Your Inbox
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  I have a friend who delights in posting the phrase Inbox Zero! on social media whenever he has managed to clear his inbox of emails. I have no idea what that feels like because I have never managed to achieve it, but I would imagine that its pretty satisfying.

title: Arthur Finkelstein, Innovative, Influential Conservative Strategist, Dies at 72
description: Arthur Finkelstein, a reclusive political Svengali who revolutionized campaign polling and financing and helped elect a bevy of conservative candidates, including President Ronald Reagan and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, died on Friday night in Ipswich, Mass., where he lived. He was 72.

title: Quotation of the Day: How to Get Away With Murder in India, With a Town Watching
description: Ninety-nine percent of cases are dealt with in this way. I get very angry. I am an honest person. I can show you four guys here who can rape a woman as easily as plucking the feathers off a bird, but they never get arrested.

title: Awed by Camden Yards, Rick Sutcliffe Started It All With a Shutout
description: Rick Sutcliffe knew better than to pitch in the rugged American League East. As a 35-year-old free agent in the winter before the 1992 season, coming off two seasons marred by injuries, Sutcliffe did not see himself as a Baltimore Oriole. Then he visited a construction site.

title: Yankees Hold Off Red Sox, Without Chapman Shutting the Door
description: BOSTON  No Aroldis Chapman, no problem.

title: Sale and Chapman Traveling Divergent Paths Out of Chicago
description: BOSTON  One left the North Side to return to the Bronx. The other left the South Side for a new adventure in Boston. Aroldis Chapman and Chris Sale, the most dominant closer and the most electrifying starter in Chicago, are headliners in the Yankees-Red Sox rivalry, and their fortunes help explain Bostons edge in the standings.

title: Dick Gregory, 84, Dies; Found Humor in the Civil Rights Struggle
description: Dick Gregory, the pioneering satirist who transformed cool humor into a barbed force for civil rights in the 1960s, then veered from his craft for a life devoted to protest and fasting in the name of assorted social causes, health regimens and conspiracy theories, died Saturday in Washington. He was 84.

title: Halep Closes In on Top Ranking
description: Simona Halep moved within a victory of the No. 1 ranking, needing just 54 minutes to cruise past Sloane Stephens, 6-2, 6-1, in the semifinals of the Western & Southern Open in Mason, Ohio. Halep can displace Karolina Pliskova at the top of the rankings with a victory over Garbie Muguruza on Sunday. Muguruza, the world No. 4, defeated Pliskova, the world No. 1 and defending champion, by 6-3, 6-2 in the other semifinal.

description: To counter a narrative of fear about refugees, a community in New Haven breaks bread  quite literally  with their new neighbor Zainab, an Iraqi cook.

description: BAGHDAD  A month after liberating Mosul from the Islamic State, Iraqi forces began a new offensive Sunday to retake Tal Afar, one of the last big cities in Iraq under control of the extremists.

title: Bannon, Spain, Eclipse: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories, and a look ahead.

title: Wreckage of U.S.S. Indianapolis, Lost for 72 Years, Is Found in the Pacific
description: In the 72 years since the Indianapolis, a United States Navy cruiser, sank about 12 minutes after being torpedoed by a Japanese submarine, the disaster has inspired controversy, dozens of books, a play and a famous scene in Jaws.

title: Grace Mugabe Wins Diplomatic Immunity After Assault Accusations
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  The wife of Zimbabwes president, Robert Mugabe, was whisked out of South Africa on Sunday, trailed by calls for her arrest after she was accused of beating a fashion model with an extension cord in a luxury hotel in Johannesburg.

title: Trump Settles on Afghan Strategy Expected to Raise Troop Levels
description: AMMAN, Jordan  President Trump, who has been accused by lawmakers of dragging his feet on Afghanistan, has settled on a new strategy to carry on the nearly 16-year-old conflict there, administration officials said Sunday. The move, following a detailed review, is likely to open the door to the deployment of several thousand troops.

title: As Spain Mourns, Hunt Intensifies for Van Driver in Barcelona Attack
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Spains royal family and prime minister joined numerous dignitaries and Muslim leaders on Sunday to mourn the 14 people killed in twin attacks last week, the deadliest case of terrorism in the country since 2004.

title: Steven Mnuchin Defends Trumps Reaction to Charlottesville Violence
description: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, under fire from Yale classmates and Jewish critics of President Trump, strongly defended the presidents equivocating response to the racially charged violence in Charlottesville, Va., in a written statement this weekend.

title: Encouraging Signs of Freshness at the Mostly Mozart Festival
description: Looking back, its clear that Jane Moss, the artistic director of Lincoln Center, made a smart move in appointing Louis Langre as music director of the Mostly Mozart Festival in 2002. Almost immediately, working together, they reinvigorated what had become over several decades a calcified summer venture, dominated by too many listlessly played and predictable programs of staples by Mozart and his contemporaries.

title: Young Voices on a Targeted Island: Very Lucky to Be From Guam
description: Though classes had yet to start, the John F. Kennedy High School football team took to the field to practice for the opener against Father Dueas Memorial. With Tumon Bay as their backdrop, the players warmed up beneath the August sun. Neither the threat of nuclear war nor 80 percent humidity could halt the dedication of the J.F.K. Islanders, and the same could be said for most others on this tiny Pacific island: Life goes on.

description: KERLGO, France  A dairy farmer, Jean-Pierre Le Guelvout, once kept 66 cows at a thriving estate in southern Brittany. But falling milk prices, accumulating debts, depression and worries about his health in middle age became too much to bear.

description: As Sunday afternoon rolled round, Americans who might normally dread the arrival of another Monday instead busied themselves preparing for the first total coast-to-coast solar eclipse in nearly a century.

title: Photographer Donates Thoreau-Inspired Artwork to the Morgan
description: In 1979, before he gained recognition for his photography, Abelardo Morell worked the night shift as a security guard for the Morgan Library & Museum. Now, Mr. Morell has donated a new work of art to the museum to honor its security staff. Thoreau: 40 Journals in Chronological Order will be on display at the Morgan from Tuesday through Sept. 10. as part of This Ever New Self: Thoreau and His Journal, which traces Henry David Thoreaus life through notebooks and other artifacts. (He is a model of resistance in a rived, self-destructive, demagogic political moment, Holland Cotter wrote in a notebook on the exhibit.)

description: President Trumps Thursday morning tweet lamenting that the removal of Confederate statues tears apart the history and culture of our great country raises numerous questions, among them: Who is encompassed in that our?

title: Silicon Valley Flocks to Foiling, Racing Above the Bays Waves

Dozens of people skim across the waters at speeds of up to 40 miles per hour, kites far ahead and their boards floating two feet above the chop of the waves. They move so smoothly and quietly that some riders are on their cellphones.

description: In a recent letter to Tom Price, the secretary of health and human services, congressional Democrats demanded detailed information on his plans for marketing and outreach during open enrollment for Affordable Care Act coverage.

title: Getting People to Enroll in Health Plans While Trump Attacks Them
description: NASHVILLE  Sharon Barker isnt used to recruiting new health insurance customers in deepest summer, long before the enrollment season for the Affordable Care Act. But this year, everything is different.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Aug. 21
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: The Red Cap Aside, Trump Souvenirs Are a Hard Sell
description: WASHINGTON  On a recent trip to Washington for a research symposium, Michelle Beermann veered into a nearby gift shop, drawn by the prospect of adding to her new bust collection.

title: A Tranquil Swimming Hole Is Overwhelmed by Its Own Internet Fame
description: DENNING, N.Y.  For decades, hikers in the Catskills have gone swimming in a freshwater pool in Sundown Wild Forest, near the foot of Peekamoose Mountain. They called it the Blue Hole because of the crystalline quality of its water, and for many, a trip there was a cherished tradition.

title: Review: In Good Karma Hospital, Some Familiar TV Templates
description: No fancy tests are needed to map the pop-cultural DNA of The Good Karma Hospital, a British dramedy whose six-episode first season arrives Monday on AcornTV.

title: Victims of the Terrorist Attacks in Spain
description: Dignitaries and officials held a minute of silence for the victims of the terrorist attacks in Spain. They were citizens of 34 countries. Here are a few of them.

title: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: Patricia Williams Goes From Crime to Comedy
description: In her new memoir, Rabbit, Patricia Williams writes that there is no simple answer to the question of how she went from living in an illegal liquor house, to running from the cops, to living in the suburbs with a flock of ducks outside my window. This standup comedian, who performs as Ms. Pat, grew up in Atlanta during the crack epidemic, one of five children of an alcoholic single mother. By 15, Ms. Williams had two children of her own. She went on to sell crack (she was shot twice) and spent time in jail.

title: Heng on South Koreas Response to Donald Trump
description: President Moon Jae-in of South Korea bluntly rebuked the United States, signaling that President Trumps fire-and-fury approach to North Korea is straining the alliance between South Korea and the United States.

title: Before a Solar Eclipse Crosses 14 States, a Great American Road Trip
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Americans across the country this weekend began a great, if brief, migration, rushing toward a swath of territory stretching from Oregon to South Carolina for a chance to witness a total eclipse of the sun.

title: The Political Failure of Trickle-Down Economics
description: Tomorrows column is in part about the political failure of Trumpcare, which was  despite all those populist noises during the campaign  a case of trickle-down economics on steroids: huge benefit cuts for lower- and middle-income families, to provide huge tax cuts for a tiny minority.

title: We Need to Move, Not Destroy, Confederate Monuments
description: Its a summer of sequels. The culture wars are back. So is the civil rights movement. So is the Civil War. They were all in evidence in Charlottesville, Va., on Aug. 12, when a protest over the planned removal from a city park of a statue of the Southern Civil War general Robert E. Lee exploded in violence. Two sets of protesters met and clashed: a battalion of white nationalists, neo-Nazis and Ku Klux Klanners and a crowd of counterprotesters, some with Black Lives Matter placards.

title: More Charities Cancel Fund-Raisers at Trumps Mar-a-Lago Club
description: With its ornate 20,000-square-foot ballroom and manicured lawns, President Trumps Mar-a-Lago Club in Palm Beach, Fla., is often the site of elaborate fund-raisers, drawing big charities  and big dollars.

title: James Murphy Wants to Justify LCD Soundsystems Existence (Again)
description: The musician James Murphy is the kind of guy who can  and will  tell an intimate David Bowie story, while also making it clear that he knows its a bit embarrassing, or at least uncomfortable, to be the kind of guy who might drop a two-ton name like that out of nowhere. He can tell what youre thinking and hes thinking it, too.

title: In His Own Words: Jerry Lewis in The New York Times
description: Our coverage of Jerry Lewis over his career.

title: The Saltshaker Trick
description: Dear Diary:

title: Something to Mind
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  London is a huge city, and without a doubt, the most convenient way to get around is the London Underground, or Tube. As a native New Yorker, it was a revelation to me that I could ride on a subway system that 1) was either air-conditioned or extremely well-ventilated, 2) offered free Wi-Fi, 3) was inhabited by citizens who seemingly had no interest in bothering one another for any reason other than to ask directions in the politest, most British way possible, and 4) was mostly unscented, in the sense that no one had recently urinated in public. It is also fast and relatively quiet.

title: Jakarta, the City Where Nobody Wants to Walk
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Dita Wahyunita doesnt like walking the streets of the Indonesian capital.

title: Talk of Preventive War Rises in White House Over North Korea
description: Not since 2002, as the United States built a case for war in Iraq, has there been so much debate inside the White House about the merits  and the enormous risks  of pre-emptive military action against an adversary nation.

title: Barcelona Attacks
description: Where the plot in Barcelona was planned and carried out.

title: For Jerry Lewis, Few Statuettes but Lots of Influence
description: Sometimes the measure of a career isnt so much in the work that you do as in the influence that you have. A case in point: Jerry Lewis.

title: Afghan Forces Are Praised, Despite Still Relying Heavily on U.S. Help
description: CAMP MOREHEAD, Afghanistan  In an hourlong ceremony in a valley a few miles southeast of Kabul on Sunday, more than 300 members of the Afghan National Army Special Operations Command stood at attention at Camp Morehead, a training base, as a succession of officials, American and Afghan, told them how successful they had been at fighting the Taliban.

title: Continued Use of Long Putter Raises Concerns on the Senior Tour
description: The Golf Channel analyst Brandel Chamblee was watching the second round of the United States Senior Open in June when television cameras zoomed in on Bernhard Langer as he attempted a 7-foot eagle putt on the 14th hole.

title: Two Men From Elite Universities Charged With a Killing Dark and Disturbing
description: CHICAGO  Since the death last month of a man in a downtown luxury apartment here, details had trickled out, perplexing and graphic. Two employees of elite universities were accused of fatally stabbing the man and then fleeing across the country in an attempt to avoid capture.

title: Bannon Was Set for a Graceful Exit. Then Came Charlottesville.
description: WASHINGTON  John F. Kelly, the new White House chief of staff, told Stephen K. Bannon in late July that he needed to go: No need for it to get messy, Mr. Kelly told Mr. Bannon, according to several people with firsthand knowledge of the exchange. The two worked out a mutually amicable departure date for mid-August, with President Trumps blessing.

title: Barcelona Attack Suspects Had Ties to Imam Linked to ISIS
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Until Thursday, just hours before the Barcelona attack, many of the young men seemed to be living completely normal lives. One had slept late, his mother said. Another had worked as a waiter serving wine in a mountaintop restaurant days before. Several were eating kebabs, looking relaxed.

title: 10 Missing After U.S. Navy Ship and Oil Tanker Collide Off Singapore
description: BANGKOK  Ten Navy sailors were missing and five were injured on Monday after a United States destroyer collided with an oil tanker off the coast of Singapore, the Navy said, the second accident involving a Navy ship and a cargo vessel in recent months.

title: Young Mets Shortstop Learns the Cost of an Untimely Double Pump
description: As the Mets turn the rest of this disappointing season into a training ground for their young prospects, some of the lessons are bound to be more painful than others.

title: Gov. Cuomos Wise Move on Congestion Pricing
description: Some New York politicians have argued that the State Legislature will never approve a system of tolls and taxi fees, known as congestion pricing, which could help reduce traffic on the streets of Manhattan and pay for much-needed transit improvements. Getting lawmakers to back this idea will be difficult, as former Mayor Michael Bloombergs failed effort a decade ago shows, but it ought not to be impossible.

title: White House Bracing for an Angry Reception in Phoenix
description: WASHINGTON  Officials in the White House and in Arizona are bracing for a furious reception to President Trumps campaign rally in Phoenix this week, amid the fallout from his comments faulting both sides for racially charged violence in Charlottesville, Va.

title: Behind the Bluster of Steve Bannons #War Cry
description: Stephen K. Bannon left the White House with a frightful howl indeed.

title: Lender to Foreign Students Raises $40 Million in Financing
description: As American universities interest in courting international students intensifies, an online lender that caters to them has drawn significant new financing.

title: Whole Foods Voting on Amazon Takeover, and Pending Verdict in Samsung Case
description: Heres a look at whats coming up this week.

title: Yankees Fall to Red Sox as Aaron Judges Struggles Continue
description: BOSTON  Imagine if, week after week, as the Yankees chased a playoff berth, they anchored their lineup with Chris Carter, the often-booed, twice-released, feast-or-mostly-famine slugger.

title: Crowded TV Marketplace Gets Ready for Three Tech Giants
description: Apple has more than $1 billion budgeted for original programming, Facebook wants its own version of Scandal and Google is ready to spend up to $3 million per episode on a drama.

title: Justin Verlander Prevails in Pitchers Duel as Tigers Beat the Dodgers
description: Justin Verlander and Kenta Maeda took no-hitters into the sixth inning on Sunday, but only Verlander kept an outstanding performance going as the Detroit Tigers trounced the Los Angeles Dodgers, 6-1, at Comerica Park.

title: Quotation of the Day: With Sly Wit, Humanizing a Struggle for Justice
description: The Negro has a callus growing on his soul, and its getting harder and harder to hurt him there.

title: Game of Thrones Season 7, Episode 6: Beyond the Wall
description: In a cozy ships cabin on Sunday, the two designated world-savers of Game of Thrones shared sexy-time gazes and a pledge to fight together for the future of humankind.

title: Twin Peaks Season 3, Episode 15: The Body Electric
description: Did you know that there are only three episodes of Twin Peaks: The Return left: one airing next week, and two the Sunday before Labor Day? Lately Ive seen some chatter on social media lamenting how close we are to the end, mainly because its becoming increasingly apparent that David Lynch and Mark Frost have no plans to bring back the chipper, can-do form of Agent Dale Cooper until close to the end of the series (if even then). Some fans are miffed that one of the elements that defined the original Twin Peaks may never become a significant part of this revival.

title: No Corrections: August 21, 2017
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, August 21, 2017.

title: Lobbyist at Trump Campaign Meeting Has a Web of Russian Connections
description: WASHINGTON  Rinat Akhmetshin, a Russian immigrant who met last summer with senior Trump campaign officials, has often struck colleagues as a classic Washington mercenary  loyal to his wife, his daughter and his bank account. He avoided work that would antagonize Moscow, they suggested, only because he profited from his reputation as a man with valuable connections there.

title: Barcelona, Steve Bannon, Jerry Lewis: Your Monday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Whats on TV Monday: The Great American Eclipse and The Good Karma Hospital
description: Today is all about the great American eclipse, and theres a viewing option for almost anyone. Elsewhere, Acorn TV heads to India with The Good Karma Hospital, an escapist medical melodrama.

title: South Korea and U.S. Begin Drills as North Warns of Rising Tensions
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The United States and South Korea began their annual joint military exercises on Monday, while North Korea warned that the drills would deepen tensions on the Korean Peninsula by throwing fuel onto fire.

title: Word + Quiz: symmetry
Previous Collisions Involving U.S. Navy Vessels
description: Ten Navy sailors were missing and five were injured on Monday after a United States destroyer collided with an oil tanker off the coast of Singapore.

title: Does Time Capsule Hold a Ball Signed by Babe Ruth? Theyll Know in 2130
description: A treasure, possibly worth half a million dollars, may lie behind a granite slab at the base of the Bloomingdales flagship store in Manhattan, just a few feet from a window displaying designer handbags: a baseball signed by Babe Ruth.

title: The Faces of Bigotry: When the Hoods Come Off
description: The pictures from Charlottesville, Va., reveal what pictures of oppression and violence generally do not: the ordinary people who typically perpetuate white supremacy.

title: Failing All Tests of the Presidency
description: We are leaderless. America doesnt have a president. America has a man in the White House holding the spot, and wreaking havoc as he waits for the day when a real president arrives to replace him.

title: What Will Trump Do to American Workers?
description: With Steve Bannon out of the White House, its clearer than ever that Donald Trumps promise to be a populist fighting for ordinary workers was worth about as much as any other Trump promise  that is, nothing. His agenda, such as it is, amounts to reverse Robin Hood with extra racism  the conventional Republican strategy of taking from struggling families to give to the rich, while distracting lower-income whites by attacking Those People, with the only difference being just how blatantly he plays the race card.

title: Why Waiters Drink. And Why It Matters.
description: My former co-worker once drank so much during a waitressing shift, she stumbled through the restaurant with her intoxication on full display to guests. Even the chaos of the service rush couldnt hide the state she was in. By closing she was fired.

title: College Football Is Here. But What Are We Really Cheering?
description: It may be a sweltering August day in the Deep South, but football fans across the region are readying their R.V.s and face paint, making plans for the tailgate feast and nervously reading injury reports on their teams star players as they prepare for the opening of the college football season. I grew up in south Louisiana, where the weeks leading up to Louisiana State Universitys home opener always felt like an extended night before Christmas: a combination of giddy excitement, nostalgia and anxious anticipation of a day that seemed it would never come. Football was life; the rest of the year was just biding time.

title: When the Harlem Renaissance Went to Communist Moscow
description: In June 1932, the poet Langston Hughes arrived in Moscow as a part of group of 22 African-Americans who had been hired to act in a Soviet film about race relations and labor disputes in the American South. The cast had been assembled by Louise Thompson, an African-American activist who helped found the Harlem branch of the Friends of the Soviet Union, an initiative of the Communist International. Thompson saw in the film (which had the remarkably literal title Black and White) an opportunity to counter the distorted and stereotypical depictions of the African-American experience that plagued Hollywood films.

title: The City That Ought to Sleep
description: The mayor was upset. He had been accused in print of repeatedly engaging in unseemly behavior. Ridiculous, the mayor, Bill de Blasio, said of the allegation. A spokesman for him tossed in absurd and untrue.
Amy ButcherSam

title: The Faces of Bigotry: When the Hoods Come Off
description: The photographs from Charlottesville, Va., last weekend tell multiple stories. They document a rally, Unite the Right, where a protest over the removal of a Confederate monument served as a smokescreen for spewing racist and anti-Semitic hate. They show the counterprotesters who gathered to uphold the values of democracy and justice. They depict the murder and injury of some of these courageous individuals.

title: Teaching Activities for: Protesters Flood Streets, and Trump Offers a Measure of Praise
description: Before reading the article:

title: Sempra Bid Tops Buffett and Singer in Race for Energy Future
description: A month and a half ago, Warren E. Buffett unveiled a $9 billion takeover bid for Energy Future Holdings, setting up a battle with a fellow billionaire, Paul E. Singer, over the bankrupt Texas utility operator.

title: Charlie Sykes Is Unsure About the Future of the G.O.P.
description: You came to national attention during the Wisconsin primaries as part of the Never Trump movement, when you used your conservative-talk-show perch to help along one of Donald Trumps few primary losses. What were you trying to do? I was hoping Wisconsin was going to be a firewall of rationality. Turns out that we were simply a speed bump.

title: How Hate Groups Forced Online Platforms to Reveal Their True Nature
description: White supremacist marchers had not yet lit their torches when the deletions began. The Unite the Right Facebook page, which had been used to organize the rally in Charlottesville, was removed the day before the event was scheduled, forcing planners to disperse to other platforms to organize. And then, in the hours and days after a participant drove his car into a crowd of counterprotesters, killing 32-year-old Heather Heyer and injuring at least 19 others, internet companies undertook a collective purge.

title: Dont Panic, Liberal Arts Majors. The Tech World Wants You.
description: YOU CAN DO ANYTHING The Surprising Power of a Useless Liberal Arts Education By George Anders 342 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $27.

title: Three Deadly Days: One Towns Experience of the Holocaust
description: A BOY IN WINTERBy Rachel Seiffert 242 pp. Pantheon Books. $25.95.

title: Trump Administration Moves to Expand Deportation Dragnet to Jails
description: The Trump administration is working with like-minded sheriffs from around the country on a plan to channel undocumented immigrants from local jails into federal detention, according to several sheriffs involved in the discussions. If it succeeds, it could vastly expand the dragnet that has already begun to transform immigration enforcement in the United States.

title: When Bragging About Your Home Is Also Your Job
description: Austin Rogers and Kirsten Baumberger moved to New York from Columbus, Ohio, a little over a year ago, arriving on a bus with three suitcases between them. Mr. Rogers, now 24, had taken a job with an e-commerce start-up in the city and Ms. Baumberger, now 20, was signing her first modeling contract.

title: Camping Today: Goodbye Pup Tent; Hello Wi-Fi
description: If youre planning to spend the last weeks of summer sleeping under the stars, you wont be alone. A new wave of campers is taking to the great outdoors, though you might not find them in A-frame tents. Theyre in tree houses and Airstreams, king beds and plush robes, prompting campgrounds to install Wi-Fi, and inspiring start-ups to build hotel-caliber apps and websites for discovering and booking campsites with zip lines and fine food.

title: The Solar Eclipse: Highlights From Its Path Across the United States
description: A total solar eclipse made contact in Oregon just after 1:15 p.m. Eastern time on Monday, darkening skies as the moon obscured the sun and cast a long shadow across Earth.

title: Fixing the Subway Requires Pain. But How Much, and for How Long?
description: On any given day, many things can provoke frustration on New York Citys fraying subway system. It could be an overstuffed car on a hot day, a prolonged wait on a platform or an interminable delay caused by a power outage or equipment failure.

title: Your Photos of A Solar Eclipses Journey Across America
description: Photos from the path of totality across the United States.

title: Total to Buy Maersks Oil and Gas Business for $4.95 Billion
description: LONDON  The Danish container shipping company A.P. Moller-Maersk said on Monday that it had agreed to sell its oil and gas business to the French energy giant Total for $4.95 billion.

title: Australia Plans More Barriers in Public Spaces After Attacks in Spain
description: SYDNEY, Australia  A few days after the vehicle attacks in Spain that killed 14 people, Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia has unveiled a counterterrorism strategy to protect crowded public spaces.

title: The Showdown Over How We Define Fringe Views in America
description: Today in the United States, sweeping majorities of the public say they support fair housing laws and the ideal of integrated schools. Nine in 10 say they would back a black candidate for president from their own party, and the same say they approve of marriage between blacks and whites. That last issue has undergone one of the greatest transformations in polling over the last 50 years. In 1960, just 4 percent of Americans approved.

title: Solar Eclipse, Spain, Game of Thrones: Your Monday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Daily: What to Expect From Stephen Bannons Return to Breitbart
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: When the Nanny Leaves
description: As they walk out the door each morning, working parents are grateful for the nannies who care for their children in their absence. And yet, those same parents often struggle with the knowledge that their young children spend more waking hours with their nannies than with their mothers and fathers.

title: Fat Bias Starts Early and Takes a Serious Toll
description: A very slender friend recently admitted to me that she cant stand to be around fat people. Her reaction is almost visceral, and it prompts her to avoid social and professional contact with people who are seriously overweight. Although she cant pinpoint the source of her feelings, she said they go back as far as she can remember.

title: New York Today: How to Watch the Solar Eclipse
description: Good morning on this magnificent Monday.

title: Another Variation on the Selfie: Get Ready for the Elfie
description: Holly Black, an author of the best-selling The Spiderwick Chronicles fantasy series, believes that everybody would look better with pointed ears like those on fairies and elves.

title: After Dangerous Collisions, Navy Will Pause for Safety Check
description: WASHINGTON  United States Navy ships worldwide will suspend operations for a day or two this week to examine basic seamanship and teamwork after the second collision of a Navy destroyer with a large commercial ship in two months, the Navys top officer said on Monday.

title: Morning Agenda: Tough Times for C.E.O.s With Trumps Ear
description: Carl C. Icahn has long maintained that he never has had a formal position within the Trump administration. But he resigned from his advisory role all the same.

title: As Trump Rolls Out War Plan, Taliban Are Gaining
description: TACTICAL BASE GAMBERI, Afghanistan  Lt. Gen. Mohammad Zaman Waziri had an immediate question about the possibility that President Trump would send more American troops to Afghanistan.

title: Finland Attack Suspect, a Moroccan Youth, Was Flagged for Extremist Views
description: The Moroccan teenager accused of carrying out Finlands first jihadist terrorist attack had been flagged months ago for extremist views, around the time he was denied asylum, the authorities said on Monday.

title: President Buhari Returns to Nigeria, Facing Serious Challenges
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  Throngs of cheering people lined a freeway in Abuja, Nigeria, over the weekend to welcome a countryman who has spent much of 2017 overseas: the president.

title: After Big Ben Rings Out, the Sound of Silence in London
description: LONDON  Ask not for whom the bell tolls  at least not for the next four years at Parliament.

title: Reader Idea | Before Tackling Shakespeare, Students Analyze Puzzling Photos
description: Browse all our Reader Ideas.

title: U.S. Sharply Curtails Visa Services in Russia
description: MOSCOW  The American diplomatic mission to Russia said Monday that it planned to sharply reduce visa services because of Moscows order to cut its staff, the latest in a series of tit-for-tat penalties by the two countries.

title: California Today: The Rise of the Super Commuter
description: Good morning.

title: University of Texas at Austin Removes Confederate Statues in Overnight Operation
description: With little warning, the University of Texas at Austin removed three Confederate monuments from its campus overnight, 10 days before classes are set to begin.

title: Danish Submarine Inventor Says He Buried Swedish Journalist at Sea
description: COPENHAGEN  The mysterious disappearance of a Swedish journalist who vanished after boarding a Danish inventors submarine took a dark turn on Monday, when the police revealed that the inventor had changed his account, telling investigators that she died on his vessel and that he had buried her at sea.

title: Denzel Washington to Star in Iceman Cometh on Broadway
description: Denzel Washington will return to Broadway this spring in a revival of Eugene ONeills The Iceman Cometh.

title: Great Wall Motor of China Sets Its Sights on Jeep
description: China is trying to clamp down on overseas acquisitions by its companies. Hostility is growing in the United States toward Chinese deals. And the auto industry faces substantial change in the form of battery-powered vehicles and autonomous cars.

title: Christopher Cantwell, White Nationalist in Vice Video, Braces for Charges
description: By at least one measure, Christopher Cantwell, a self-described white nationalist, said he believed his decision to be interviewed in a Vice News report had worked out magnificently.

title: South Korea Faces an Uncomfortable Reality: A Nuclear Neighbor
description: SEOUL, South Korea  As the United States debates the wisdom of military action against North Korea, its allies in South Korea have largely moved on and reached an uncomfortable conclusion  that they may have no choice but to live with a nuclear-armed neighbor.

title: At a Dark Time in My Life, He Brought Me Joy: Comedians Mourn and Celebrate Jerry Lewis
description: Multiple generations of comedians mourned Jerry Lewis and celebrated his work after news of his death at 91 broke Sunday afternoon.

title: Marijuana Tied to Hypertension Risk
description: Marijuana use may be a cause of high blood pressure, a new study reports.

title: T Magazines New Editor: From Glossies to Global Vision
description: Growing up in Hawaii in the early 1990s, Hanya Yanagihara, the new editor in chief of T: The New York Times Style Magazine, wasnt the sort of teenager who dog-eared issues of Vogue and worshiped at the altar of Richard Avedon.

title: Books, Photos and Animals
description: Benefits were held for the East Hampton Library, Guild Hall and Veterinarians International.

title: Liberty University Alumni Return Diplomas in Protest of Trump Remarks
description: Dozens of Liberty University alumni plan to return their diplomas in protest after the universitys leader, Jerry Falwell Jr., defended President Trumps response to the white supremacist rally and deadly car attack in Charlottesville, Va.

title: Van Driver in Barcelona Attack Is Killed by Police
description: SUBIRATS, Spain  The woman who spotted him on Monday afternoon said the young man was wearing unusually bulky clothes for a hot summer day. On a second look, she told the police when she phoned in the tip, she had no doubt he was the fugitive suspected of driving the van in last weeks terrorist attack in Barcelona.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Readers of Cooking receive emails five days a week discussing food and suggesting recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here. Download the NYT Cooking app here.

title: The Case for a Breakfast Feast
description: Many of us grab coffee and a quick bite in the morning and eat more as the day goes on, with a medium-size lunch and the largest meal of the day in the evening. But a growing body of research on weight and health suggests we may be doing it all backward.

title: After 127 Years, the Gavel Falls on a Connecticut Courthouse
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn.  In the second-floor courtroom of the granite courthouse here, where rows of Victorian chandeliers cast a glow on oil portraits of long-gone judges, one can imagine a rogues gallery of criminals, scoundrels and iconoclasts  horse thieves, adulterers and violators of the Sunday blue laws  stretching back to 1890.

title: No, Seriously, Dont Look at the Sun During the Eclipse Without Special Glasses
description: Were all guilty of occasionally disregarding the warnings of scientists. Let she who has never ignored the risks and eaten raw cookie dough cast the first stone.

title: Insider Trading Case to Be a Test of the Role of Friendship
description: Inside information is like a childs allowance, burning a hole in the pocket of the recipient who just has to pass it along to others. But not everyone who gets a tip about an impending deal violates the law. There is a fuzzy line between innocent trades and securities violations.

title: When Trump Was Jealous of Jerry Lewis
description: The first time I met Donald Trump, he told me he wanted to be like Jerry Lewis.

title: New App Tracks Whats In Season From Coast to Coast
description: The Seasonal Food Guide is a convenient new app that tells you whats in season state by state. It makes it easy to check on Colorados blackberries in late summer or discover that, if youre in Kentucky at this time of year, you are out of luck when it comes to local asparagus. The app gives recipes and background information on the produce. It was created in consultation with scientists by the nonprofit Grace Communications Foundation, which works to educate the public about food sustainability: The Seasonal Food Guide, seasonalfoodguide.org.

title: Venezuela Cancels Gustavo Dudamel Tour After His Criticisms
description: After struggling to remain above the fray, the conductor Gustavo Dudamel has increasingly criticized the rulers of his native Venezuela this year as an escalating political crisis has roiled the nation. Now he is facing the consequences: The Venezuelan government has canceled Mr. Dudamels upcoming tour of the United States with the National Youth Orchestra of Venezuela.

title: Shailene Woodley on Her Emmy Nomination and Feminist Evolution
description: Once again, the women of Big Little Lies will be pitted against one another, this time at the Emmy Awards. But please dont call it a rivalry, said Shailene Woodley, who was nominated for supporting actress in a limited series alongside Laura Dern. (Nicole Kidman and Reese Witherspoon are up for lead actress.)

title: Death Ave Opens a Tap Room
description: Death Ave, the Greek-inspired restaurant named for a once-deadly stretch of 10th Avenue, has opened a tap room. Michael Tzezailidis, above, the owner, wanted to make beer on the premises for several years. Now, the restaurant serves beers made on-site, which can include a mellow farmhouse ale, a fruity hefeweizen, a gently citric Belgian-style ale, a golden I.P.A. suggesting black tea, a honeyed amber I.P.A. and an aggressively tart Berliner weisse. Soon 32-ounce cans will be available for takeout: Death Ave Brewing Company, 315 10th Avenue (28th Street), 212-695-8080, deathave.com.

title: The Best College Football Team Youve Probably Never Heard Of
description: The final 1943 Associated Press college football poll had a lot of familiar names: Notre Dame, Michigan, Washington and Texas were all ranked in the Top 20.

title: Simple Spanish Solution For Summer Entertaining
description: These simple drinking glasses come from Spain, where theyre used everywhere. Multipurpose and made of tempered glass, they can be neatly stacked and suit a tight budget. Use the small (7.5 ounces) for wine, a panna cotta, yogurt and berries, or serving condiments and pickles. The midsize (12 ounces) is perfect for cocktails like a Negroni or an old-fashioned, as well as milk or iced tea. And the largest (17 ounces) is ample for your pint of brew: Stackable Bodega Glasses, $25 to $35 a dozen, food52.com.

title: For That Glass of Ros, Remember the Savory Snacks
description: This summer Rtisserie Georgette started serving savory mini-madeleines with drinks. The recipe is easily made at home. Heat oven to 375 degrees. Butter a mini-madeleine pan. Whisk together 1 cup cake flour,  teaspoon white pepper,  teaspoon cream of tartar, 1 teaspoon baking powder and 1 tablespoon herbes de Provence. In a separate bowl, beat 4 eggs with 2 tablespoons sugar until thick and light, about 4 minutes. Add dry ingredients to eggs and mix in 3 ounces butter, melted. Add 1 cup finely grated Parmesan cheese and  cup minced nioise olives. Fill mini-madeleine pan and bake about 8 minutes, until lightly browned. Remove madeleines from pan and repeat to use all the batter. The recipe makes about 75, and they freeze well. Pair them with ros: Rtisserie Georgette, 14 East 60th Street, 212-390-8060, rotisserieg.com.

title: Food Scholar Shares His Story on the Upper East Side
description: The 92nd Street Y kicks off its culinary talks this fall with Michael W. Twitty, left, a writer who covers African-American food history on his blog, Afroculinaria. He will discuss his new book, The Cooking Gene: A Journey Through African American Culinary History in the Old South, which explores his family and how generations of cooking traditions affect communities: The Cooking Gene, $29, 7 p.m., Sept. 7, 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue (East 92nd Street), 212-415-5500, 92y.org.

title: Cupcakes That Pay Tribute to Grandma, and Beyonc
description: Inspired by her grandmothers baking, Tiffany Washington, above, began turning out cupcakes and cookies for friends in 2009. Last year, she and a business partner, Tamika Young, opened a small shop in Prospect-Lefferts Gardens, Brooklyn, but closed it when Manhattan beckoned. From a studio apartment-size kitchen and display counter in the Essex Street Market, Ms. Washington bakes and sells tender cupcakes with swirled frosting topknots, which start at $2.50, and red velvet and lemon Bundt cakes as well as brownies and cookies, all named for women like Oprah Winfrey and Beyonc. The shops name is a reference to Ms. Washingtons grandmother, Ilene Miriam: I.M. Pastry Studio, Essex Street Market, 120 Essex Street (Delancey Street), 212-254-2112, impastrystudio.com.

title: Kesha Returns at No. 1 With Rainbow
description: After more than four complicated years of public struggle with the music industry, Kesha may have shed her mischievous wild-child persona and electro-pop sound, but she still found her way to a No. 1 album.

title: The Burning Girl, About Intense Pre-Teenage Friendship, Never Catches Fire
description: The fat gods of fortune have smiled this century on novels with girl in their titles. Claire Messuds fifth novel is called The Burning Girl. Before accusing her of pandering to the analytics of the best-seller list, note that this books epigraph is from Elizabeth Bishops indelible poem Casabianca, which begins:

title: YoungBoy Never Broke Again Brings Back Rap Realism
description: Over the past few years, hip-hop has been swinging from one pole to the other. On one end, you have the melodic sensualists  Drake and post-Drake  who baked in the songwriting and emotion of R&B and pop to make hip-hop a globally accessible force. Lately, at the other end, have come the rowdy genre-bashing eccentrics, whove rebaptized the genre as punk, psychedelia or both.

title: In the Berkshires, Musicals With Ambitions Not Always Realized
description: Gentlemen dont wear straw hats anymore. Even if they did, theres no straw-hat circuit to wear them to.

title: Is the Stuff You Buy Over 20 Years Worth 40,000 Hours of Time?
description: I really didnt feel like writing about money after the events of this past week. It felt hollow.

title: New Jersey Is Front Line in a National Battle Over Bail
description: Less than a year after New Jersey established a sweeping new law that all but eliminated cash bail, the state has found itself facing a challenge familiar to others that have overhauled their bail systems: an energetic legal attack from the bail industry.

title: Margarets 3 TV Shows to Watch This Week
description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

title: Stop Everything for the Eclipse? It Depends on the Team, and the Coach
description: South Carolinas football coach, Will Muschamp, was asked recently if the Gamecocks had planned their preseason camp around Mondays solar eclipse.

title: Fine Print in Sempras Energy Deal Bears a Close Examination
description: Sempra Energys $9.45 billion deal to buy Energy Future Holdings and its 80 percent stake in Oncor, a Texas electricity provider, bears a close read of the fine print.

title: After Criticism, Publisher Reverses Decision to Bow to Chinas Censors
description: BEIJING  One of the worlds leading academic publishers, Cambridge University Press, on Monday abruptly reversed its decision to bow to censorship of a leading journal on contemporary China, after its agreement to remove offending papers from its website in China ignited condemnation from academics.

title: Jerry Lewis Was the Quintessential American Jew
description: Jerry Lewis, who died Sunday at 91, was not a man often overlooked, or pigeonholed. But in reckoning with his legacy, there is often one surprising omission. Hes rarely featured in discussions of the pantheon of mid-20th century Jewish comedy. Possibly this was because of his overwhelming popularity, tending to remove the necessity for any qualifying adjective. Looking at pictures of the crowds flocking to catch a glimpse of him and his partner, Dean Martin, at their hotels, youd think you were witnessing Beatlemania. Only Martin and Lewis were 10 years earlier.

title: Why Lee Should Go, and Washington Should Stay
description: Nashville  I grew up on Missionary Ridge, a Civil War battlefield overlooking Chattanooga, Tenn. In my childhood we could still find minie balls from the battle in which a young Union soldier, Arthur MacArthur, the father of Douglas, received the Medal of Honor. The wars relics were real and tangible  I still have a few on my desk as I write  and so were the wars perennial and tragic consequences.

title: Expanding the Windows Start Menu
description: Q. In Windows 10, is it possible to get the screen where the apps are displayed as they were in Windows 8?

title: Beet Salad with Goat Cheese
description: This vibrant version is a convincing argument that beets and goat cheese should be considered a classic.

title: Think Beet and Goat Cheese Salad Is a Clich? A New Recipe Proves Its a Classic
description: Although he grew up in Wisconsin farm country, the chef Joshua McFadden says he never saw a fresh beet, in the ground or in the kitchen, until he began cooking professionally. Canned and pickled is all I knew, he said. And I didnt like them either way. Now, at his restaurants Ava Genes and Tusk in Portland, Ore., he is the kind of chef who cooks beets in all ways and in all seasons, from the tip of the root to the tall green-and-magenta tops.

title: Stitching Together Forests Can Help Save Species, Study Finds
description: In the 1980s, an ecologist named Thomas Lovejoy conducted an unusual experiment in Brazils Amazon rain forest. As loggers moved in with chain saws to clear trees for cattle pasture north of Manaus, he asked them to leave untouched several small islands of forest to see how the animals within them fared.

title: Who Is Really Making Chihuly Art?
description: SEATTLE  More than 40 years later, Jeffrey Beers still vividly remembers what it felt like to have Dale Chihuly call up to convene a pre-dawn glassblowing session. You felt flattered and inspired, he said, jazzed by Mr. Chihulys caffeinated freight train of energy and the idea of making art with him while most of the world slept in.

title: Kremlin Names Veteran Diplomat as Ambassador to the U.S.
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin on Monday named a career diplomat and arms control expert who is under European Union sanctions as the next Russian ambassador to Washington, replacing an envoy drawn into the swirling questions surrounding contacts between the Trump campaign and the Kremlin.

title: Watching the Eclipse in Oregon
description: SALEM, Ore.  It was a lovely August morning here in Salem, with a warm sun blazing from a blue sky, when the world began to end.

title: Dominique Morisseau: The First Time I Imagined I Was Pregnant
description: Choosing ones words carefully: something every writer must do. This scrutiny can fatigue the people in our lives. It aint that deep, Dominique, Ive been told by loved ones. But not to my kind of brain. Its all very deep.

title: Thinning Hair? A New Treatment Offers Hope
description: When Heidi Imhof started losing her hair at 42, she also started losing sleep. Ms. Imhof, a lawyer, was afraid that blow-drying her straight dark hair would hasten the shedding, so she got up two hours early to shower and apply mousse and volumizers. When her hair finally air-dried, shed pull it back, hoping to hide the bald patches on her scalp.

title: Audi Engineer Implicates Superiors in Diesel Case, Lawyer Says
description: FRANKFURT  A cloud of suspicion hanging over Volkswagen thickened on Monday after a lawyer for a jailed former engineer said his client implicated top managers of the German carmakers Audi luxury brand in a continuing diesel cheating scandal.

title: Actor Richard Dormer on Game of Thrones and That Wicked Flaming Sword
description: On this weeks episode of Game of Thrones, Jon Snow led a group beyond the Wall and we finally saw this seasons secret star  Beric Dondarrions flaming sword. Turns out, its not only a great weapon for fighting the undead, it can also cauterize wounds, burn bodies, light decoy fires and provide heat on a cold winters night.

title: Ohio Judge Returns Fire After He Is Ambushed on Way to Court
description: A judge in Ohio who was shot and injured in an ambush-style attack outside a courthouse early on Monday managed to return fire with his own handgun before the suspect was shot dead by a probation officer nearby, officials said.

title: Barcelona, North Korea, Singapore: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New Scrutiny for In-House Financial Court as Banker Faces Ban
description: WASHINGTON  When a former Goldman Sachs executive was found to have mishandled confidential information in connection with an embarrassing leak at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the decision did not come in a typical court of law.

title: How Hard Can It Be for a French Girl to Go on Vacation?
description: Filled with talkative young French people, Le Rayon Vert is quintessential Eric Rohmer. The premise  one womans attempt to go on summer vacation  is almost laughably banal, something like a satire on the French vacation obsession.

title: Martin Shkreli Was His Own Worst Enemy, Juror Says
description: Martin Shkreli, a juror at his fraud trial said on Monday, was his own worst enemy.

title: In Search of Donald Trump at His Boyhood Home
description: By the dawns early light, I searched the kitchen of Donald J. Trumps childhood home in Queens for a coffee mug.

title: Airports (Like Carriers) Use Twitter to Ease Travelers Concerns
description: Before arriving at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport, Joe Carella, the assistant dean of executive education at the Eller College of Management at the University of Arizonas Phoenix campus, checks the airports Facebook page.

title: Trumps Changing Stance on Afghanistan
description: Before he became a candidate for president, Donald J. Trump was clear about Afghanistan. But during his campaign, he switched views.

title: For Tony Kushner, Its Angels Over the Breakfast Nook
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass.  I dont have a big angel collection, but  the Angels in America playwright Tony Kushner insisted with an embarrassed laugh. After all, evidence to the contrary  via a sculptures outstretched wings  nearly smacked a reporter in the head as he entered Mr. Kushners home here. Suspended from the ceiling, just past the doorway, was an infant-size ceramic angel created by the Peruvian-born Philadelphia artist Kukuli Velarde  one of four such angels hanging in the house Mr. Kushner shares with his husband, Mark Harris.

title: Bill Cosby Hires a Former Lawyer for Michael Jackson
description: Bill Cosby has appointed the lawyer who helped Michael Jackson win acquittal in his 2005 child molesting trial to defend him in the retrial of his criminal sexual assault case in Pennsylvania in November, Mr. Cosbys spokesman, Andrew Wyatt, said Monday.

title: A Birkin Bag in the Box Is Worth a Lifetime of Debt
description: After she lost her job, Angela Rivers found herself in need of some quick cash. Instead of heading to her bank, she delved into her Brooklyn closet. An avid shoe and handbag collector, she took out her cherished chocolate brown Birkin and went across the river to Manhattan, where she had an appointment in the chaotic diamond district at a pawnshop called New York Loan Company.

title: Between Birth and Death, Some Dancing and a Little Mystery
description: There is a fine line between a deep love of life and a keen awareness of its ending. This zone of ambivalence is the natural habitat of the choreographer John Heginbotham and the artist Maira Kalman.

title: Edinburghs Fringe, Now 70, Is Having Growing Pains
description: EDINBURGH  Once a year, the cobbled, medieval streets here host an extra million people, tripling the population of the Scottish capital for the nearly monthlong Edinburgh Fringe Festival, which used to be known as the biggest theater festival in the English-speaking world.

title: A Total Solar Eclipse Leaves a Nation in Awe
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  The United States basked in the glory of a total eclipse on Monday, as the moons shadow swept from the rocky beaches of Oregon to the marshes of South Carolina.

title: How Deep Sea Creatures Emit Their Own Light
description: The depths of the ocean are a lot brighter than you might think. New research from the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute shows that nearly three quarters of deep sea creatures emit their own light using bioluminescence.

title: Sonny Burgess, Rockabilly Wild Man, Is Dead at 88
description: Sonny Burgess, a rockabilly singer whose hollering vocal style and frantic, jangling guitar made him one of the most electrifying stars in the Sun Records galaxy in the 1950s, died on Friday in Little Rock, Ark. He was 88.

title: Missed the Solar Eclipse? Youll Have Another Chance in 7 Years
description: So you missed the Great Eclipse of 2017.

title: Coal Mining Health Study Is Halted by Interior Department
description: WASHINGTON  The Interior Department has ordered a halt to a scientific study begun under President Obama of the public health risks of mountaintop-removal coal mining.

title: These Graduates Throw Themselves, Not Caps, in the Air
description: MOSCOW  Ringling Brothers has shut down in the United States, but the big top lives on in Russia, which carries on a deeply-rooted circus tradition that soars above todays geopolitical conflicts.

title: Teaching Kids Coding, by the Book
description: One sunny summer morning this month, a group of 20 teenage girls gathered in a conference room in the sleek offices of a tech company in Manhattan. It was their fifth week of coding camp, and they were huddled around laptops, brainstorming designs for their final projects. One group was building a computer game that simulates the experience of going through life with depression and anxiety, while others were drafting plans for websites that track diversity at companies and help connect newly arrived immigrants with local community groups.

title: The New Yves Saint Laurent Museum in Marrakesh
description: In October, an expansive new institution dedicated to the works of the designer will open its doors.

title: In Marrakesh, a New Museum Celebrates Yves Saint Laurent
description: Yves Saint Laurent had many muses, but only one Marrakesh, the city where he discovered light and color, draping and caftans. There, in a series of homes  of which his final and most notable was the opulent Villa Oasis  Saint Laurent sketched some of his best designs (and hosted some of his wildest parties).

title: Identity Thieves Hijack Cellphone Accounts to Go After Virtual Currency
description: Hackers have discovered that one of the most central elements of online security  the mobile phone number  is also one of the easiest to steal.

title: Leo Hershkowitz, 92, Dies; Unearthed New York City History
description: One day in 1976, Leo Hershkowitz spotted canvas laundry hampers filled with documents being dumped into trucks outside the Municipal Building in Lower Manhattan, about to be hauled to a pulp mill in the East Bronx.

title: Mayor de Blasio Says He Does Not Believe in Congestion Pricing
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said that he does not believe in a proposal to charge drivers to enter New York Citys highest-traffic areas and use the proceeds to fund its ailing transportation network, an approach known as congestion pricing, which has lately gotten a boost from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: Hospitals Are Clogged With Patients Struggling With Opioids
description: President Trump this month declared the opioid epidemic a national emergency, a move intended to direct more funding and attention toward the crisis.

title: Victoria Azarenka Pulls Out of U.S. Open Over Custody Dispute
description: Victoria Azarenka, a two-time finalist at the United States Open, withdrew from this years tournament Monday because of a  custody dispute over her infant son, Leo.

title: Do Animals Overeat in the Wild?
description: Q. Do any animals overeat in the wild?

title: A Reverie for the Voyager Probes, Humanitys Calling Cards
description: In the shadow, one might say, of the Great American Eclipse, a major anniversary in the history of space exploration  and indeed cosmic consciousness  is being celebrated.

title: Herman Farrell Set to Close a 42-Year State Assembly Career
description: When Herman D. Farrell Jr. was first elected to the New York State Legislature, platform shoes for men were popular. Mr. Farrell has outlasted that trend, and more than a few others, having held his Assembly seat in Albany for more than 42 years straight.

title: Roger Goodell Said to Be in Line for New Five-Year N.F.L. Contract
description: Commissioner Roger Goodell may get a lot of criticism for the way he has handled issues related to domestic violence, player celebrations and the investigation into so-called Deflategate, but by and large, the N.F.L.s 32 team owners think he is doing a great job.

description: After taking a year off, the New York International Fringe Festival has announced it will return in October 2018 in a smaller capacity.

description: Steven Matz positioned himself next to Jacob deGrom in right field during the Mets batting practice Monday afternoon, and the two pitchers spoke for a majority of the teams session before a game against the Arizona Diamondbacks.

title: Game of Thrones Director on Jon Snow and Daenerys Romance, Dragons and Speedy Ravens
description: Alan Taylor was a key director in early Game of Thrones episodes, overseeing the first two season finales, as well as signature moments like the hatching of the dragons and Ned Starks execution.

title: Pictures From the Great American Eclipse
description: The Times asked a half-dozen photographers around the United States to record scenes from the total solar eclipse that crossed from coast to coast on Monday. Here are some highlights of their work.

title: Why France Understood Jerry Lewis as America Never Did
description: PARIS  Despite the traditional August lull and the terrorist attacks in Barcelona, the death of Jerry Lewis has been big news here in France, where the American actor-writer-director-producer was revered as an outstanding artist, and a polymath auteur. The French daily newspaper Libration stated it clearly and simply on its front page: Gnie Lewis (Lewis the Genius), summarizing in two words what the French have thought of the American comedian since the early 1950s.

title: Safety Plan for Jouvert in Brooklyn Borrows From New Years Eve Tactics
description: Hundreds of thousands of people are expected to flood the streets of central Brooklyn over Labor Day weekend for the Jouvert parade, a daybreak celebration that marks the start of Carnival in Caribbean cultures.

title: In Nashvilles Sky, a Ring of Fire
description: Nashville  My sister and nephew drove up here from Birmingham, Ala., on Sunday, the day before the eclipse, and out of pure curiosity we went downtown. The place was crawling with tourists. The Great American Eclipse website had estimated that as many as 7.4 million Americans would be traveling somewhere to witness the event, and this is the largest city in the path of totality. It seemed like a lot of them were already here.

title: Chilean Tribunal Weighs In: Some Abortions Will Now Be Legal
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Chiles Constitutional Tribunal voted on Monday to legalize abortion under limited circumstances, reinstating a right Chilean women lost 28 years ago in the twilight of the military dictatorship.

title: Yankees May Get a Breather, but a Gantlet Awaits
description: BOSTON  When the Yankees polished off a four-game sweep of the Mets last Thursday night, they could not contain their glee on Twitter. Above a screen grab of the final score of each game, the Yankees posted a message: Bend the knee. It was punctuated with a crown emoji.

title: Perspectives on the Eclipse
description: The 2017 solar eclipse seen from up above and down below.

title: Experience Eclipse Totality
description: Squeeze in among the crowds and witness the first total solar eclipse to cross the entire continental United States since 1918. An exclusive video by The New York Times in partnership with NOVA/PBS.

title: Angry Trump Grilled His Generals About Troop Increase, Then Gave In
description: WASHINGTON  President Trumps skepticism about Americas involvement in Afghanistan was no secret to his staff. But his top national security officials were still taken aback at a meeting in the Situation Room on July 19, when an angry Mr. Trump began ripping apart their latest proposal to send thousands of additional American troops to the country.

title: Publisher and Top Editors Ousted at Los Angeles Times in Leadership Shake-Up
description: Tronc, the parent company of The Los Angeles Times, abruptly replaced the newspapers top leadership on Monday in a shake-up that stunned many in the newsroom.

title: Chaos Breaks Out at Charlottesville City Council Meeting
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  They shouted down the mayor and City Council members, took over the Council chambers for about a half-hour, and gave more than four hours of impassioned testimony about how city officials had botched the response to the deadly white supremacist rally here this month.

title: Quotation of the Day: As Colonizer Flounders, Angola Flaunts Riches
description: In Angola, they call Portugal the laundromat. Its because it is.

title: Trump Outlines New Afghanistan War Strategy With Few Details
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump put forward on Monday a long-awaited strategy for resolving the nearly 16-year-old conflict in Afghanistan, but he declined to specify either the number of troops that would be committed, or the conditions by which he would judge the success of their mission there.

title: Germany Condemns Detention of Turkish-Born Writer in Spain
description: BERLIN  In the latest episode in the diplomatic skirmish between Germany and Turkey, the police in Spain, acting on a request from the Turkish authorities, have arrested a Turkish-German writer on vacation in Spain.

title: Trumps Strategy May Help in Afghanistan, but Few Expect Outright Victory
description: President Trumps new strategy for the war in Afghanistan, which he laid out Monday night in a televised address, is intended to give a badly needed boost to the campaign to push back the Taliban, step up the fight against terrorism and reverse the steady deterioration of security that has allowed devastating bombings to shake Kabul.

title: Full Transcript and Video: Trumps Speech on Afghanistan
description: President Trump addressed the nation on Monday from Fort Myer military base in Arlington, Va., to lay out his military plans for Afghanistan.

description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  We have a geography lesson from Timothy Polin today, along with facts about each of the seven cities in his grid.

title: The Deep Seas Are Alive With Light
description: Bioluminescence is not rare, scientists have learned. It is so common in the oceans that it ranks as one of the planets dominant traits.

title: Ryan Condemns Trumps Both Sides Remark but Tries to Move On
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker Paul D. Ryan condemned President Trumps blaming of both sides for last weeks violence in Charlottesville, Va., but argued during a town hall on Monday night that the president had since repaired the damage he had done.

title: Indians Edge Red Sox With a Run in the Ninth
description: Brandon Guyer scored when first baseman Brock Holt threw away Roberto Perezs bunt in the ninth inning, lifting the Indians over the Boston Red Sox, 5-4, on Monday night in a matchup of first-place teams in Cleveland.

title: China, Like U.S., Struggles to Revive Industrial Heartland
description: SHENYANG, China  The hulking, brown-brick industrial plants lining the roads were once the backbone of this gritty city. Today, they are outdated and unwanted, and the region is one of the Chinese economys most troubled.

title: Portugal Dominated Angola for Centuries. Now the Roles Are Reversed.
description: LISBON  How the roles have reversed: The colonizer, some Portuguese contend, has been colonized.

title: $417 Million Awarded in Suit Tying Johnsons Baby Powder to Cancer
description: In what may be the largest award so far in a lawsuit tying ovarian cancer to talcum powder, a Los Angeles jury on Monday ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay $417 million in damages to a medical receptionist who developed ovarian cancer after using the companys trademark Johnsons Baby Powder on her perineum for decades.

title: Mnuchins Wife Mocks Oregon Woman Over Lifestyle and Wealth
description: WASHINGTON  The wife of the Treasury secretary on Monday night took a page from President Trumps social media playbook for punching down.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday: The Wedding Plan and Black Girl
description: A dumped Israeli bride decides to go through with the wedding in the belief that a groom will show up. And a Senegalese domestic worker is thrown into despair by the life she had longed for.

title: Popes Planned Visit to Myanmar Risks Stoking Religious Tensions
description: MANDALAY, Myanmar  Even before the popes expected visit to Myanmar has been officially announced, it has become the subject of boisterous contention in a country riven by religious and ethnic tension.

title: Divisive Monuments? Put Them All in a Taiwan Park
description: To some, he is a hero despite losing a civil war. To others, he is a symbol of oppression. Some of the statues built in his honor have since been removed, but others remain because the cause he represented still has support.

title: Venus Williams Is in the Top 10. Stop Talking About Her Age.
description: TORONTO  The questions were coming, the dreaded questions, and Venus Williams knew it.

title: How to Move When You Have Dogs and Cats
description: Few events in life can be as stressful as moving. Add pets into the mix, and everyones blood pressure, including your dogs or cats, will most likely rise.

title: After Combat, a Photographer and a Marine Find Common Ground
description: A photographer went from taking the picture of a Marine under fire to collaborating with him on a book about war and its emotional aftermath.

title: Kurds Risky Dream of Independence
description: After yearning for independence for generations, Kurds in Iraq are scheduled to take a major step in that direction with a nonbinding referendum set for Sept. 25. The vote, expected to endorse a separate state, would be a mistake, increasing turmoil in a part of the world roiled by the fight against the Islamic State and further threatening Iraqs territorial integrity. Postponement makes better sense.

title: Why Is the Fed So Scared of Inflation?
description: When the worlds central bankers meet this week in Jackson Hole, Wyo., the topic on the table will be how to foster a dynamic global economy. For Americas central bank, the Federal Reserve, the biggest problem is at home, not abroad, and its latest view on the economy, released last week, shows it may not have a handle on it.

title: Live in a Poor Neighborhood? Better Be a Perfect Parent.
description: Elines children feared going to sleep in the closet of their studio apartment, but it was the only place they would be safe from the rats. Covered in blankets from neck to toe, Eline would keep an eye on the kitchen entrance and followed the sounds of the rodents rummaging in the cupboards.

title: Let Consumers Sue Companies
description: Washington  When a data breach at Home Depot in 2014 led to losses for banks nationwide, a group of banks filed a class-action lawsuit seeking compensation. Companies have the choice of taking legal action together. Yet consumers are frequently blocked from exercising the same legal right when they believe that companies have wronged them.

title: The Boring Little Budget Office That Trump Hates
description: The Congressional Budget Office never exuded sex appeal, at least not until recently. Its bland office building, which sits unobtrusively by a freeway in southwest Washington, houses an often-overlooked assemblage of wonkish economists whose idea of professional happiness is producing 10-year fiscal forecasts.

title: What Moderates Believe
description: Donald Trump is not the answer to this nations problems, so the great questions of the moment are: If not Trump, what? What does the reaction to Trump look like?

title: Why Vietnam Was Unwinnable
description: While I was working for the Pentagon in the early 2000s, wounded veterans from Iraq and Afghanistan were routinely bused down from Walter Reed Hospital, in Northwest Washington, D.C., to receive their medals. It was a heart-rending experience to see these young men and women, many of them missing eyes, arms, legs or even multiple limbs, being wheeled through the building.

title: My University Is Named for Robert E. Lee. What Now?
description: Despite the horrific timing of his remarks, President Trumps defense of Confederate statues last week revealed a viewpoint thats widely held in this country  and not just by neo-Nazis or white supremacists. Plenty of Americans find themselves conflicted about recent efforts to remove monuments to the Confederacy, be they statues or the names of buildings, highways or schools.

title: Adopt-a-Station Ideas
description: Ideas for renaming certain M.T.A. stations under the adopt-a-station program

title: The Game of the Name
description: Among the cash-raising ideas for New York Citys woebegone subways is Gov. Andrew Cuomos suggestion to let businesses slap their names on stations  for a price, of course. The governor said a few weeks ago that a $600,000 contribution might be the ticket to buy into an adopt a station program. The money would go to cleaning and repairs. In return, the sponsor would have its name on display so the train-riding public could marvel at its civic virtue.

title: For Asians Used to North Korean Threats, Guam Is Still a Getaway
description: TAMUNING, Guam  After North Korea threatened to lob missiles toward Guam, the people of this American territory in the Western Pacific stayed calm. One thing that certainly helped the mood: Its tourists arent the kind to shy away.

title: Trump Looks Directly at the Eclipse, and Conan OBrien Spies an Opening
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: Peaceful Protesting
description: Take a close look at the photo above, of the woman protesting violence against journalists in Mexico City last June. The New York Times used her photo in an Opinion piece about widespread human rights violations in Mexico.

title: Teaching Activities for: Claire Liu, a Rising Teenage Tennis Player, Reaches a Crossroad
description: Before reading the article:

title: After Combat, a Photographer and a Marine Find Common Ground
description: My camera shutter whirred as a rocket-propelled grenade wobbled toward Sgt. Thomas James Brennan, leader of Third Platoon, Fourth Squad, Alpha Company, First Battalion, Eighth Marines. Then came the explosion, followed by a ringing silence. Gunfire and shouting soon resumed, breaking a momentary spell. The noise, dust and confusion of battle made it difficult to know what had just happened.

title: The Strange Politics of Classified Information
description: Is it easier to keep secrets when you have fewer of them? Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan seemed to think so. Twenty years ago, he was chairman of the Commission on Protecting and Reducing Government Secrecy, insisting that the protecting and the reducing parts went hand in hand  that in order to safeguard the secrets that really mattered, those secrets would have to be few and far between. The commission combed through a long history of protected information, concerning everything from bomb tests to Communist infiltration, before calling for a vast reduction in the amount of federal information deemed classified. Moynihan hoped that the end of the Cold War had made Washingtons pernicious culture of secrecy obsolete. But history did not go his way. Congress continues to hold hearings on the same stubborn problem, and every year, the state continues to generate tens of millions of new classified documents.

title: More Young People Are Dying of Colon Cancer
description: When researchers reported earlier this year that colorectal cancer rates were rising in adults as young as their 20s and 30s, some scientists were skeptical. The spike in figures, they suggested, might not reflect a real increase in disease incidence but earlier detection, which can be a good thing.

title: Dear Match Book: Where Can I Find Brotherhood Through Books?
description: Dear Match Book,

title: What to Read Before You Head to Botswana
description: Botswana is known for its eco-diversity, and much of its tourism is driven by places like the Kalahari Desert, which is actually dominated by grasslands and fossilized river valleys, and is home to wildlife like cheetahs, giraffes and hyenas. But Botswana is more than its safaris; its a country made rich by diamonds, and its progressiveness is evident in the all-female safari guide team employed at Chobe National Park. Below, two books dig into what its like to live in Botswana, while a memoir by a geologist highlights the countrys nature by recounting his adventure in the bush.

title: Can North Korea Actually Hit the United States With a Nuclear Weapon?
description: Six systems that North Korea needs to master to achieve a long-sought goal: being able to reliably hit the United States.

title: In Campus Confidential, a Professor Laments That Teaching Is Not the Priority of Teachers
description: CAMPUS CONFIDENTIAL How College Works, or Doesnt, for Professors, Parents, and Students By Jacques Berlinerblau 246 pp. Melville House. Paper, $26.99.

title: A Pioneering Neuroscientist Reports From the Border of Life and Death
description: INTO THE GRAY ZONE A Neuroscientist Explores the Border Between Life and Death By Adrian Owen 304 pp. Scribner. $28.

title: A Day at the Beach in, Yes, Gary, Indiana
description: Gary, Ind., is rooted at the bottom of the U-shaped curve of Lake Michigan, a region of crisscrossing highways, casinos and forests of smokestacks.

title: Should I Turn in My Tax-Cheating Relative?
description: My relative works in the marijuana industry, which has been legal in my state for almost two years. Nevertheless, he has worked under the table during that time, earning tens of thousands of dollars and not paying taxes on it. I confronted him and told him that I didnt think the tax evasion was ethical. He disagreed, saying that plenty of people do not report their tips. Our relationship has been a little strained since the confrontation, but we still mostly get along. Is it unethical of me to report him to the I.R.S.? Name Withheld

title: Public Hospitals Treat Greater Share of Mental Health Patients
description: For people in New York with severe mental illness, the path to treatment has increasingly passed through the citys public hospitals, even as health officials and private hospitals try to accelerate years of slow progress by providing people with better outpatient care.

title: Inside Lizzie Bordens House of Horror
description: SEE WHAT I HAVE DONEBy Sarah Schmidt328 pp. Atlantic Monthly Press. $26.

title: The Wonder Women of Botswana Safari
description: By midmorning, the dirt tracks of Chobe National Park rumbled with vehicles. Uniformed guides cruised by slowly, the names of their safari companies emblazoned on their open-air, four-wheel drives. A friendly man in a Land Cruiser stopped to chat with our guide. He asked which route we had taken and which animals we had seen so far. His passengers, excited to be on safari, surveyed the tawny delta landscape punctuated by deep green trees and bushes through their binoculars, and talked excitedly among themselves. When their eyes fell on my guide, who accessorized with an elephant-print scarf and a green bucket hat, their faces registered surprise. My guide, unlike the other guides we passed, was a woman.
